int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The interventions were special lessons used with experimental classes instead of regular science lessons"
"Intervention lessons were designed around these schemata of formal operations: control and exclusion of variables, ratio and proportionality, equilibrium, compensation, combinatorial thinking, correlation, probability, compound variables, and conservation involving formal modeling. "
" Each intervention lesson focuses on one of the schemata, although as the program progresses one lesson may also call up schemata introduced previously."
"The terminology required is initially introduced in contexts which require concrete modeling only. Once familiar with terms such as \x93variables,\x94 \x93values of variables,\x94 and \x93relationships between variables,\x94 students are given practical problems which require the use of the formal schema for their solution. There is no attempt to teach, for instance, \x93rules for controlling variables.\x94 Rather, the student is put in the position where she has to construct the schema for herself in order to solve a practical problem."
"Feedback from the problem, managed by the teacher, shows the student the extent to which she is being successful in reaching a solution. [¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]" each schema is related to examples from the regular science curriculum. In the science curriculum, reference is made to experiences from the intervention lessons. This \x93bridging\x94 back and forth is hypothesized to be necessary for the consolidation of the development of formal schemata.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Cognitive Acceleration through Science Education (CASE), designed to test whether science education in secondary schools could be a context in which the cognitive development of adolescents can be changed[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Project teachers received the intervention lessons in the form of teachers\x92 notes, students\x92 worksheets, and problems. At the start of the project they spent one day together for an introduction to the nature of the schemata of formal operations, and a review of the main features of a Piagetian developmental perspective on learning. There was also a run-through of the specific activities included in the intervention lessons to be taught in the first term. In each subsequent term during the project a similar one-day meeting was held, including a mixture of practical experience with new intervention activities and some theoretical perspective such as bridging, formal modeling, or the possibilities of such a thing as general development. As the project progressed teachers played an increasingly participatory role, providing feedback on the lessons taught and their own suggestions for new activities and for bridging from the interventions to the regular science curriculum. In addition to these meetings, each school was visited by project staff at least once per term. Intervention lessons were observed and discussed with the teacher afterwards.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]" The total programme for this experiment consisted of 26 CA activities plus three introductory listening’ activities intended to introduce children to the working methods of the activities (listening to others, respecting others’ views, finding ways of disagreeing constructively, and so on). In practice, the teachers would do the CA activity with one group of six children on Monday, while the rest of the class carried on with other work set from the task board’, sometimes with the help of a teacher assistant. Each day of the week a different group would get the CA activity, so that a whole class of 30 children could be covered in each week. The activities typically took 30 to 40 minutes. Each activity related to one of the schemata of concrete operations described in detail by Piaget and Inhelder, and scaled by Shayer et al. (1988). This latter work, especially, provides comprehensive data from a large international study on the relative difficulty of each schema. One set of concrete schemata, however, was specifically excluded from the intervention programme for this experiment: those related to conservation."
"A list of the CA activities in the intervention programme for this experiment is given in 1'aiSi'c 6. Table 6. List of activities in CA intervention programme, 1999/2000[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"Each activity has a pattern in its delivery. There is initial concrete preparation’ in which the situation, apparatus, and any unfamiliar words and phrases are introduced. Then there is a phase of cognitive conflict where the problem is presented and the difficulty of reasoning comes to the fore as attempts are made to find a solution, with all in the group contributing to the construction of new understanding. Whilst metacognition may be included in this phase, it is often also made specific after the construction (‘How did we solve that problem?'). Finally there is a bridging phase, when the teacher shows other opportunities where that schema can be used.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"To investigate the effect of a cogniti ve intervention programme on the cognitive development of children in Year I of primary schools.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"Within a formal educational setting, the development of concrete operational thinking, as characterised by Piaget a nd Inhelder, can be accelerated in children aged five or six years with an intervention programme which provides well-managed cognitive conflict and structured opportunities for social construction, including the encouragement of metacognition.[¬e]"']
int_prov_raw: ['University/ researcher design', 'Local education authority or district']
int_training_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]"All of the authors of this paper have extensive experience of working with practising teachers to support the development of their pedagogy and we drew both on this experience and on research on effective staff development (e.g., Joyce & Showers. 1995) to design a course of six in-[¬e]"', 'Page 13:\n[¬s]"service days and three or four coaching visits to each teacher to help them develop the necessary skills. The programme introduced the basic theory of cognitive acceleration, allowed the teachers to experience the specific activities, and gave them plenty of opportunity to share their experiences of using the method with their children. Teaching methods on the professional development programme mirrored the methods of cognitive acceleration, especially with respect to social construction and metacognition.[¬e]"']

The technique is a group- problem activity in which students read a passage of expository text, paragraph by paragraph"\n" During the reading, they acquire and practice four reading comprehension strategies: generating questions, summarizing, at\xad tempting to clarify word meanings or confusing text, and predicting what might appear in the next paragraph. The articulation of these four strategies promotes understanding and monitoring of comprehension[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"For 10 weeks, the metacognitive systematic inquiry group completed the training instrument twice a week within the naturalistic setting of literature block classroom independent reading time. Every week teacher assistants placed one module on one of the four cognitive abilities into the reading folder of each of these subjects. The Reading Folder was a two pocket folder with the subject’s cognitive profile on the inside front cover. Twice a week, with prompting from the literature block teacher, these subjects read independently for 20 minutes (as did all students in the other two groups) and then[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"thoughtfully responded to one of the pages in their folder (see Materials section) for about 10 minutes while the students in the other two groups engaged in usual classroom independent practice reading activities. In the first metacognitive inquiry session each week, students made judgments of learning predictions about their comprehension in relation to background knowledge, long-term retrieval, working memory, and processing speed and then answered reading comprehension questions directly related to each of the measured cognitive abilities. They wrote responses in pen so that answers could not be changed. In the second metacognitive inquiry session, subjects analyzed their individual strengths and weaknesses and that relationship to reading comprehension. Literature block teachers monitored and encouraged student effort during response time.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"In sum, in this research we sought to test whether intermediate element ary readers in the classroom environment would improve their reading comprehension achievement if students deliberately monitored comprehension using individualized profiles of the five cognitive abilities needed to understand text as measured by the Woodcock-Johnson III (Woodcock et. al, 2001a) and then systematically reflected metacognitively on person\xad alized strengths and weaknesses during classroom reading instruction.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Students were trained to use CWPT by the participant teachers and by the researcher. "
" Specific procedures were indi\xad vidually explained and modeled by the teacher and the researcher. Students were then divided into pairs and role played each procedure."
"The CWPT procedures in which the students were trained included (a) peer-tutoring social skills, (b) transi\xad tion from regular seating into tutoring pairs and from tutoring pairs into regular seating, (c) retrieval and return of tutoring materials, (d) practice in tutoring, (e) tutee responding behaviors, (f) error correction procedures, and (g) point assignment procedures.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"After each teacher-directed lesson, students par\xad ticipated in CWPT to actively practice the skills covered during the instructional lesson."
"An answer key was also provided to the tutor (coach) to assist her or him in deter\xad mining correct responses by the tutee (player). Each worksheet was divided into two separate parts so that each player practiced problems that had not been completed by her or his partner. Consistent with CWPT procedures, students served as both coach and player. As coaches, students not only recorded player responses but also were trained to model how to solve problems when problems were answered incorrectly by the pl ayer. To aid coac hes in modeling how to solve division equations and word prob\xad lems correctly, coaches were supplied model scripts that guided them in the problem-solving sequence for both division equations and word problems.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"he effec\xad tiveness of CWPT compared with independent student practice to assist students in learning and practicing alge\xad bra problem-solving skills.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Phase 1 consisted of inservice for the volunteer teachers in the algebra problem-solving curriculum and in CWPT."\n"The researcher conducted a 1-day inservice with three of the four teachers involved with the study. The fourth teacher could not participate in the initial inservice due to travel problems, so a separate inservice was provided for her at her school . Teachers learned the basic purposes and proce\xad dures for the beginning algebra curriculum and received copies of the curriculum for review. Teachers were also introduced to CWPT through a short videotape demon\xad strating its use with students learning reading comprehen\xad sion skills. Major components of CWPT were introduced by the researcher, and questions and concerns were dis\xad cussed. Teachers were also given a handout that described how CWPT would be implemented with the particular algebra curriculum. The researcher was available for que s\xad tions by phone and through regular meetings held through\xad out the 5-week study.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"actual instruction in problem solving occurred for 16 to 18 class days.[¬e]"']
int_freq_info: 16 - 18 days within a 25 class period equals an average of every 1.4 - 1.6 days.
int_leng_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"The CWPT sessions usually last approximately 30 minutes and occur 2 to 4 days a week. A typical session consists of approximately 10-12 minutes for each tutee in the pair and approximately 5-6 min\xad utes for point recording and totaling. [¬e]"']
int_leng_info: Highlighted are materials in relation to CWPT generally rather than in relation to the specific study here, although it is implied that CWPT procedures were adhered to.

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"First, after putting the student at ease, the T-E read the following set of directions prior to having the stu\xad dent read the practice passage: In front of you is a passage that has been divided into three parts. Each part is on a separate page. After you finish reading each part, I’ll ask you some questions. You may look back at any part of the passage to answer them. In fact, you should look back for answers to questions that you are not sure about. To help you look back, I[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"want you to use this study aid. (T-E shows student the graphic organizer segment that corresponds to the first segment of the practice passage.) Think of the graphic or\xad ganizer as a “road map” to the passage. It will guide you quickly to the spot in the text where you can find the an\xad swer to my question. (T-E demonstrates how the student is to use the organizer.) Do you understand what you are to do? (T-E pauses.) You may begin. As the student read silently, the T-E took notes on the student’s nonverbal behaviors. When the student had finished reading, the T-E asked the first set of questions orally and the student responded orally. The teacher re\xad corded the student’s answers on a response form. For the second and third sets of questions, the T-E also re\xad corded whether the student actually looked back to a previous page for an answer to a designated lookback question. (See Garner & Reis, 1981, for a more complete description of this procedure.) Second, after informing students of their scores on the practice passage, the T-E introduced one of the two experimental passages. The procedure for S tep 1 was re\xad peated, including the directions for the use of the graphic organizer. Third, beginning and ending times for reading and answering questions on both the practice and experi\xad mental passages were recorded by the T-E.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" This study investigated the effects of a graphic organizer that was designed to induce students to look back in their texts for information they had missed, misunder\xad stood, or forgotten.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"The present research therefore focussed on the acquisition of critical thinking skills by vocational education students in Further Education (FE) colleges, and in particular on the development of the skills of reasoned argu- ment via practice. Our speci\x02c aims were to develop, implement and evaluate a programme for teaching critical thinking skills, particularly those related to generating and critiquing evidence-based arguments. The programme was guided by three broad principles. First and most generally, instruction aimed at improving the quality of the learners' domain knowledge should be inte- grated fully with the development of more effective thinking skills."
"Second, explicit descriptions (`models') of what is involved in thinking effectively should be made available to learners. This modelling of effective thinking should be accompanied by attempts to engage students in exercises which help them develop insight into the nature of thinking. Third, thorough, systematic prac- tice in applying targeted skills to complex tasks which matter to students is[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"required, and there is much evidence (e.g. see the collection of papers in Foot, Howe, Anderson, Tolmie & Warden, 1994) to suggest that these exercises might pro\x02tably make use of peer-based social interaction.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]" In essence, the programme attempted to teach the students Kuhn's (1991) four key argumentative critical thinking skills, namely, providing evidence for one's own theory, envisioning alternative theories, providing counter-arguments, and rebutting, in the context of devising the design of their projects and writing their reports. These skills provided a focus for practising both evidence based justi\x02cation and the generation of critique. Besides these four key skills, the teaching programme additionally addressed the issue of meaning clari\x02cation and the importance of assumptions, but the[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"most substantial focus was upon evidence-based justi\x02cation. The starting point was the fact that for the Additional Assessment students are required to produce six `items of (written) evidence', namely a project outline, a project plan, a portfolio of evidence from project activities, a record of progress, the project outcome, and an evaluation report. The lessons were scheduled for the \x02rst months of an exercise which is intended to occupy the full academic year. Thus, it was decided to focus on activities relevant to the \x02rst two items of evidence, the outline and plan. To this end, a series of activities were sketched out which involved: a) explication of the Additional Assessment speci\x02cation as it related to some aspect of the outline or plan, and guidance as to how the requirements might be ful\x02lled, b) homework where the students wrote down their preliminary ideas about what might be implied for their own projects, c) modelling by the research team of what peer-based critiquing would involve (by demonstration around specially prepared materials), d) deployment of the model by the students through the presentation and defense of their ideas in group discussion with their classmates, and e) preparation of an updated written record in the light of the group discussion.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" The principal aims of the study were to develop, implement and evaluate a programme for teaching evidence- based justi\x02cation to vocational education students in Further Education colleges. Teaching was via modelling and peer-based critiquing exercises in the context of the students\' project work.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Once the activities had been \x02nalised, they were implemented within the colleges. One member of the research team led the lessons within each college, although other members were present to model the peer-based critiquing. To preserve continuity, the same researchers were present each week in any given college.[¬e]"']
int_approach_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Thus, it was decided to focus on activities relevant to the \x02rst two items of evidence, the outline and plan. To this end, a series of activities were sketched out which involved: a) explication of the Additional Assessment speci\x02cation as it related to some aspect of the outline or plan, and guidance as to how the requirements might be ful\x02lled, b) homework where the students wrote down their preliminary ideas about what might be implied for their own projects, c) modelling by the research team of what peer-based critiquing would involve (by demonstration around specially prepared materials), d) deployment of the model by the students through the presentation and defense of their ideas in group discussion with their classmates, and e) preparation of an updated written record in the light of the group discussion.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The programme therefore took the form of a series of ten lessons[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"The lessons were scheduled for the \x02rst months of an exercise which is intended to occupy the full academic year.[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" the time available for the teaching programme (from one to three hours per lesson \x96 although note that the total time devoted to the Additional Assessment was constant across Colleges, so that those students with shorter lessons had time left over for re\x03ection and private study[¬e]"']
int_fidel_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"There were therefore several common threads that ran through the teaching across the sites, and also much sharing of materials and examples for critiquing. There were, however, also slight variations of emphasis, to dovetail with the requirements of individual colleges. For example, at College B, there was a slightly greater emphasis on problem solving, including conceptual- isation of the Additional Assessment as a problem to be solved (the theme of problem solving being emphasised in three lessons as opposed to one in college C). Likewise, because all students at College C were students of Health Care and therefore committed to running a health promotion action event for their Additional Assessment project, persuasive communication featured more explicitly in the lessons (the theme occurring in at least three lessons: see Appendix 1) than was the case in College B, for example (where persuasive communication emerged as an issue in two lessons). Nevertheless, such variations in emphasis were relatively subtle (students at College B did hear a little about persuasive communication, and students at College C did hear about problem-solving) and the number of common elements within the teaching programmes in the different colleges was much more striking than the variations of emphasis.[¬e]"']
int_fidel_info: Not explicitly - however variations in intervention across sites are reported
base_diff_ht: NA

int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"ngs. Teachers who usetheprogram. called Process-Based Instruction (PBI), focus upon developing students\x92 independence in learning and problem solving byproviding astructure into which curriculum activities can beplac[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"PBI plans are the strategic devices used in the program. Plans are structured sequences of actions and metacognitions that lead to successful task completion. They may be oral, written, pictorial or acombination of these forms. They have four components: those that cue or prompt students where to look for relevant information and trigger an action sequence; those that involve actions; those that promote monitoring or the checking of progress; and those that seek to verify whether the Iearning or problem solving goal has been achi[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"There are four instructional phases in the PBI model (see Table 1). In general terms, astudent passing through these four phases will be systematically introduced to plans and the concept of planning; plan construction, application and adaptation; and gain an understanding of how the planning process can maximize learning and problem solving endea"
"Table 1 Phases in the Process-Based Instruction Classroom Mode[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"The study reported here is an evaluation of the effectiveness of PBI at the primary school level within six months of its introduction. The focus was acomparison of students who were to be introduced to PBI with others attending classes where PBI was not to be used during the school year in which the study was condu[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]"ars. Experimental condition teachers involved in this study first learned about PBI through apresentation made at aschool staff meeting and were part of alarger group of teachers who expressed their willingness to attend aworkshop onPBI at their respective schools. These workshops were provided bythe authors and/or atrained consultant and extended from one half-day followed by individual consultations to two consecutive full days. The training schedule depended largely upon the school program and the availability of substitute teaching staff when training occurred during class time. In total, teachers received aminimum of eight hours of instruction. The content and structure of the in-service program was consistent with ideas presented byJoyce and Showers (1988)) namely, the inclusion of theory and the demonstration of practical components to maximize the transfer ofskills, strategies and material to classroom practice. Sixteen topics were presented covering the theory underlying PBI, practical experiences in plan development and adaptation and onthe use and maintenance of PBI methods in the classroom. During the initial training workshop, the Introduction and Establishment phases were the primary foci. Teachers saw many examples of plans, they prepared plans which were relevant to their own classroom situation and students, discussed the application of plans with other teachers and the trainers, and left with aworkbook that contained extensive notes and asummary of the program. Many teachers, including those involved in the present study, received some assistance from aPBI trainer (not the authors) when introducing PBI into their classrooms and consulted with atrainer on an informal basis - about once every two weeks - until they were familiar with the methods and had begun using plans in their less[¬e]"']
int_approach_info: Not explicitly stated but presumably large groups

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"The instructional strategy itself (Bau\xad mann, 1983b) consisted of five steps, which were repeated for each of the eight lessons."
"1. Introduction: In this step, the students are provided a purpose for the ensuing lesson, and they are told why the acquisition of the skill will help them become better readers. In effect, the introduction is simply a structured overview, so the students have a clear understanding of the content and purpose of the lesson that follows. 2. Example: As an extension of the introduction, a section of text that contains an example of the skill is shown to the students. This helps the students understand more fully what they will learn about. The example demonstrates how this relationship or convention exists in written text (main ideas in this example) and how the ability to understand the relationship or convention will help students better comprehend what they read. 3. Direct instruction: Direct instruction, the real heart of the instructional strategy, consists of the teacher telling, showing, demonstrating, modeling the skill to be learned. In direct instruction, the teacher is leading the lesson; that is, responsibility for skill acquisition rests solely with the teacher. Students should be involved with learning, but the transfer of responsibility to students comes in following steps. Heuristics are also an important part of direct instruction; they provide students with some structure or method to use when they apply independently the skill in the future. 4. Teacher-directed application: In this step, the responsibility for skill acquisition begins to shift to the student. In teacher-[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"directed application, the teacher still initiates the activities, but the student is required to “puzzle out” texts which contain the targeted skill. In other words, the teacher is still present for guidance and feedback, but the students are forced to apply the skill previously taught. This enables the teacher to monitor the students’ success in skill acquisition and then reteach the skill if necessary. 5. Independent practice: In the final step, the transition from full teacher responsi\xad bility for learning, to shared pupil/teacher responsibility, to full student responsibility is complete. Students are provided exercises that consist of materials not used in instruction or application and which require them to practice the skill independently.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"In light of the success researchers have had in training students in comprehension skills when instruction has been systematic and direct, it was the purpose of this study to develop a direct instruction paradigm for teaching children main idea comprehension and to evaluate its effectiveness relative to traditional (basal reader) instruction in main ideas and to no instruction at all.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" received eight lessons"\n" distributed over a 2 1/2 week period[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: NA

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]" The rule-governed group followed procedures outlined by McNeil and Donant (1982). Students were in- troduced to one of six rules each day through teacher modeling on a transparency and whole-class application. When students were adept at all six rules as a class, they applied the strategy in small groups and finally on an in- dividual basis. The following teaching sequence was used to teach the six summarization rules: Rule 1. Delete unnecessary material. A five-sentence paragraph was displayed on an overhead transparency. As a class, students decided which words were unimpor- tant to the overall meaning of the paragraph and these were crossed out. Two paragraphs were used to teach this rule.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"Rule 2. Delete redundant material. The second day the same two paragraphs were used to teach the second rule using a whole-class approach. Students quickly discovered that too much information had been deleted on the previous day. This self-discovery seemed to help students grasp the selective nature of the deletion rule. On the third day, these same two rules were practiced on additional paragraphs. At the end of the third day, students were able to apply rules one and two. Rule 3. Compose a word to replace a list of items. Rule 4. Compose a word to replace the individual parts of an action. These two rules were taught on the fourth day of instruction using the same paragraph transparencies that were used for rules one and two. Rule 5. Select a topic sentence. Rule 6. Invent a topic sentence if one is not available. Rule five came easily to students once they had mastered the dele- tion rule. Rule six was unnecessary since these were well-structured paragraphs with topic sentences.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" The first is a rule-governed approach that provides students with a heuristic for identifying a text\'s gist or macrostructure (McNeil & Donant, 1982)."\n"struction pro- cedure that emphasizes initial teacher modeling and guidance leading to in- dependent student application (Adams, Carnine, & Gersten, 1982; Pearson & Gallagher, 1983). The need for a study comparing both approaches prompted the present study which examined the effect of rule-governed and intuitive procedures on students\' summary writing and reading comprehension.[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Table 1"\n"Mean Paragraph Comprehension Scores on the Pretest[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"the concept of metacognition was introduced and an orientation to Raphael\x92s Question- Answer Relationship model provided. The classroom teacher explained and modelled both the reading and question answering processes - talking aloud as she decoded vocabulary terms, linked new information t o old, paraphrased content to sum- marize text and considered the demands of a question in order t o correctly supply an answer. Next, in small groups, the students read additional social studies passages and discussed, labelled and answered follow-up text questions referring to a wall chart and to individualized desk cards for reference as needed. Students were con- sistently encouraged to read actively and to think about how much they understood of the material read. Eventually, pupils in the experimental group were paired to read the text selections, answer the follow-up questions and speak openly to one another about the material learned as well as material not understood. Finally, at the conclusion of the study, all students independently completed the social studies reading and questioning tasks. Once again, in follow-up whole class discussions, the students verbalized the reasoning they employed as they labelled and answered the social studies text questions.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"This research study was designed to teach students the QAR model and to provide additional metacognitive instruction in conjunction with the adopted social studies textbook. The social studies instruction provided was used in place of the basal reading instructional program typically employed for reading instruction. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]" Students had to work in pairs on the execution of reading tasks following a consciousness-raising method, consisting of an orientation phase in which they explore the reading tasks and select a reading strategy, a practice/application phase in which actual performance takes place and a verbalisation phase, in which the steps that lead to a correct solution must be formulated explicitly. The programme was directed to four reading strategies: looking for key fragments, paying attention to structure marking elements (hinge words), making up questions (questioning) and mapping the most important information from a text (semantic mapping),[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Key fragments, consists of looking for important information in a text."
"Hinge words, is aimed at the use of connecting words (conjunctions and pronominal adverbs). By paying attention to connecting words during reading the reader can try to get a grip on logical connections in a tex"
"Questioning is a strategy entailing complex mental activities. Application of the strategy means that the reader becomes aware of his reading goal(s), identifies text passages with a high information value, constructs meaning on a level higher than word and sentence level, makes up questions which can only be answered correctly if adequate meaning has been constructed, and, finally, answers his own questions.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"Semantic mapping (mapping the most important information from a text or text passage in such a way that mutual relations between important information units are visible at a glance)[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Metacognitive learning cycle for 7th grade science
int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"In the concept assessment phase, students reﬂect on their science ideas and the status of their ideas before instruction begins. Each student keeps a concept journal in which he/ she records her ideas and the condition of her ideas. To avoid concern that students might use the condition terms, such as fruitful, without reliably understanding what it means for a concept to be fruitful, students considered the condition of their ideas by asking them- selves a series of questions developed by Hennessey (1991, 1993). To illustrate, when considering whether a science idea is intelligible, the student should be able to give examples of the concept or be able to explain his or her idea to a classmate (Fig. 4). For an idea to be plausible, the student must decide if his or her idea ﬁts with other experiences that they have had or know about. If the idea is fruitful, the student considers whether his or her idea helps in problem solving or explains phenomena in a new and/or better way. The aim in the concept exploration phase is to give students the opportunity[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"to explore phenomena related to the concept under investigation. During the concept in- troduction phase, the teacher collects information the students have generated and works with students to deﬁne patterns in the data and introduce the main concept of the lesson. At this point in the model, students revisit their ideas and reﬂect on any changes that may have occurred in their science ideas or the condition of their ideas. In the concept appli- cation phase, students are confronted with other examples of the science concept that can be understood using information produced during the earlier phases and again consider the condition of their science ideas. The Metacognitive Learning Cycle differs from the SCIS Learning Cycle because it allows for directed reﬂection in all four phases.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Students are encouraged to discuss their scientific ideas in the classroom

"In accordance with the direct assessment and intervention approach (Shapiro, 1989; Fuchs & Fuchs, 1990), the material used in the programs was taken from the school\x92s curriculum: mathematical activities, especially multiplication, division and arithmetic problem-solving activities, as well as reading comprehension activities onliterary, scientific and historical texts. Th"
"oups, the first phase of the training consisted of six sessions outside ofthe classroom using the material described above. Thetwo programs were modified according to findings from previous work (Bomas et al., 1990). The metacognitive aspects of the training were emphasized; the instructor\x92s verbalizations during the modeling stage were much more specific and directed towards the task in question, i.e., emphasis was placed onthe use of concrete verbalization for each task. The time allotted to each stage of the problem-solving training was adjusted to each task[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Emphasis was given to the problem-identification and the alternatives-generation stages (what to do and how to do it) of solving arithmetical problems. Onthe contrary, during multiplication problems emphasis was laid upon creating work methods which avoid the source of errors which are made during multiplication (forgetting what is carried over, confusing columns, erroneous addition, checking over results ...) as multiplication is straightforward and how and what to do are quite clear. Matching strategy and task was made clear to show the students which strategy must or could be applied to each task. The second phase of the training was conducted bythe instructors in the classroom. This phase consisted of 16 sessions each (the instructors spent four hours aweek for four weeks on this phase). The instructors\x92 job was to help the children decide which of those strategies previously learned was the best to apply to specific academic class material. If necessary, they reminded the children of the different stages, helped them with tasks they had not been trained for, and reinforced both the application of the strategies as well as task solving. A post-training evaluation took place at the end of these phases and afollow-up evaluation including the MFF20 scores and various academic achievement tests was carried out six months later.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Preskill development: Explicit instruction and small-group discussion of story paragraphs, story grammar elements, and stylistic features of stories "
" Strategy instruction: Explicit instruction, cognitive modeling, and small-group discussion of effective writing strategies "
" Strategy retrieval: Use of mnemonic charts to memorize story grammar elements and stylistic features of stories. "
" Practice in strategy use: Guided and independent practice in planning, composing, and redrafting stories. "
" Self-regulation procedures: Explicit instruction in and modeling of self-regulation procedures followed by guided and independent practice in the following: (a) Self-monitoring of strategic planning "
" (b) Self-monitoring of revision activities "
" (c) Setting of strategy- and outcome-related goals "
" (d) Self-evaluation of strategy use and writing performance "
" Additional practice: Practice of composition skills with supplementary material.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" This condition combined the instruction of writing strategies with self-regulation procedures designed to help students carry out the learned strate- gies in different phases of the composition process.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"First, before the start of the study, each instructor was taught how to implement the procedures included in the two different programs. For this purpose, the instructors received a manual describing in some detail the strategies, exercises, materials, and instructions to be taught and assigned to students in each session included in the respective program. The instructors were required to model each lesson until they demonstrated a high level of proficiency in modeling strategies (and self-regulation techniques), providing feedback and temporary guidance to students, fading instructional support, encouraging children, and praising them for good work.[¬e]"']

['Page 12:
[¬s]"The code name for the strategy is EXPRESS yourself through reading,
and the format is as follows: (1) EX--Jaamine the text to be read, and set a
purpose for reading. The students must look at the title and headings of the
chapter to be read. Record the title and section heading on the worksheet. (2)
P--!rior knowledge should be activated. The students must learn to ask
themselves what they already know about the topic. Record this on the
worksheet. (3) R--aead the text. (4) E--.E.xtract the important facts from the
content. Record this on the worksheet. (5) s--,aignificance of the important
information should be determined, and should be recorded in one or two brief
sentences on the worksheet. (6) S--Student collaboration. In groups of three,
including a high, middle and low student in each group, the students review the
important facts which have been recorded, and add any that have been missed.
In addition, they use the self-monitoring checklist to determine whether they
have completed all of the steps of the strategy. Then the teacher must review[¬e]"', 'Page 13:
[¬s]"with the class as a whole to insure that the students are zeroing in on the crucial
information. The last step of the strategy, student collaboration, was not
implemented until the students were able to work independently on the strategy."

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Learning strategy instruction started with the development of the students’ self\xad regulation belief system. The facilitator helped the students develop the important belief orientation to understand, acquire and execute target learning strategies. The purpose of self-regulated learning strategies, how, and when to use them were discussed and explained by the facilitator. The facilita\xad tor explicitly taught and demonstrated how the strategies were used with the aid of the appropriate self-instructions techniques. The self-instructions included the combination of problem definition, planning, strategy use, self-evaluation, coping and error cor\xad rection, and self-reinforcement statements. Collaborative and independent practice of the students were used to monitor the efficient use of the self-regulated learning strategies. The first five sessions oriented the stu\xad dents to the value of personal responsibility, self-efficacy, learning goal and attribution to effort. The facilitator delivered lectures with the aid of story telling, picture presentations and group sharing of ideas. Participants were asked to share their goals and ambitions in life through the lessons discussed. Sessions six to eleven were conducted to formally introduce Zimmerman’s (1989) 14 self-regulated learning strategies. Each strategy was explained emphasizing its use and importance to learning. Participants were given opportunities to practice each strategy on their own. They were explicitly taught how to write learning goals as well as how to properly pace, sequence and plan activities. The facilitator demonstrated the think-aloud strategy for rehearsing and memorizing information and then asked volunteers to do same. The students collated records of quizzes, seat works and assignments to monitor their performance and progress in schoolwork. A self-evaluation form was provided to help them assess how they were doing in their Mathematics class. Adiscussion about strategies to remedy low performance was initiated by the facilitator. The value of[¬e]"', 'Page 6:\n[¬s]"rewarding oneself when a task was accom\xad plished was taught through games and with the use of the “If-then Contract.” The “If-then contract” made the students thought of the rewards they would like to give themselves on certain conditions. The facilitator guided the students for the self-consequating to be fair and to call for and reward accomplishment rather than simply obedience. As for the last strategy, students were encouraged to seek assistance from their peers, parents, teachers, and tutors as well as to use the school library to seek additional information. Sessions 12-30 were facilitated for the participants to apply the self-regulated learning strategies in their Mathematics lessons. During the remaining sessions, students were guided to monitor and evalu\xad ate their own progress with the proper use of self-regulated learning strategies. Each week they have to complete forms for goal setting, self-evaluation and self-consequat\xad ing. In each session, the facilitator observed the students in terms of how they performed during the class activity. A case report was provided for each student.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"The SRLP, conceptualized specifically for this research project, is a training program consisted of four main components"
" The first component refers to the knowledge and beliefs of the subjects. Subjects introduced to the learning goal (Dweck, 1986), attribution to effort (Weiner, 1979), and self-efficacy (Bandura, 1986) are hoped to be oriented to the idea of self-direction (Bandura, 1989), self-responsibility, personal causation (de Charms, 1987), and self-regulation (Zim\xad merman, 1989) of their own learning."
"The second component refers to the explicit instruction of the self-regulated learning (SRL) strategies."
"The purpose of each strategy is to improve students’ self-regulation of their a) personal functioning, b) academic behavioral performance, and c) learning environment."
"For example, the strategies of organizing and transforming, rehearsing and memorizing, and goal setting and planning focused on op\xad timizing personal regulation. Strategies such as self-evaluation and self-consequences were designed to enhance behavioral functioning. The strategies of environmental structuring, seeking information, reviewing, and seeking assistance were intended to optimize the stu\xad dents’ immediate learning environment."
"The third component is the SRL oppor\xad"
"tunities given to the subjects which parallels the conceptual definition of self-regulated learning (Zimmerman, 1994). Subjects must be given the opportunities to freely use and have the appropriate environment to practice the SRLstrategies to qualify as self-regulated learners. The fourth component states that with the use of SRL strategies, subjects’ performance outcome must be consistently monitored (Butler and Winne, 1995). Moni\xad toring generates feedback that provides in\xad formation for confirming or re-examining and modifying strategies, thus, select and use more productive procedures.[¬e]"']

comp_var_rep_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"To maximize power and to ensure the intervention and
control groups were as similar as possible for all the demographic
variables collected, we stratified the sample on four demographic
variables: special education status, free or reduced-price lunch
status, ethnicity, and gender. Average normal curve equivalent
(NCE) scores for the two groups were then compared; if average
NCEs were more than two NCEs different, students were ran-
domly selected from affected strata until the average NCE scores
of treatment and control were highly comparable. This process was
repeated until treatment and control were equivalent in terms of
achievement scores and in terms of each of the four strata vari-
ables.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Metacocgnitive instruction to low-ability mathematics students  Mayer's model
int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"1. Techniques of metacognitive instruction, which (a) stimulate and develop students\x92 think- ing through insights into their own mental pro- cesses; (b) redirect students\x92 activities during the act of problem solving byappraising their own thinking; and (c) transform the classroom into anactive, inquisitive environment by displaying ateacher-student interaction with explicit discussion of not only what to learn but also how and why. This metacognitive view contrasts with the conventional approac"\n"the teacher usually focuses on what to learn and students are passive in the process. 2.Mayer\x92s model which indicates sequen- tially the steps to take in solving aproblem: understanding the question, integrating the in- formation into a coherent representation, designing aplan of what to dofirst in solving the problem, and calculating the results. 3. A procedure tested byElawar and Corn0 (1985) for taking the students\x92 errors as asource of information and providing feedback tailored to individual needs. This type of feedback in- cluded both praise and constructive criticism to guide the student\x92s self-correction in amotiva- tional way. This approach contrasts with feed- back that only takes into account right and wrong answ[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: 6th form students received metacognitive instruction to help them in mathematical problem solving. They were taught problem solving through steps. Also, wrong answers were treated as guide to provide students with individual feedback.

int_name_info: As the highlighted material shows, the intervention was developed by the author in earlier studies and is being applied here to a mathematics problem solving model.
int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Teachers presented the lessons in three stages. The first stage was the Introductory Discussion. The teacher solved aproblem on the chalkboard (to introduce atopic) or asked astudent to solve one problem to reinforce practice onthe topic already introduced by the teacher. The teacher used this stage ofthe lesson tomodel the self-questioning process in front of students by asking and answering the four questions derived from Mayer's mod[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The second lesson stage was independent work. Students worked independently for at least 15- 20 minutes solving problems similar to the ones provided on the chalkboard. The teacher moved around the class, providing individualized feed- back. The metacognitive feedback guided the students to focus onany errors they had made and provided clues for self-correction. The teacher assisted individual students in monitor- ing their own thinking instead of simply provid- ing the right answer when the students made err"
"e third and final stage was Summary. The lesson summary was accomplished bythe stu- dents themselves asthey answered questions asked by the teacher. Two questions that were asked frequently were (a) "What did you learn today?" and (b) "What did you learn about yourself in solving mathematics problems?" Stu- dents expressed their feelings and percep[¬e]"']

The control group left before the training began (they were promised the training after the experiment was completed). The experi- mental group (N = 10) remained with the ex- perimenter for approximately 17additional training hours. The experimenter trained the teachers in the metacognitive instructional approach for teach- ing students how to solve problems using a combination of lecture, demonstrations, open discussion, and simulation exercises. Metacog- nitive theory was discussed as self-knowledge and self-evaluation. [¬e]"', 'Page 6:

int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]" teachers, after receiving the training, were told by the instructor that they should apply the strategies learned in the context of their real classes over a period of three months. They were to generalize the strategies and the methods learned and adapt them to their students, using curriculum textbooks (without modification) in the context of their content area. That is, every time they work in their classes with a text, they should apply the comprehension strategies according to the guidelines provided during the instruction period. The strategies that teachers had to apply in their classroom were previous knowl- edge activation about the content of the text, text structure strategy knowledge, hierarchical representation of text ideas, and text composition. In order to teach these strategies, the teacher had to model, explain and promote both guided and independent practice.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]" In the generalization induction condition, informed training and self- instructional training techniques were employed. The procedures involved the teacher explaining how, why, and when the self-questioning strategy could be used, followed by these five stages:"
"1. Cognitive modeling\x97the teacher modeled the self-questioning routine by "thinking aloud" while reading through the text,"
"2. Overt external guidance\x97the students imitated the teacher's self-questioning routine;"
"3. Overt selj-guidance\x97the students read through the text by themselves while verbalizing the self-questions and answers aloud."
"4. Faded self-guidance\x97the students read the text while whispering the self- questions."
"5. Covert self-guidance\x97the students read the text using covert self- questions.[¬e]"']

The program provides instruction in the use of a self-question\xad ing strategy for the identification of main ideas and incorporates self-instructional training techniques to promote generali\xad zation of strategy across settings.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Students were taught units on the aforementioned topics by their classroom teacher based on the modified SSCS instructional approach, i.e. students\' brain\xad storming and identifying problems were followed by preparing and implementing their plans by means of group discussions with an occasional student-designed activity, and class presentation of answers or ideas. Since ninth-grade students in Taiwan have a heavy course load and take numerous tests, extra time is not available to them to seek extra materials and resources beyond the textbook. The search phase of the SSCS model has been modified to have students\' brainstorm and identify problems of researchable questions after reading articles from science newspapers or magazines, and materials prepared by the researchers and the class\xad room teacher. It is noted that the very same materials were also provided to the control group as a placebo control. The solve phase was not modified; this phase required students to prepare and implement their plans by analysing and investi\xad gating the researchable questions individually. The create phase was adjusted so that students could generate a solution or solutions by group discussions and communications. The cooperative discussion groups sat at separate tables and were asked to generate solutions and build consensus on the solutions. During this stage students had the opportunity to discuss ideas and to further modify their understanding of a particular concept. Going beyond communications, students within a group reflected on, evaluated solutions and answers, and at times presented the ideas or answers to the class in the modified share phase. At the conclusions of SSCS for each unit, the classroom teacher briefly summarized the content presented and led students to further questions. The most important characteristics of the lesson series are enabling students to become more skilful using problem-solving strategies and helping them become aware of their own ideas and ideas of others, including conflicting opinions among class members, which are necessary if one wishes to promote conceptual change. [¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"The most important characteristics of the lesson series are enabling students to become more skilful using problem-solving strategies and helping them become aware of their own ideas and ideas of others, including conflicting opinions among class members, which are necessary if one wishes to promote conceptual change. These character\xad[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"istics embedded in the lessons are aligned with the goals and purposes of the instructional method.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Learner can examine the SRL index and learning process using the self-inspection interface, as all SRL processes of individual learners were automatically stored in the SRL portfolio database.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Based on the system architecture (Fig. 2), the primary function- alities of the proposed PELS with SRL-assistive mechanisms can be divided into learner and instructor sides. Learners can log into the system via the interface on the learner side, and teachers can mon- itor SRL behavior of individual learners and manage learning activ- ity using the interface on the instructor side. Fig. 3 shows the registration and login interface. Learners must utilize legal accounts via the registration function, and then log into the system. After a learner logs into the system, he/she will be directed to ﬁll out a self-monitor form before progressing to courseware learn- ing each time. The system displays automatically the self-regu- lated learning competence indicators set by the learner during the previous learning session. The data ﬁelds contain the target learning time, number of learned courseware, the effort exerted while learning courseware, the target for degree of concentration when learning courseware, and the target achievement index of learner ability."
"After the self-monitoring form is ﬁlled out, the system guides learners in entering the interface for courseware learning.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"When learning time set by an individual learner is achieved or a learner presses the terminative button, the system directs the lear- ner to ﬁll out a self-evaluation form. "
" In addition to the self-evaluation form, all self-regulated learn- ing competence indexes and learning performance indexes analyzed by the system are also displayed to the learner. This function pro- vides useful self-examination information to individual learners as they conduct their self-evaluation processes. After the learning process is terminated, learners can view the self-regulated learning processes, including total learning time and the self-regulated learn- ing competence indexes using the self-inspection interface."
"Moreover, learners can interact with teachers via the discussion board and the Q&A module when they have questions during a learning process.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]" A learner can immediately progress Q&A with teacher using the HCL module (Fig. 9). The proposed system can automatically send an alarm message to an individual learner when learner’s idle time is over an assigned time (Fig. 10). Of course, a teacher can also con- vey encouraging messages or hints to individual learners via the hint message module.[¬e]"']

int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Thus, a novel ASRLM, which dynamically displays individual SRL states, including the learning time achievement index, sustained atten- tion index, effort index, learning ability index and reading index via a SRL radar chart, was designed to support online reading of English texts with annotations in a web-based reading annotation system. Moreover, the proposed ASRLM also promptly offers encouraging words or prompts according to an individual learner\x92s SRL situations. This study aims to explore the effects of online reading with ASRLM support on learners\x92 sustained attention and on the promotion of reading comprehension.[¬e]"']

I worked through one example with the children and explained how to"\n"use the foldout answer sheet. From day two, the experimental groups worked on the program independently at the back of their classrooms during a specified time period. The control groups received no supplemental instruction. When the experimental groups were working on the program, the control groups continued their work right along with the other children in the class. One period of about 15 minutes on 6 consecutive days was devoted to the first part of training. I met again with the experimental groups outside their classrooms to introduce them to Section II of the program. The children later worked independently in their classrooms for 20 minutes on each of 4 consecutive days. Each day, the students read one short story and generated two ques tions. Their questions were scored by their teachers, using a key based on the steps from Section I. (For example, the question asks for an answer = 1 point; it ends with a question mark = 1 point.) int_desc_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"The teacher or teaching assistant and pupils take turns to lead a discussion of a text adapted from children’s literature, with the teacher showing children how to engage with the writing in increasingly sophisticated ways. Specifically, the teacher shows the children how to apply four comprehension strategies: summarising, clarifying, questioning, and predicting. These strategies force children to check that they understand the content, to identify exactly what the problem is when they don’t understand, and to make inferences based on what they have read."\n"The method of delivery for the LIT programme is not particularly prescriptive: it can be used to teach whole classes or small groups, can be delivered by teachers or teaching assistants, and can be offered in addition to or instead of regular English classes (although children typically receive 3–4 hours of instruction as part of the LIT programme each week). [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"In the present experiment the original Piagetian system of formal operations was re-formulated and three groups of operations were identified: the group of logical operations contains the binary operations of propositional logic; the system of combinative operations is enhanced by taking into account further combinatorial structures not studied by the Geneva school; and the group of systematizing operations contains the operations of ordering (binary relations), class inclusion, classification, and multiple classification[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"For each combination of the operational abilities to be developed, a collection of structured tasks was devised in co-operation with practising teachers. Specifically, this team-work resulted in collections of exercises that were edited and mimeographed in booklet form. Each of the twelve (grammar-combinative, grammar-logical physics-systematizing) collections contained about fifty-three of these structured tasks. The fourth grade tasks for the systematizing ability were exceptions. These tasks were devised by using the analogy and experience of the other work and were not tried out and refined before their use in the main experiment.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"No direct rules were taught (in contrast with many intervention studies, where a specific performance or skill was probably learnt, e.g. in the study by Fishbein et al. 1970). The training was exclusively limited to combining, classifying, etc., the concepts of teaching material in a meaningful way in the particular context or discussing why the complex propositions of the texts are true or false."
" While teaching stereotypes limited the possibilities of using the structured tasks, usually one experimental lesson per week and two tasks per lesson (one at the beginning of the lesson as whole-class work and one at the end of the lesson as individual work) should be considered as a rule. As extra time could not be devoted to the interventions, the structured experimental tasks were alternative versions rather than additions to school subjects.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]" During the four-month period of the project, students in the experimental classes employed an inquiry problem-solving model to investigate the problems and issues related to the conditions of housing in their communities. In particular, student inquiry addressed the following questions: Does a housing problem exist in your community? What factors affect the cost of housing? What can be done to lower the cost of housing? What can be done to provide more rental accommodations? What are the rights and responsibilities of renters and owners? What should be done about the housing problem? and, What are the appropriate methods for taking social action in a democratic society? A variety of reading selections that included articles from newspapers and magazines, government publications, and brochures from political parties and special interest groups were provided to each class. Additionally, field studies and interviews with local resource persons were sources of relevant data for the students in their communities."
"During the first critical thinking lesson, students were introduced to a general concept of critical thinking, and a rationale for developing critical thinking skills in the social studies program, was discussed. The following lesson had the students consider a modified list of the critical thinking skills enumerated by Ennis (1962). Additionally, students were taught to use evaluative criteria "
". The two and one-half hour interview had been edited by the investigator to 25 minutes, and it included a heated discussion about the feasibility of rent controls, the interest rates charged by mortgage companies, and the need for government intervention in the housing market. Telephone calls from three listeners were also included on the tape. To complete the work sheet accompanying the tape, students identified, weighed, and evaluated arguments by both the interviewer and interviewee, searched out words and phrases that were emotionally loaded, defined terms in arguments, located irrelevant questions and comments, found examples of fact and opinion statements, and evaluated analogies. In the majority of classes, the analysis and discussion of the broadcast was carried on over a minimum of three periods,[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"The analysis of the radio broadcast was followed by several lessons that consisted of an examination of They Build Houses, Don’t They?, a comic book published by the Exploding Myths Comic Collection of Toronto, Ontario. The assignment for these lessons included questions that had students study frames in order to locate evidence of the cartoonist’s bias, identify his point of view, and evaluate his arguments. Additional activities had the students speculate as to how the interviewee on the radio broadcast discussed earlier might react to the way the housing problem was described in the comic book, and as to how landlords, developers, renters, and buyers would have been represented had the comic book been prepared by realtors. Finally, the students were required to evaluate the comic book and decide whether it presented an accurate assessment of the housing problem and to provide evidence to support their opinion. When presented with data in succeeding lessons, students were encouraged to note the source of the information, suggest the frame of reference of the author, and search the material for evidence of bias, ambiguity, and contradiction. In addition, they were to judge the authoritativeness of the data and the validity of the arguments presented.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"This paper reports the findings of a study intended to teach critical thinking skills in nonacademic secondary classes.[¬e]"', 'Page 2:\n[¬s]" employed an inquiry problem-solving model to investigate the problems and issues related to the conditions of housing in their communities.[¬e]"']
comp_anal_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"Two-way classification analysis of covariance with the data arranged according to treatment and geographic location, and with IQ and pretest scores as covariates, was the basic analysis used for the data from the nonequivalent control group design. The general least squares solution for unequal-sized groups was used, as recommended by Winer (1971, p. 498). The t test for correlated data was used to test pretest-posttest differences for the one-group design data.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"The question-generation-practice group read the same three pas- sages per session and was instructed to generate two good think- type questions for each passage. Subjects were told that good questions assessed the most important ideas in the passage, made them think about what they read, and could not be answered by underlining parts of the passage. The question-generation-practice group was included because of somewhat questionable findings from the Andre and Anderson (1978-1979) study, in which the question-practice group did not appear to differ from the trained group, and to assess any effects on quality and form of generated questions or on overall comprehension, related to practicing this sk[¬e]"']

[¬s]" The program using visual material was a new classroom version of Klauer's Program Inductive Reasoning 1 (De Koning & Hamers, 1995) and was applied to the third grade. The Program Inductive Reasoning in Reading Comprehension (De Koning & Hamers, 1996) consisted of verbal material and was applied to the fourth grade. In both programs, teaching and learning were embedded in a classroom dialog in which the pupils and the teacher explicated exactly how they reasoned inductively. "
"The programs introduce the reasoning processes using easy-to-perceive (visual program) and easy-to-understand (verbal program) materials."
" the visual material changed from building blocks to pictures of objects and to pictures of situations and abstract ®gures; the verbal material changed from short texts with everyday context to longer texts with everyday context and to longer texts with unfamiliar context (see Fig. 3).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"extending the stimulation of the development of inductive reasoning in the preparatory phase to the third and fourth grades[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 16:\n[¬s]"The teachers were provided with two kinds of information. First, the objec- tives underlying the three-phase teaching method were described in general, rather than abstract, terms. Second, the teachers received a manual with de- tailed examples of the typical tasks and dialogs to be used preferably in each separate phase. In a few sessions teachers were supported to connect the two kinds of information.[¬e]"', 'Page 18:\n[¬s]"Without exception the lessons were very demanding for the teachers. First, teachers had to be assisted in bringing about a process-focused attitude while weakening their emphasis on the product of reasoning. For example, they had to be taught how to ask their pupils questions like ``Why do you think this answer is correct\'\' or ``What other correct solutions do you suggest\'\'[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Each of the metacognitive (Number Town) sessions involved a direct Pr strategy as well as a direct cognitive (NR, P, L, and M) instruction (see Appendix A). The tasks were especially created for the metacognitive and cognitive group. This metacognitive training was verbal in nature and focused on prediction of task difficulty (see Figure 1) as well as on the tasks and problem-solving procedures themselves (see Figures 3 and 5). Each session in the metacognitive condition started with an orientation or rehearsal phase. Then, the need for a metacognitive principle was experi- enced and brought about in small group sessions.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"The five sessions were carefully designed to encompass elements such as story planning, modelling, trialling the equipment, exploring different animation techniques, filming, and editing. Each element was matched to one of the 5Rs (a learning dispositions framework) developed by CfL 2 : Readiness, Resourcefulness, Resilience, Responsibility and Reflectiveness (Wall et al. 2010). The progression through the programme was carefully mapped to ensure that the metacognitive elements and the animation process were closely associated and therefore maximised opportunities for transfer. This process was standardised using a number of resources including goal and reflection sheets that allowed the families to record their learning experiences. [¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]" There were two aspects to the intervention. The first involved training teachers in how to embed metacognitive approaches in their work, and how to continue to effectively and strategically involve parents. This training took place over a day and was provided by a consultant. The second component focused on parental engagement and offered families the opportunity to participate in a series of facilitated workshops where children and parents work together to create an animated film.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Mind the Gap seeks to create better learners by harnessing the power of effective metacognition strategies. This is based on the idea that effective learning depends on skills, attitudes and dispositions to learning, and that these can themselves be learned.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"Staff development: All intervention schools were invited to send two teachers to a regional training day led by Jackie Beere, an independent consultant with established expertise in the field of Learning to Learn, working in partnership with CfL. This day’s training focused on how to embed approaches for developing metacognition in their work, and how to develop a strategic approach to effective parental engagement. The training covered why metacognitive development is important, including some of the[¬e]"', 'Page 14:\n[¬s]"theoretical background in this area, as well as a practical consideration of requirements in individual school contexts, enabling teachers to apply their learning to their own work. Teachers were also provided with access to resources and references to use in school.[¬e]"']
int_approach_info: Focus is on teacher training (so teachers can embed metacognitive approaches in their teaching) and parental workshops where children and parents create an animated film. No specification about teaching approach.
int_when_info: Animation sessions took place after school.
int_who_info: Practitioners came in to deliver animation sessions.
int_leng_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]" five sessions (10 hours in total, 2 hours per week[¬e]"']
int_cost_ht: ['Page 37:\n[¬s]" Teacher training The teacher training component of the course was typically £195 per delegate. On a per child basis, this translated to a small additional cost, in the region of £7.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"For schools that already have the required IT hardware, delivery of the animation course for up to 15 families costs in the region of £1,950. This translates into a per child cost of roughly £130. The cost of teacher training was typically an additional £195 per delegate.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"directly explaining the mental acts associated with strategic reading[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" we taught treatment teachers to recast and then model such skills as problem-solving strategies by (a) identifying for students a soon-to-be en\xad countered reading situation where an unknown compound word will be found; (b) teaching stu\xad dents to stop reading when they recognize that the word is not known; (c) showing them how to search their repertoire of strategies for one that can be used to identify the unknown word; and (d) making statements about how to look for recognizable word parts, how to combine men\xad tally the meaning of the two words, and how to think about the combined meaning to see if it makes sense in the text. The latter two steps (searching and reasoning) were the essence of the mental processing explained by treatment teachers.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" the treatme nt group were taught how to make decisions about when and how to explain the mental processing associ\xad ated with using reading skills as strategies[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]"k. The emphasis was not on skills, in the traditional sense of rules and procedures to be memorized and applied in isolated tasks, but rather, on the mental proc\xad esses an expert reader uses when strategically applying basal text skills to remove blockages encountered when reading connected text (Duffy & Roehler, 1987b; Roehler, Duffy, & Meloth, 1986). The curricular emphasis in treatment classrooms, therefore, was on the rea\xad soning associated with strategic skill usage, not on the performance of isolated skill tasks.[¬e]"']
