int_desc_ht:
['Page 108:
[¬s]" Data were collected in the following manner for each group for the three sessions. The first session was a practice session to familiarize the subjects with the research situation, procedures, and the researcher. Based on recommendations of Collins and Smith (1980), the first session consisted of teacher cognitive modeling to a group of twelve, followed by each subject practicing the modeled techniques while reading aloud to another subject, concluding with each subject using the techniques and thinking aloud while reading silently. The second and third sessions consisted of teacher cognitive modeling to groups of two, followed by each subject individually using the modeled strategy and thinking aloud while reading silently, followed by a buffer task, an oral retelling of the passage read, and written comprehension ques t i o n s . [¬e]"', 'Page 109:
[¬s]" Specific Procedures At the beginning of the first session the subjects were told that the purpose of the study was to try out some methods that teachers can use to help their students comprehend better when they read, that it would not be used 93[¬e]"', 'Page 110:
[¬s]"as a test of their individual abilities (Olshavsky, 1976-77; Pritchard, 1987) and that it would not affect their class grade in any way. The session began with a short discussion of thinking silently as opposed to thinking aloud, things that are confusing as one reads, and what a reader can do to fix-up the confusions. The following directions adapted from those used by Bereiter and Bird (1985, p . 145), were typed and given to the subjects to read silently as the researcher read them orally: 1. I will be showing you some ways to read that will help you better understand what you read. I will read some passages out loud, saying my thoughts out loud as I go along. I will say what is confusing for me while I read and what I can do to fix it up. You will follow on your copy. Pay attention to the types of things I think and say while I'm reading. 2. You will then be given a passage to read. You will read it orally with a partner and apply the same think aloud strategy I used when I read for you. As you read, stop frequently and tell your partner when something is confusing and then tell your partner what you will do to fix it up. Wherever you see a red dot on the paper, I want you to stop and tell what you're thinking. You can stopother places, too, but always stop where there's a red dot. 3. After you have finished the reading, fill in the signposts check sheet. 4. You and your partner will tape record each other. These directions were also reviewed at the beginning of the second and third sessions with minor changes given in directions 2 and 3 - namely "read it silently" and, "tell me everything you can remember about what you read" and "answer 94[¬e]"', 'Page 111:
[¬s]"some written question" after haviii3 read the passage. (See Appendix O . ) The cognitive modeling for all three sessions included two aspects of reading comprehension monitoring (problem identification and fix-up strategies) and utilized four of the steps from D a v e y 1s (1983) "Think Aloud" strategy: 1) make a prediction, 2) share an analogy, 3) verbalize confusions, and 4) demonstrate fix-up strategies that could be used to help clear up the confusion. The fix-up strategies followed those identified by Alessi, Anderson and Goetz (1979): 1) store the problem in memory as a pending question; 2) reread the text; 3) read ahead in the text; 4) consult another source. A listing of think-aloud steps and fix-up strategies was typed and available for subjects to refer to. They were also posted in the room on large sheets of construction paper. Davey and Porter (1982) found that posting strategies aided students in monitoring their own comprehension. This listing of the think-aloud steps and fix-up strategies served as "signposts" for subjects to refer to as they proceeded through their own think-alouds. [¬e]"', 'Page 112:
[¬s]"I. PASSIVE COGNITIVE MODELING GROUP Step 1 Cognitive Modeling: The researcher cognitively- modeled a passage for the subjects. This modeling followed the same think-aloud strategy used in session 1 with the same emphasis on problem identification and fix-up strategies. The think-aloud steps and fix-up strategies remained posted throughout the study. Step 2 Verbal Protocol: Next, following a procedure developed by Meichenbaum and Goodman (1971), each subject individually performed the modeled think-aloud strategy to him/herself while silently reading another passage with no help from the researcher. Following the think-aloud the subject received a list of the think-aloud steps and was asked to self-check this "signpost" listing to see if he/she performed the steps in the strategy. Step 3 Comprehension Assessment: Immediately following, the subject was asked to work on a personal interests questionnaire which served as a buffer task. Based on Kintsch's (1974) work on memory, the insertion of an "unrelated buffer passage" between reading and recalling helps to block short term memory and helps assure that propositional memory and not short term memory is being tested. The use of a questionnaire for this purpose has been used in other studies (Mandel and 96[¬e]"', 'Page 113:
[¬s]"Johnson, 1984; Pritchard, 1987) and was therefore used in this study. (See Appendix P.) After several minutes, the subject was instructed to orally retell the passage that he/she just read with the instruction Tell me everything you can remember about the passage you just read. What you might want to do is pretend that I haven't read it and that you're going to tell me everything you can remember about it. After the subject completed the retelling, probes were used following the criteria established by Tierney, Bridge and Cera (1978-79, p. 546). * Questions will use only information already supplied by the subject in the retelling. * Questions will not be stated in a way that they might lead the subject beyond their own understandings. Probes should not "[lead] the readers into insights which were not originally their o w n . " (e.g. Student: "Well, it was about manatees and where they lived, and what they eat, and how they eat." Probe: "Are there any other things it told about the manatees?" Student: "Ya, they eat under water, and they live near Florida in lagoons and stuff like that." Probe: "Is there anything else y o u ’d like to add?" Student: "No.") After completing the probed retelling, the subject was instructed on how to complete the sentence verification assessment and allowed time to do so. (See Appendix K . ) I I . ACTIVE COGNITIVE MODELING GROUP Step 1 Cognitive Modeling: In this group, the cognitive modeling was prefaced with a statement by the researcher to explain the functional value of the 97[¬e]"', 'Page 114:
[¬s]"strategy to be modeled and to foster self-efficacy in the subject. Students who do best in reading do certain things while they read. Those who do best in reading recognize when they don't understand what they are reading and they know what to do to fix-up the problem." [functional value] I've worked with a lot of students like you and I've found that those who do best in reading think that they can understand the meaning of what they read, that they need to work hard, and that they're always getting better at their reading and their thinking. As you begin reading today, you may say to yourself, 'I can do this. I ’m going to try really h a r d . 1 And when you finish, you might think, 'I'm getting pretty good at my reading and my thin k i n g . ' Remember to think that you can read well, that you need to work hard, and that you're getting pretty good in reading and thinking, [self-efficacy] These statements were an adaptation of those used by Shunk, et.al. (1984) in their study of the effects of functional value and self-efficacy on division skills of subjects. The cognitive modeling of the passage then proceeded as it did with the "cognitive modeling only" group. Step 2 - Verbal Protocol and Step 3 - Comprehension Assessment: These steps proceeded the same as for the "passive cognitive modeling" group.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"Conditional logic, the kind considered in this study, is so called because the central ingredient in a conditional argument is one or more condi\xad tional statements. A conditional statement is one of the form, 'If p, then q‘, in which 'p' and 'q' represent statements of varying degrees of complexity.[¬e]"', 'Page 29:
[¬s]"To our knowledge no study of the readiness of primary children to learn conditional logic has ever been done.[¬e]"', 'Page 42:
[¬s]"Our instruction in logic was carried out using fifteen individually administered audio-tutorial programs with science content. The lessons were installed weekly in a three-sided carrel placed on a table in six of the experimental classrooms. The three classes in the urban school used a single carrel located in a learning center. Each lesson consisted of a set of materials for the child to observe and manipulate, and an audio tape recording. The recording guided the observations and manipulations, presented the logic principles, and posed questions for the child to answer by applying the logic to the situation at hand. In each case a situation was developed which illustrated a scientific principle. After the child had become familiar with the situation, the logic content which the lesson was designed to teach was introduced. Usually the child was then asked questions which required him to apply the logic to the specific situation. Following each such question the correct answer was given together with a brief explanation as to why that answer was correct. Each lesson lasted from fifteen to twenty minutes.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]" metacognitive strategies: using questions to enhance metacognition.[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"There were three main parts of metacognitive strategies: using questions to enhance metacognition. Students were expected to answer certain questions before, during, and at the end of each lesson. "
"Students were encouraged to monitor, regulate, and assess their understanding."
" Questions were introduced to students prior to a unit of study or prior to a day's activity in order to guide their learning. The following sentences were to be completed learning diary, and giving feedback after all quizzes and all homework assignments."
"During the lecture first questions were asked to increase awareness. Then questions for translation, integration, planning and monitoring, solution, and self-evaluation followed."
"After working on the mathematical meanings of words came the integration process. In this step students were expected to remember whether they had solved these kinds of questions before. If they had, they were directed to compare this question with the previous ones and discover similarities and differences,"
"n planning and monitoring processes, the aim was to determine the kind of knowledge necessary to solve the problem and make a plan to solve the problem."
" In the solution step students were expected to use their procedural knowledge and solve the problem. In the fifth and final step, students had an opportunity to control their work by self-checking. "
"At the end of the lesson, students were expected to make a summary of the lesson and to evaluate their learning. They were asked to detennine parts of the topic, they found easy or difficult. For the difficult parts, they were directed to find methods to overcome the difficulty."
"Every student was directed to keep a diary.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"These diaries were used for answering questions during homework assignments to reflect upon their thinking. Specific forms of written feedback (Cardelle\xad Elawar, 1992) were used to evaluate students' quizzes and homework assignments. The teacher identified students' mistakes and arranged motivational guidance toward self-correction.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"Language Arts, Science, and Social Studies teachers of the departmentalized fifth and sixth grades participated in two series of workshops in content area reading strategies conducted by two professors of the School of Education at the state university"
"The initial workshops were held in January and February, 1990, with additional sessions the following summer for a total of thirty-six clock hours’ training"
"Workshops were followed by professor-modeling of strategies in the participating teachers’ classrooms, as teachers assumed responsibility for the implementation of the reading/leaming strategies, the professors continued to monitor the project through frequent classroom visits and meetings with the teachers, as well as videotaping of classroom instruction and providing feedback and assistance wherever they were needed."
"Throughout the preparation ror and implementation of this project, particular emphasis was placed on the two factors identified by Duffy, Roehler, and Hermann (1988) as essential to teacher modeling: (a) the transfer of metacognitive control to students, and (b) the modeling of processes rather than procedures. The stages of responsibility model (Pearson, 1985) was chiefly used in this respect Additional emphasis was given to the integration of the new strategies with existing programs. Teachers were shown not only how to[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"incorporate them into textbook lessons, but also how to reorganize their materials and curricula so that transfer of learning could take place between various content areas.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"Stage 5. Collaborative practice. Students and the instructor use the writing strategy and their self-instruc\xad tions collaboratively to complete specific writing tasks."
"Stage 6. Independent performance. Students use the writing strategy independently and their self-instruc\xad tions are covert in their thoughts."
"Finally, in order to promote maintenance and gener\xad alization there are three additional sessions where supportive materials, such as graphic organizers, mnemonic charts of strategies or individual lists of self- instructions were deleted. In the first session, the instructor thought aloud while planning, writing and revising a comparative-contrast text. Later, students worked in pairs, each observing and commenting while the other thought aloud while planning, drafting and revising; the instructor provided additional feedback. Finally, students worked alone, planning, drafting and revising a compare-contrast text with additional feed\xad back from the teacher.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Instructional program based on the self-regulated strategy development model. According to the SRSD model (Graham & Harris, 1987), the instructional pro\xad gram followed the six general stages of training. Stage 1. Develop and activate background knowledge."
"Students’ background knowledge, previous knowledge, and any pre-skills are developed, because they are ess en\xad tial for understanding and executing the next stages. Stage 2. Strategy goals and significance. The instructor and students discuss the writing strategy to be learned[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"Stage 3. Modeling of the strategy. The instructor models the specific strategy by thinking aloud."
"Stage 4. Memorization of the strategy. Students memo\xad rize and automate the steps of the writing strategy and some self-statements of their personal lists of self-regu\xad lation, sometimes by means of mnemonic rules and charts or self-regulatory list.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"we assess the effectiveness of these instructional programs by combining on-line measure\xad ments (writing log measurements) with writing prod\xad uct measurements, aiming not just to determine whether interventions result in improved text but also to explore the nature of this action."
"On the other hand, although the main objective of this study was not strictly to increase writing self-effi\xad cacy perceptions, it is worthwhile to examine the effects of both cognitive and self-regulatory interven\xad tions on this motivational factor.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]" self-efficacy beliefs are expected to be linked reciprocally to students' use of self-regulatory procedures. That is to say, students who learn to use cognitive and self-regulatory strategies in writing increase their perceptions of self-efficacy to write effectively (Zimmerman & Risemberg, 1997). On the other hand, effective self-regulation depends on the extent of self-efficacy for using skills to achieve mastery (Bandura, 1986, 1997); that is, students who feel that their performance is efficient are more likely to use cognitive and self-regulatory strategies and to have increased metacognition, and are more likely to plan, monitor, control, and regulate themselves during a task[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" social cog\xad nitive model of sequential skill acquisition (SCM intervention)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]" According to this model, students can acquire new writing skills optimally in four sequential levels: observation, emulation, self-control, and self-regulation"
"These sequential levels provide the general pattern of instruction that was implemented in the program. At the first level, observation was the focus; the instructor provides a clear image of how a specific skill, in this case a writing process, should be performed. The instructor modeled how to perform the writing process by think\xad ing aloud while doing it.[¬e]"', 'Page 13:
[¬s]"The second level covered emulation. At this level, students learned to emulate a model's performance that had been previously developed. Students worked in pairs, using a cognitive model that incorporated modeled explanations and demonstrations with verbal\xad ization of the model's thoughts and reasons for per\xad forming actions."
"At the third level, which dealt with self-control, stu\xad dents learned from self-directed and individual practice to achieve automation in their behavioral writing process, focusing on the process rather than on its out\xad comes; that is, the quality of written text (Zimmerman & Kitsantas, 2002). At this level, students worked indi\xad vidually using a cognitive model based on the exem\xad plary performances implemented by the instructor and the students themselves in the previous sessions."
"Finally, at the fourth level, which considered self\xad regulation, the students learned to adapt their per\xad formance to changes in contextual environment, either"
"internal or external. Thus, students shifted their atten\xad tion from modeled processes to performance outcomes[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"the SCM model involves more extensive modeling, combining mastery and cop\xad ing, and different models, such as expert (instructor) and novice (peers), which can influence the effects of the intervention on the writing product and process or on modulation variables, such as self-efficacy. Furthermore, the different patterns of instruction can reveal which pattern is more suitable for primary"
"students with LD.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]" on one hand, self-efficacy beliefs are expected to be linked reciprocally to students' use of self-regulatory procedures. That is to say, students who learn to use cognitive and self-regulatory strategies in writing increase their perceptions of self-efficacy to write effectively (Zimmerman & Risemberg, 1997). On the other hand, effective self-regulation depends on the extent of self-efficacy for using skills to achieve mastery (Bandura, 1986, 1997); that is, students who feel that their performance is efficient are more likely to use cognitive and self-regulatory strategies and to have increased metacognition, and are more likely to plan, monitor, control, and regulate themselves during a task"
" For these reasons it is interesting to study the role of writ\xad ing self-efficacy.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" directed-inquiry approach to learning science process skills and scientific problem solving [DIAL(SPS)2]. [¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The first lab of a unit typically took more time because two or three 45-minute periods were generally needed to develop student background knowledge to the point where they possessed the concepts required to understand and perform the activity. Following this preparation, prelab process skills required about two periods. Another period was needed to perform the lab procedure and to collect the data. Postlab activities took one to two periods. When all classroom work was completed, students wrote a lab report that typically included the following parts: purpose, preface (advance organizer), introduction (background information), problem, hypothesis, variable to be tested, variable to be affected, variables to be held constant for a fair test, assumptions, prediction, procedure, data tables and graphs, conclusions, and discussion of results. The discussion included a restatement of the problem, hypothesis, and prediction; arguments concerning how the data proved the conclusion that was drawn; a listing of possible experimental enor; a description of limitations and/or surprising results; a commentary of how knowledge gained in the[¬e]"', 'Page 6:\n[¬s]"lab can explain some phenomena in nature or in daily life; and suggestions for further experimentation.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"This study investigated the effectiveness of a directed-inquiry approach to learning science process skills and scientific problem solving [DIAL(SPS)2]. This approach is founded on the thesis that most students are capable of learning inquiry if background information is carefully developed and students are guided through the process until they are ready to be independent.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 12:
[¬s]"The classroom protocol must be adhered to, but it was up to schools how often they conducted P4C lessons."
"With guidance from the teacher, the dialogue is focused not only on the chosen questions but also on the assumptions that lie behind the answers and the criteria used to make judgements."
"The following are the main ten stages of a P4C session: 1. Getting set 2. Presentation of stimulus 3. Thinking time 4. Question making 5. Question airing 6. Question choosing 7. First thoughts 8. Building 9. Last thoughts 10. Review[¬e]"', 'Page 14:
[¬s]"P4C, as promoted by SAPERE, is a template to practise and organise a classroom session for philosophical enquiry. The intervention suggests useful stages of initiating, practising, and concluding the dialogue with pupils. However, it does not have any specified materials or stimuli that must be used; there are only examples and suggestions. The tens step outlined above are a guide to organising the classroom dialogue and can be used flexibly as the teacher\x92s expertise grows. [¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"determine the effect of the P4C programme on the Key Stage 2 scores of pupils who were in Year 5 when the schools were randomised and Year 6 by the end of the trial. A further outcome was the scores on the CAT4 (Cognitive Ability Test, Fourth Edition; GL Assessment website) for those in Years 4 and 5 at the start and in Years 5 and 6 when post- tested. A subsequent aim proposed by the developers and agreed by the funders was to consider the short-term impact of P4C on pupils\x92 experiences at school, and their relationship with teachers and peers.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"Schools that undertook P4C received two types of training: introductory training for all staff in year 1 and additional days of in-school support as well as access to resources. All the training and support was provided by SAPERE-accredited trainers using standardised SAPERE methods.[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"All staff received two days of training (SAPERE Level 1). Some schools were able to devote two whole days to the training, while others decided to have one day plus an additional day of classroom demonstrations by the trainer together with two after-school sessions. "
"In addition to the introductory training, schools were offered additional support. The first step was for trainers to demonstrate P4C with children in each school. In subsequent sessions, the trainers supported teachers doing P4C by helping them plan lessons and giving them feedback. They also advised teachers who had taken on a leading role for P4C in the school. Nine support days were available to schools over the two years of the project.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Teachers were trained in P4C by the Society for the Advancement of Philosophical Enquiry and Reflection in Education (SAPERE).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 55:
[¬s]"The strategies taught were divided into three major categories: (1) Prereading strategies; (2) during reading strategies; and (3) postreading strategies. The specific prereading strategies included examining the titles and headings, looking at the pictures, skimming the text, thinking about what the story might be about, and activating prior knowledge. Strategies focused upon during reading included identifying the main idea, making inferences, and backtracking. Postreading strategies included self-monitoring such as "Did I meet my goal?", “What did 1 learn?", "Were my predictions accurate?", "Did everything make sense?", and "Can I summarize"
"Intervention for the treatment group also focused on vocabulary development and
reading comprehension. A two-fold approach to instruction was employed. Students
received reading strategy instruction as well as reattribution training for effort.[¬e]"', 'Page 56:
[¬s]"the main points?" (Paris et al., 1991)."
"On the first day of reading an article, the key vocabulary from
the passage was presented to the students. Vocabulary words were printed on the
blackboard with regular phonemes and morphemes, i.e., double vowels, r controls,
digraphs, diphthongs, prefixes, suffixes, etc., marked in coloured chalk. The purpose of
this approach was to draw students’ attention to sound-symbol relationships in order to
improve their word attack/recognition skills. The highlighted phonological sounds were
reviewed with the students before they were asked to pronounce the word. Words were
then said aloud by the students, and the meaning of each word was discussed. Once the
vocabulary from the story had been examined, predictions were made as to what the
article might be about. Students were then taught pre-reading strategies.[¬e]"', 'Page 60:
[¬s]"The second major component of treatment related to attributional training.
Students in the treatment group received specific reattribution training for effort. During
each remedial reading session, students were informed that the effortful use of strategies[¬e]"', 'Page 61:
[¬s]"would help them to better understand and remember what they had read. Also, students
were instructed in the role that effort plays in achievement."
"Because practice is a key element of learning to read (Rosenshine & Stevens,
1986), students were encouraged to read at home on a regular basis. The teacher asked
students to select a book and to choose a goal, in the form of a date, for completing their
book."
"In the months of September, November, January, March, and May, students were[¬e]"', 'Page 62:
[¬s]"tested to determine their reading rate.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"With this approach, students are explicitly and systematically taught strategies for accomplishing speciﬁc writing tasks. Students are also taught any information or skills needed to use these strate- gies. Students further learn how to use self-regulation procedures including as goal setting, self-monitoring, self-instructions, and self-reinforcement to help them man- age the target strategies and task of writing, as well as to obtain concrete and visible evidence of their progress.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Writing is a complex task. Its development depends in large part on changes that occur in children\x01s strategic behavior, knowledge, and motivation. In the present study, the eﬀective- ness of an instructional model, Self-Regulated Strategy Development (SRSD), designed to fos- ter development in each of these areas, was examined.[¬e]"']

It included written metacognitive awareness guidance for each of the three reading assessment tasks. The MCAG was given to students before performing the reading assessment tasks. After answering the metacognitive awareness questions, they were asked to say out loud, \x93Now I know a lot about.... What I know about... will help me to understand the passage. Within each activity, students personalized their learning bycomposing their own questions as the basis for observing, reading, and writing. These questions generated opportunities for self-directed learning. In addition to informational texts, teachers introduced novels, folklore, and poetry related to the unit\'s conceptual theme. The last phase emphasized communicating to others. Having gained expertise in aparticular topic, students were motivated to speak, write, discuss, and display their understanding to other students and adu[¬e]"']

['Page 1:
[¬s]"Central to the rationale for this investigation is the finding that motivation and engagement contribute to reading comprehension.[¬e]"', 'Page 10:
[¬s]" in Study 2, a plan for instructing struggling readers was implemented in CORI classrooms. For[¬e]"', 'Page 11:
[¬s]"30 min daily, students identified by the teacher as substantially lower achieving than others in the class were given instruction focusing on fluency development and simplified SI consistent with the conceptual theme."
"Science activities in CORI were the same as in Study 1, with identical themes and science processes. The aquatic experiments were fine tuned with more explicit charts and guides for student journaling (Barbosa & Alexander, 2004).[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"Within CORI, students\x92 motivation and engagement were explicitly supported through five prac- tices: (a) using content goals for reading instruction, (b) affording choices and control to students, (c) providing hands-on activities, (d) using inter- esting texts for instruction, and (e) organizing collaboration for learning from text. SI was intended to support students\x92 development of self- efficacy for reading comprehension.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"In CORI, explicit SI was provided for the following reading compre- hension strategies: (a) activating background knowledge, (b) questioning, (c) searching for information, (d) summarizing, (e) organizing graphically, and (f) identifying story structure. Each strategy was taught for one week in the order presented previously (6 weeks), and in the next 6 weeks, strategies were systematically integrated with each other."
"There was no explicit support for student motivation stipulated in the SI program, although teachers used a variety of practices to motivate their students to read. In particular, SI teachers usually provided support for students\x92 self-efficacy by enabling them to become confident in using strategies as tools to read better, which can facilitate reading self-efficacy (Bandura, 1997). The sequence of strategies was the same in SI and CORI.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Summer workshops provided professional development for the two instructional models. CORI teachers participated in a 10-day workshop that included viewing examples of instruction, performing the reading strate- gies, discussing motivational practices, constructing reading\x96science inte- grations, identifying books appropriate for this instruction, and planning for the 12-week theme using a teacher\x92s guide supplied by the project. SI teachers participated in a 5-day workshop that included viewing examples of instruction, performing the reading strategies, discussing motivational practices, identifying books appropriate for this instruction, and planning 12 weeks of instruction using a teacher\x92s guide supplied by the project. During the SI workshop, teachers identified books and materials for SI. We provided guidance in how to align texts with specific strategies and how to use available narrative and information texts for instruction in each strategy.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 40:
[¬s]"Training sessions were given at two different sites. Subjects in[¬e]"', 'Page 41:
[¬s]"each training group met with this investigator for a total of eight sessions. Training occurred in a classroom other than the subject's classroom. Each training session lasted for 30 to 45 minutes. Training scripts were developed to insure uniformity of instruction (see Appendix B). On the first training session, subjects were shown an Atari Pac-Man poster. The Pae-Man metaphor was presented as a mnemonic aimed at assisting subjects in remembering the four monitoring rules (see Appendix B, Day 1). Except for the first session, each session introduced a monitoring rule which was first demonstrated by the researcher. Following this modeling process, students practiced the rule while reading a 200-word expository story (see Appendix D). The following day, students again practiced tiie rule using another story. During training, subjects were taught to: 1. Place a question mark on their paper where they needed to ask themselves a question. 2. Underline any word, phrase or sentence that they did not understand. 3. Refer back to text for questions that required multiple pieces of information. 4. Check why the story did or did not make sense as well as supplying a reason for the lack of clarity. At the end of each session, subjects discussed how they had used a particular rule and feedback was given concerning how effectively that rule had been used. In doing this, subjects were given standards by which they should assess their own performance. At the last session, subjects were given a piece of paper which contained the four monitoring rules in a Pac-Man related format (see Appendix B, Day 5). Subjects were told that this paper could be used to help them remember the rules[¬e]"', 'Page 42:
[¬s]"they had been taught.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" `Denktraining fu È r Kinder 1\' (Cognitive training for children).[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The programme consists of 120 tasks (problem plates). Each class of tasks consists of 20 plates. Each plate presents the student with a problem which can be solved by application of inductive reasoning processes (Fig. 2 exhibits examples of problem plates). The tasks are divided across 20 lessons, and six tasks are dealt with in each lesson. There are two lessons per week, and each lesson lasts 45 minutes"
"The steps can be performed by two procedures. The ®rst procedure (see Fig. 3) is characterized by systematic and analytic searching and comparison of attributes or relations."
"Instruction of this inductive reasoning pro-[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"cess is realized by means of a `direct teaching' method (Van Parreren, 1981), known as `guided discovery'"
"Teaching both procedures consists of three phases. The introductory phase uses simple tasks to give students an impression of the tasks and the way to solve them. int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Thinking, Doing, Talking Science (TDTS) comprises a series of professional development sessions, support, and resources for primary school teachers. It aims to improve pupils\x92 thinking skills and science attainment by making science lessons more conceptually challenging, more practical, and more interactiv"\n"two teachers from each school participated in five days of professional development (both were Year 5 teachers or, in one-form entry schools, Year 5 and another member of staff such as the science subject leader). Due to staff changes, in many cases these were not the same teachers that had taken part in the pilot. In the professional development sessions, the teachers were shown how to plan and deliver their own conceptually challenging lessons, tailored to the needs and abilities of their pupils. They also spent two days in-school planning and sharing knowledge to ensure the strategies were embedded.[¬e]"']

"Lessons tend to follow a similar overall pattern. They start with an up-to-date hook to engage students and provide them with concrete examples and materials. Students are then encouraged to think about a series of progressively more challenging problems, working collaboratively with peers to promote exploratory talk and social construction of knowledge. Towards the end of the session the teacher encourages them to reflect on their learning and to broaden their focus from the lesson specifics to other contexts.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]" three-pronged design which includes two holistic strategies, Integrated Skill Development (ISD) and Thinking Across the Curriculum (TAC) in addition to the Supplemental Curriculum (SC)"
" Integrated Skill Development (ISD). ISD encompasses the cognitive competencies of thinking, listening, remembering, speaking, reading and writing."
"The teacher constructs tasks which require students to engage in at least four of the six skills within the context of a single lesson. Second, the teacher ensures that each student engages in each type of skill activity.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"he integrated approach enables the teacher to get a lot of "cognitive mileage" out of a single lesson. Teachers are encouraged to arrange seats in a circle to facilitate discussion and promote the development of nonverbal communication skills."
" Thinking Across the Curriculum (TAC). TAC is based on the premise that learning in each subject area shares many of the same intellectual skills and attitudes."
"The techniques include having students generate alternative solutions to problems and having them use multiple methods of representing information.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Supplemental Curriculum (SC). SC consists of five sections: critical thinking, clarification, logic, listening and argumentation[¬e]"']

ISD and TAC training and im- plementation continue during phase two of the program.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"In this current research study, each student used the following self-regulating questions: a. What is the method for solving the given exercise? b. What are the signs that brought me to choose a particular solution? c. What are the signs that led me NOT to choose a particular solution?[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"the researcher presented the three questions (see page 8) to the students of groups 1 and 3, and they were told how to use these questions while doing their exercises[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"In general, self-regulation refers to the processes that coordinate cognition and reveal the ability to strategically use metacognitive knowledge to achieve cognitive goals, especially in cases in which overcoming cognitive obstacles is necessary (Panaoura, Demetriou, & Gagatsis, 2009, p. 1). Self-Regulating Questions (SRQ) are vital to the learning process: a. SRQ determine how students activate, alter, and sustain their knowledge (Zimmerman & Martinez-Pons, 1986) and are part of a self- directed process through which learners transform their mental abilities into task-related academic skills (Zimmerman, 2001, p. 1); b. Self-regulated students are active participants in their own learning process, taking the initiative to acquire skills and knowledge instead of depending on external sources; c. Students who self-regulate learning are more aware of their mistakes and take steps to correct their deﬁciencies (Zimmerman, 2001, p. 1); d. SRQ are important tools that help to focus the learner\x92s attention on those aspects of knowledge relevant to the process of solving a problem or an exercise (e.g., Schoenfeld, 1987).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"In this current research study, each student used the following self-regulating questions: a. What is the method for solving the given exercise? b. What are the signs that brought me to choose a particular solution? c. What are the signs that led me NOT to choose a particular solution?[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"The research took place over a period of ﬁve months. In each school we summoned the students to the computer lab. There they did exercises (see appendix A) with Virtual Spaces 1.0 (Groups 1 and 2) while the others worked on the same exercises (see appendix A) in booklets (Group 3 or Group 4) in vacant classrooms. Each student in Groups 1 and 2 worked with Virtual Spaces 1.0 (Hauptman, 2010, p. 126) for 15 min a day for 3 weeks. In the ﬁrst week, all students were tested on MRT and APTS\x96E and completed the VARK learning style inventory and the PLSI-Paragon learning style inventory questionnaires. During the next 2 weeks, the researcher met with the participants of Groups 1 and 2 and conducted a short presentation on the new technology (the stereoscopic 5DT HMD and the three-dimensional mouse). The participants then practiced for 5\x9612 min, navigating the H. Hauptman, A. Cohen / Computers & Education 57 (2011) 2106\x962117 2111[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"\x93world of concepts\x94 and using the manipulating tools (Hauptman, 2010, p. 132). Additionally, the researcher presented the three questions (see page 8) to the students of groups 1 and 3, and they were told how to use these questions while doing their exercises. During the next 15 weeks, students in Groups 1 and 2 ﬁnished doing exercises with Virtual Spaces 1.0 at the same time as students in Groups 3 and four ﬁnished their exercises in their booklets. The subjects studied with a teacher who explained the instructions for each exercise and asked the students to solve the exercises. After two lessons, they had ﬁnished all of the exercises.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"In general, self-regulation refers to the processes that coordinate cognition and reveal the ability to strategically use metacognitive knowledge to achieve cognitive goals, especially in cases in which overcoming cognitive obstacles is necessary (Panaoura, Demetriou, & Gagatsis, 2009, p. 1). Self-Regulating Questions (SRQ) are vital to the learning process: a. SRQ determine how students activate, alter, and sustain their knowledge (Zimmerman & Martinez-Pons, 1986) and are part of a self- directed process through which learners transform their mental abilities into task-related academic skills (Zimmerman, 2001, p. 1); b. Self-regulated students are active participants in their own learning process, taking the initiative to acquire skills and knowledge instead of depending on external sources; c. Students who self-regulate learning are more aware of their mistakes and take steps to correct their deﬁciencies (Zimmerman, 2001, p. 1); d. SRQ are important tools that help to focus the learner\x92s attention on those aspects of knowledge relevant to the process of solving a problem or an exercise (e.g., Schoenfeld, 1987).[¬e]"']

int_name_info: There are 2 conditions in this report - both of which are coded. Question-response (QR) and Thinking Aloud (TA)
int_desc_ht: ['Page 183:\n[¬s]"Thinking Aloud In the TA condition, silent reading with monitoring was followed by oral reading with thinking aloud, or "saying out loud what occurs to you in your head while reading the science passage." Students with poor comprehension tend to apply a limited number of strategies (Cote & Goldman, 1999; Kucan & Beck, 2004; Mackin & Lawrence, 2001; Swanson, 1990); therefore, expansion of students\' repertoire of available strategies and their flexible use were critical aspects of the intervention. Instruction embedded into the think-aloud protocol focused on four strategy clusters drawn from the research literature on what good comprehenders do when reading: monitoring (Cote & Goldman, 1999; McMackin & Lawrence; Pressley & Afflerbach, 1995), explaining (Bereiter & Bird, 1985; Cote & Goldman), connecting (Baumann et al., 1992; McMackin & Lawrence), and predicting/questioning (Cote & Goldman; Palincsar & Brown, 1984). RAs determined the level of support (Wood, 2002) needed by the student in order to successfully implement the strategy and comprehend the text.[¬e]"', 'Page 192:\n[¬s]"Question-Response Instruction The second instructional approach, QR followed a more traditional teaching pattern. After silent and oral round robin reading, the RAs initiated questions about the passage, the sixth graders responded, and the RAs evaluated their answers. Complete lessons for the QR condition followed this general framework (see Appendix H) with comprehension assessment taking the form of literal and inferential questions.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Thinking aloud (TA) - Silent reading was followed by oral reading with thinking aloud. RAs instructed students in 4 strategies  monitoring, explaining, connecting, predicting/questioning. (see table 24, p.167). Full explanation of this can be found on pages 166-175. Question-Response Instruction (QR)- after silent and oral round reading, the RAs asked questions and the students responded. The RAs then evaluated their answers. Pages 175-176 for full explanation.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]" In this whole-class instruction the teacher demonstrates strategies for solving mathematical problems. He/ she serves as a leader or expert for his/her students in a cognitive appren- ticeship model. The methods used involved exploration, coaching, articu-[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"lation, and reflection."
"For example, the teacher reads the assignment aloud, and asks students how the problem could be represented. He/she stresses the importance of the first steps in the problem-solving process. The process of creating a mental representation of the problem situation is completed by the con- struction of a schema, diagram, graph, or drawing. In the next step a plan is made in order to solve the problem."
"Subsequently the teacher asks what steps can be taken, which proce- dures are adequate, and whether a heuristic can be used. During and after the execution of the plan, the teacher asks whether the participants are still on the right track. Finally, teacher and students look back, reflect on the process, and check the answer"
"Students subsequently start working in small co-operative heterogene- ous groups of students on course materials with mathematical problems; and for the experimental groups special assignments in strategic learning. In this stage, the teacher has the opportunity to observe interaction proc- esses. Where necessary, the teacher intervenes in the interaction process in order to assist students in putting the cognitive strategies into practice (practice and feedback). After the work in small heterogeneous groups and after a diagnostic test the outcomes are discussed in a whole class session. The students then work individually in small homogeneous groups of 4 students (temporary 'within class setting', i.e., low-, medium-, and high- achieving groups). The group of low-achievers works as a remedial group under the direct guidance and supervision of the teacher. Meanwhile the medium-, and high-achieving students work on enrichment tasks at the appropriate level. In the next stage all students work individually in the context of their own level group, with the opportunity of helping each other. Here too if needed, the low-achievers receive adapted guidance from their teacher. At the end of the session the teacher winds the teaching learning cycle down with a recapitulation of the most important concepts, procedures and strategies. Finally, the post-test is administered, after which teacher and students look back on the whole cycle and reflect on the process and the results of learning.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"From a cognitive perspective, theorists state that low-achieving stu- dents benefit less from group work since they lack prior knowledge (de- clarative, procedural, strategic, metacognitive, and situational). Differ- ences in access to resources are primarily seen in terms of knowledge and strategies. Low-achieving students are not always able to use knowledge and problem-solving strategies (at the right moment). As a consequence of deficiencies in strategic and metacognitive knowledge, low-achievers are not always able to cope with the strategies used by high-achievers. On their part, high-achievers are not always able to explain their routinely used strategies. From the cognitive perspective the promotion of learning in co-operative groups can be realised by improvement of their strategies and metacognitive awareness. This can be done by training students in the use of (meta-) cognitive strategies, for example problem solving strate- gies and control strategies such as planning, monitoring, checking, and revising[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"From these theoretical and empirical analyses, ideas emerged for an investigation into the effects of training in social and cognitive strategies. The training should provide more students with access to resources, al- lowing them to participate effectively in co-operative problem solving. An intervention study was developed in which two different experimental programs and a control program were implemented. In the experimental programs students were trained either in the use of social strategies for small-group participation or in the use of cognitive strategies for solving mathematical problems.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The cycle begins with whole-class instruction. The aim of this intro- duction is to motivate students by situating the mathematical content in their daily-life contexts; to allow them to review the necessary pre-knowl- edge; to give an overview of the learning unit; and to introduce the most important concepts and procedures.[¬e]"']

int_objec_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]" Both the intervention lessons and the follow-up reßections aimed to enact a basic learn- ing principle (Glaser, 1994)Ñto make learnersÕ thinking processes, in this case their collabora- tive thinking, apparent and overt so that they could be examined, questioned, and shaped as an object of learning.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]" These lessons aimed to help students (a) understand what collaborative scientiÞc reasoning is and why it is desirable; (b) understand that collaborative reasoning requires conscious, constructive cog- nitive activity; (c) believe that constructing new knowledge often is hard for everyone and that knowledge is rarely absolute; (d) desire to become proÞcient at collaborative reasoning; and (e) see that collaborative reasoning can lead to payoffs that make their efforts worthwhile."
"The aim of fostering metacognitive regulation of scientiÞc reasoning was to help groups regulate their work just as self-regulating individuals doÑby planning and selecting approaches for accom- plishing tasks, persisting to accomplish goals, monitoring their thinking processes, and reßect- ing on and evaluating their completed work (Brown, 1987; Zimmerman, 1994).[¬e]"']

[¬s]"Teachers in the SOLVED group observed a sample SOLVED lesson; we taught them to present the lesson fol- lowing a six-step procedure: 1. Distribute a copy of the SOLVED check list to accompa- ny the lesson. 2. Demonstrate how SOLVED could be applied to a sample problem."
"3. Wherever possible, simplify terms to explain the applica- tion of each of the six steps in SOLVED."
"4. Provide two similar problems for individual practice. 5. After practice, pair students with a partner to discuss how they applied the mnemonic and what solution was derived. 6. Kequire each pair to explain how they used SOLVED in one of the problems.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"On the basis of the foregoing analysis of the metacogni- tive phases of mathematical problem solving, we created a training program for this study as an attempt to help ele- mentary mathematics students remember and engage in these processes. "\n"The training program is entitled SOLVED, which stands for State the problem, Options to use, Links to the past, Visual aid, Execute your answer, and Do check back. Each letter cues a concept or procedure that, if followed, would help the learner to consider the necessary phases of problem solving.[¬e]"']

This is metacognitive information about the strategy. The strategy serves, in other words, as a stepping-stone for the structuring of information that will be dealt with in the lesson."

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]" The procedures for condition four were identical to those in condition three with the addition of a monitoring accuracy training component. This training consisted of an additional element to foe foink-aloud and additional discussion at foe end of each session. As part of foe foink-aloud and discussion components of each lesson, students in this condition discussed the following questions: 1. Why is it important to think about how confident, or sure, you are about your answers to foe comprehension questions? 2. How can a confidence judgment help you monitor your comprehension?[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]"Following independent practice and the dissemination of correct answers students were encouraged to compare their confidence judgments with their actual performance. Specifically students were asked to reflect on the following questions: 1. What does your confidence rating suggest about your comprehension of the text? 2. Compare your confidence rating with your actual performance. Were you under\xad confident? Overconfident? 3. How can drinking about your confidence level help you improve your reading comprehension? Discussion ensued in response to these questions. Points were made regarding the implications of being either under or over confident, and the discussion was wrapped up by emphasizing the importance of using confidence judgments as tools for monitoring comprehension. Students were encouraged to try and improve the accuracy of their confidence judgments on subsequent practice passages.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The students in the explicit classes were taught how to solve physics problems using the explicit problem-solving strategy described by Heller et al. (1992). The method includes a de- tailed Þve-step procedure to solve real-world, context-rich physics problems rather than simple textbook physics problems."
" The Þve steps of the strategy are: (a) focus the problem; (b) describe the physics; (c) plan the solution; (d) execute the plan; and (e) evaluate the solution."
" The third step is to plan the solution. In this step, the physics description is translated into speciÞc math- ematical equations which are used to solve the problem. This step includes three parts: con- structing speciÞc equations, checking for sufÞciency, and outlining the math solution. The con- struction of speciÞc equations always begins with an equation containing the target variable, and involves the successive combination of equations in which unknown variables are related to known variables."
"The check for sufÞciency involves a comparison of the number of equations to the number of unknowns. A mathematical solution is possible when one has as many equations as unknowns. Finally, the math solution is outlined to provide a bridge to the actually mathematical execution. [¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]" The fourth step is to execute the plan. In this step, the equations are combined algebraically according to the plan, to produce an equation with a single unknown target variable. The units of each term in this equation are checked to make sure they are correct, and are converted if necessary. Final- ly, the known quantities are inserted into the equation to calculate the value of the target vari-[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"able. The Þnal step is to evaluate the solution. In this step, the solution is checked to ensure that it is properly stated, reasonable, and complete.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"One instructional method that has been used to address both problem-solving performance and conceptual understanding is explicit problem-solving instruction. Explicit problem solving is instruction that directly teaches students how to use more advanced techniques for solving problems. "
"Textbook problem solving also tends to emphasize primarily the quantita- tive aspects of problem solving, while explicit problem solving tends to emphasize both the qualitative and quantitative aspects of problem solving. This emphasis on the qualitative aspects of problem solving may help students not only to improve their problem-solving performance, but also to better understand the concepts and principles of physics. [¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Although on the surface the explicit strategy appears to be quite similar to the textbook strategy, the explicit strategy provides a much more detailed series of instructions for students to follow, including bridging steps that help students move from one step to the next. The ex- plicit strategy can be viewed as a systematic series of translations, in which each step requires the student to translate the problem into increasingly more abstract and mathematical represen- tations of the problem."
"Context-rich problems were used because the complexity of the problem played an im- portant role in promoting the use of the strategy. "
"when students were faced with context-rich problems, their novice prob- lem-solving techniques were not sufÞcient to solve the problem, and hence the students had a need to learn more expertlike techniques (Heller & Hollabaugh, 1992). For these reasons, the students in the explicit group solved context-rich problems rather than the one- or two-step prob- lems found in most physics textbooks.[¬e]"']
int_approach_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]" Throughout the problem-solving phase, students practiced solving problems using their respective strategies in weekly group problem-solving sessions using cooperative learning[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Students need to be introduced to the activity (concrete preparation) in such a way that they collaborate together in small groups of two to four or more, to construct as much of solutions to the task in hand in a given time, so that when the word is given they have something worth presenting to the rest of the class. Orchestrating or chairing this whole-class discussion so that six or seven working groups listen (and cross-question) each otherÑwhile the teachers try to get out of the way themselvesÑis the principal class-management skill the teachers have to de- velop. In 20 min collaboration so many interesting things are dealt with by different students in different groupsÑbut for each student to have a chance to beneÞt he needs to witness the suc- cessful performance of just that one person who is just beyond him. If that person was in an- other group, then bad luckÑunless the key episodes of each group are made available to the[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"whole class. Metacognition occurs when students are asked to reßect collaboratively on what the class has achieved, and are encouraged to Þnd good names for the ideas or strategies de- veloped, to aid subsequent retrieval from long-term memory."
"Finally, from Feuerstein (1980) is drawn the idea of BridgingÑtaking a strategy or a tech- nical term or concept from the context where it is learned, and applying it to a different but rel- evant one. "
"As teachers learn to see the cognitive content of their normal sci- ence lessons in Piagetian terms, they transfer the class-management skills speciÞc to Thinking Science (TS) lessons to the rest of their science teaching.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" This article reports the result of using, in the context of Pakistan secondary education, an intervention program which earlier was shown in British schools to have a substantial effect over a 2-year period on the cognitive development of pupils, and subsequently to have long-term effects on studentsÕ school achievement. This study is not merely a replication; the attempt, in the context of a developing country, has cultural implications which also need discussion."\n"Since the science curriculum could not be taught with understanding on the part of the students, it had to be taught by rote. Might it be possible to improve this state of affairs by conducting an intervention which would improve the match between curriculum demands and studentsÕ ability?[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Initially, a rather ambitious program of inservice training was planned. All teachers attend- ed 2 days of intensive training at the University of the Punjab, in which the theory of the CASE intervention and also the speciÞcs of class management for the earlier TS lessons were pre- sented. The TS lessons would then be delivered to students of the University of Punjab campus school by the researcher (Iqbal) at a frequency of one every 2 weeks, and would be witnessed by all the project teachersÑwho were encouraged to join in the lessons with the students when[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"small-group work was going on. The teachers would then teach the lessons in their own school in light of that experience. This schedule was followed for 8 of the 30 TS lessons, but then had to be dropped because it was making too great a demand on the three schools in terms of time the teachers were spend- ing away from their school (and classes). For the rest of the Þrst year teachers came to after- school training sessions, in which three to four TS activities would be discussed in detail, fol- lowing which the lessons were delivered by the teachers in their own schools. At the end of the year, Shayer visited the schools and observed some TS lessons, and a further training day was arranged in which Shayer and Iqbal gave the teachers further feedback on the development of the CASE methodology, with particular emphasis on the development of the skill of bridging. The teachers remained with their classes for the 2 years of the intervention. Even this schedule had to be abandoned in the second year of the research. Instead, Iqbal undertook to provide guidelines to the participating teachers at their workplace on a one-to-one basis. Regular visits were paid to participating schools at the time when these lessons were de- livered. On-the-spot guidance was provided to help teachers deliver TS lessons in accordance with the underlying CASE philosophy and methodology.[¬e]"']
int_freq_info: Not specified. As CASE was implemented in regular science lessons it can be estimated that students received the intervention at a minimum of once or twice per week.

Additionally – adhering to the implications mentioned above – metacognitive hints are added to the cognitive content of the word problems."
"In this procedure, a picture of a staircase is oﬀered with the steps ‘‘I read carefully’’ (orientation), ‘‘I make a plan’’ (planning), ‘‘I check my answer’’ (evaluation), and ‘‘What did I learn?’’ (reﬂection). These steps have been used previously to teach metacognitive skills in classroom instruction in primary education.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"In the program interface, the problem and the steps of the staircase are presented at the same time, and after reading the problem a student can decide to choose one of the steps for support. The support is thus provided during and after processing a word problem.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" Half ofthe time was devoted to IE using the following instruments: Organi\xad zation of dots; Comparison, Orientation in the Space (I & III); Categorization and Analytic Perception. The other half of the time was devoted to various topics which were not learned in school (computers, art, etc.). On each day of study there were four lessons: two from IE and two from other topics. All the lessons of the same day were bridged (integrated) with metacognitive principles according to Brown’s model. The main objectives of the bridging were: systematic thinking for problem-solving; enrichment of vocabulary, concepts and increase of verbalization; regulation of tempo of work; awareness of the cognitive processes and monitoring them. For more detailed description ofthe program see Kaniel and Reichenberg, (1990). At the end of the program (two years) the above tasks were administered to both control and experimental groups.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"It is argued that by combining IE with Brown’s model of metacognition the potential of efficient bridging will increase. Such bridging will ensure generalization from IE tasks to verbal thinking tasks and school achievements which are far from the IE tasks. Well built bridging lessons will help the learner to internalize the strategies and to continue and work correctly in the absence of a mediator (Vygotsky, 1978; Brown and Campione, 1982).[¬e]"', 'Page 3:\n[¬s]" The main objectives of the bridging were: systematic thinking for problem-solving; enrichment of vocabulary, concepts and increase of verbalization; regulation of tempo of work; awareness of the cognitive processes and monitoring them. [¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]" metacognitive support during the process and at its end[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"StudentsÕ procedure Supplying metacognitive support is activated in the intervention program as follows: At the phase of problem identiÞcation, the solver is given a directive by the question: ÒWhat are you asked to Þnd?Ó ÒWhat is given in the problem?Ó Thus the student starts the data coding process. At the phase of problem representation the problem solver is given a directive by the question: ÒIn what way is this problem similar to the example?Ó This phase starts a process of analogy and selective comparing. At the phase of solution plan the student is presented a directive by use of the question: ÒWhat is the strategy?Ó The students have the following possible reactions: to solve in their own way, to use a solved example or to use the problem mapping (see below). At this phase the studentÕs integration ability, pattern matching and conceptualization is expressed. At the phase of solution performance the student is directed to write the full solution in Ôthe draft pageÕ (see Ap- pendix A) and to include a verbal answer at the end of the solution. During the solution the student can click the buttons labeled Ôproblem mappingÕ and Ôsolved exampleÕ in order to be assisted by these cognitive strategies."
" At the phase of performance evaluation the student is directed by the question: ÒIs the solution suitable for the problemÕs conditions?Ó At this phase the student can still check his/her solution and change it, if necessary, before pressing the Enter key."
"At the end of the solution (after pressing the Enter key) the student is given a reaction of some encouragement with an appropriate animation from the reactionÕs list of responses. A correct answer is followed by a question directed toward additional thinking: ÒIs there any other way to solve the problem you have already solved? If so, what is it?Ó This kind of feedback is deÞned as directing feedback. A wrong answer is followed by the question: ÒWhy is your answer wrong? Where is the mistake?Ó This kind of feedback is deÞned as correcting feedback. The computer sug- gests a list of possible errors as answers to the questions of the correcting feedback. The student speciÞes the numbers of the relevant error types. A wrong answer can be corrected.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Group A Ð Giving metacognitive support during the process and at its end In this treatment group, cognitive and metacognitive support was given during the process in each of its different phases, as well as at the com- pletion of the process, using guiding feedback directed towards additional activity (in case of a correct answer) and correcting feedback (in case of a wrong answer).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The computerized intervention program was developed in light of a generic purpose to enhance the acquiring of cognitive and metacognitive strategies for word-problem solving among students with a reported lack of such skills (e.g., Schoenfeld, 1990)."
"The generic purpose is elaborated to speciÞc aims. First, teaching a strategy for the activation of monitoring and control meta- processes in each phase of the problem solving through the metacognitive directing questions during the solution process."
"Second, intensifying self-feedback, according to the directing and cor- recting feedback, that were formulated and developed in this research, due to the fact that an outcome feedback is not effective enough for learning"
"Third, empowering the awareness of the importance of previous knowledge through pointing out the differences and similarities between a current problem and a former one or to the solved example"
"Finally, imparting a strategy while analyzing a word-mathematics text, since students have difÞculties in the word-problem comprehension phase and a lack of linguistic strategies [¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" multiple strategy instruction with metacognitive information[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"In addition to strategic instruction, students in the explicit training condition with metacognitive information also participated in teacher-led discussions about spelling. Specifically, students talked about the importance of good spelling as it related to educational attainment, literacy, and their everyday lives. These students also dis- cussed the importance of spelling strategies and were provided with \x91when\x92, \x91where\x92, and \x91how\x92 information about each of the instructional strategies. Briefly, students were told that they should use their spelling strategies whenever they needed to spell an unfamiliar word, regardless of whether they were inside or outside the classroom. They were also instructed to use the strategies alone or in combination. For example, they were told to use the analogy strategy if they knew the spelling of a word that rhymed with the unknown one. Imagery was explained to be an effective strategy for recalling the spelling of a known word and one that would help prevent them from forgetting a new spelling, with students encouraged to use imagery after using either analogy of phonology. Phonology was explained to be an effective strategy when students could identify some of the letter patterns in an unknown word. Students were also encouraged to use phonology as a second step when spelling by analogy (i.e. use phonology to spell the remaining portion of a word not accounted for by the rhyming principle). This information was reiterated by the instructor when she modelled each strategy. The provision of this information did not require additional study time, but was carried out while the other students practised using spelling strategies or completing language arts activities.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" Because a repertoire of effective spelling strategies was taught in this study, it was anticipated that providing first-grade students with explicit instruction about multiple strategies, which included metacognitive information about when and where to use each strategy, would improve spelling relative to providing strategy instruction or traditional language arts activities[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Table 1."\n"Pretest[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" a computer-supported problem-based learning environment, Animal Investi- gator.[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"At the beginning of the class, the prior domain knowledge and background surveys were administered by teachers. At the beginning of the ﬁrst class activity, one researcher presented oral instruction to the students on how to use Animal Investigator (see Fig. 1), how to write their hypotheses in the response form, and how to save the response ﬁle to a shared directory on the network. Then, students performed the in-class activities to complete the hypothesis-development performance in Animal Investigator. Additionally, participants in the experi- mental group were instructed on the use of the three metacognitive scaffolds. After identifying the problem and reviewing the initial information regarding the oil spill, students started to look for clues from the information provided about the rescued animal and the animal shelters in the hypothesis-development stage. Next, students developed hypotheses and explored clues to evaluate and justify their hypotheses about solving a given problem, and then they ﬁlled out a response form (see Appendix B). Finally, students conducted their problem-solving activities with a different animal with no oral instruction. Student activities in Animal Investigator were directed by a virtual agent, a character who facilitated the problem-solving process.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Thus, the purpose of this study was to investigate whether the presence of metacognitive scaffolds in the hypothesis-development phase of ill-structured problem solving helps early adolescents\x92 performance on developing hypotheses, and to examine the effects of that performance on students\x92 solution-development performance.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" a total of ten sessions during 2 weeks[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"Each session occurred during a 50- to 55-min computer class. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Texts and assessments. A variety of non-fiction texts, ranging from maga- zine articles to books, were used in the study. The topics addressed included: baby animals, hurricanes, volcanoes, the Earth\'s crust, the solar system, aster- oids and meteorites. Six times throughout the school year, students were given researcher-designed assessments on specific non-fiction texts. Questions on these assessments were designed using the Question Answer Relationship (QAR) categorization (Raphael, 1986). In addition, scores from the science por- tion of the state-mandated Michigan Educational Assessment Program (MEAP) test, which was given in March, were also collected."\n"Classroom instruction and observation. For the first month of school, teach- ers were encouraged to use RT every time they taught science. Afterward, teach- ers used RT as much as possible and kept a record of how many RT lessons they had taught. Once a month throughout the study, classroom observations were conducted. Observations were either video taped or recorded verbatim using a laptop computer. For consistency, classrooms across schools were observed working with the same piece of non-fiction text.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"The purpose of this research was to examine reciprocal teaching in typical classrooms where teachers had previous exposure to constructivist thinking. We wanted to determine if RT would provide fifth graders with a strategy to help them build understanding of non-fiction science text.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"On average, each CPD session included approximately 30 teachers and were led by two trainers. Sessions were highly interactive and practical in nature, requiring equipment to be set out and cleared away throughout the day. Two trainers were used to maximise interactions with the teachers, to help enable all teachers to participate in the practical investigations, and to minimise time lost due to logistical transitions between sections of the session. In addition, the intervention team requested that at least two teachers from each school participate in the CPD sessions to facilitate ongoing collaboration and mutual support. "
"In the CPD sessions, teachers were provided with a folder of reference materials to use when they returned to their classrooms and to assist with lesson planning. These materials included an agenda, the background to the strategies, exemplar teaching materials for each strategy, slides that could be used in the classroom, and instructions for all the investigations and problem-solving activities. All materials in the folder were available online through the programme’s secure web portal.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Thinking, Doing, Talking Science (TDTS) is a teacher training intervention aimed at improving Year 5 science outcomes by making science lessons more effective. Teachers are trained to develop and teach challenging, enquiry-based science lessons that incorporate more practical activities, deeper thinking and discussion, and sharply focused recording.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]"When implemented at scale, what is the impact of the Thinking, Doing, Talking Science (TDTS) programme on the (a) science knowledge attainment and (b) attitudes toward science of participating pupils at the end of the school year? This research question focused on two broad outcomes: pupil science knowledge attainment and attitudes toward science. TDTS is intended to help teachers create more engaging lessons that would result in increased pupil interest in, and self-efficacy toward, science. In addition, TDTS is focused on boosting science learning and enquiry skills. Hence, the ultimate outcome would be a meaningful increase in pupils’ knowledge of science.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"To prepare the trainers for the delivery of the TDTS programme, the Oxford team worked with the trainers during four two-day, face-to-face sessions (eight days total for each trainer). These sessions were staggered throughout the year and preceded each teacher CPD session. They began in April prior to the intervention year, and subsequent sessions were timed to occur just prior to the delivery of TDTS CPD to teachers. The first train-the-trainers session included a briefing on the evaluation and details on the process for the trainers to recruit schools from their home regions into the study. In each train-the-trainer session, the Oxford team modelled the delivery of the upcoming CPD session, including engagement of the trainers in the science investigations and activities in the manner that they were to be used with teachers. Trainers were provided with, and trained on, materials for the upcoming CPD session: an agenda, presentation slides, trainer notes, and science investigation materials and instructions. The sessions were highly interactive, and the Oxford team leveraged the experience and knowledge of the trainers by soliciting feedback and applying that feedback in subsequent days of training. For example, the trainers encouraged the Oxford team to make explicit how each practical that was shared with the teachers linked to the key programme elements (illustrated in Figure 1). Discussions with the trainers also included thoughts on what to prioritise from the content of the latest national curriculum and how to infuse that content into the design of the CPD days. The intervention ethos and strategies remained the same, but the Oxford team updated the materials to be used with teachers based on feedback from the trainers.[¬e]"']

"The non-financial costs included four days of teacher supply time and laptops for trainers to use in the CPD sessions. Because sessions are a full day in term, and co-ordinated across schools that may have different schedules, supply cover was necessary for teacher attendance as opposed to sessions outside teaching hours or during school inset days. [¬e]"', 'Page 6:

The non-financial costs included four days of teacher supply time per teacher and laptops for trainers to use in the CPD sessions.[¬e]"']
