[¬s]"At the pupil level, several statistically significant differences occurred between the treatment and control groups (Table 7). First, pupils in the treatment schools were more likely to be ever FSM eligible (27.4%)[¬e]"', 'Page 26:
[¬s]"than pupils in the control schools (24.7%).9 Second, pupils in the treatment schools had slightly lower KS1 test scores.10 For example, the percent of pupils in treatment schools scoring 2A and above was 52.2% in mathematics and 55.2% in reading and writing compared with 54.6% in mathematics and 57.8% in reading and writing among pupils in control schools. The effect sizes of the differences at this cut-point (scoring 2A and above)—, 2.4 percentage points in mathematics and 2.5 in reading and writing—, are both approximately 0.06 using Cox’s Index (U.S. Department of Education, 2014). Finally, pupil IDACI also was lower in the treatment schools (46.9% in the low category) than in the control schools (40.3% in the low category).11 The additional analyses of outcome measures included these variables as covariates in the model."

int_desc_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]"All of these tasks can be solved in a very similar way by looking for the relationship between corresponding pairs. The tasks provide enough information for inducing the relationship. Therefore, it seems justified to assume strong transfer of training from one task to the other. This is obviously not the case, at least not under normal conditions. Children \x97 and even adults - do not spontaneously recognize the same basic structure underlying these different kinds of tasks. This is particularly true if the tasks use elements from different content domains as, for instance, flowers or human beings or animals or prices or geometrical figures or numbers, etc. A training program has to take these problems into account. Consequently it is necessary \x97 to teach the basic structure, the paradigm, in such a way that children can understand it; - to teach how such a structure is to be solved; - to teach recognizing the basic structure under different conditions, in various disguises; \x97 to teach how the solving procedure can be adapted to different content domains. This is done for every one of the paradigms dealt with when teaching for inductive thinking. The different paradigms which are to be taught make it necessary to look for an adequate allotment of space to the different paradigms and an adequate number and distribution of repetitions within each of the paradigms. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"The training was based on the program published by Klauer and Phye (1994). Basic cogni- tive and metacognitive objectives of the program are to teach the children to recognize an inductive problem, to differentiate between the types of problems (not necessarily by labeling them), to apply the adequate solution procedure to the type of problem, and ®nally to check one\'s own solution. Particular emphasis was put on teaching for transfer such that the children should become able to apply the cognitive and metacognitive strategies on any inductive prob- lem whenever they met one. The project started at the beginning of the second half of the school year. In all schools, one class received training and the other class continued with regular classroom activities. The training lasted 5 weeks. In each of the weeks, every child participated in 2 training sessions of maximally 45 min so that 10 training lessons were administered to each child. The training sessions took place in small groups of about three to ®ve children. It was administered in a separate room so that the children had to leave their classroom in order to participate in the training.[¬e]"']

Particular emphasis was put on teaching for transfer such that the children should become able to apply the cognitive and metacognitive strategies on any inductive prob- lem whenever they met one.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]"Program Inductive Reasoning 1[¬e]"', 'Page 13:\n[¬s]" Program Inductive Reasoning in Reading Comprehension[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"The Program Inductive Reasoning 1 consists of visual material: building blocks and large pictures that can be attached to the blackboard. The program comprises 20 lessons, each containing six tasks. In the ®rst 4 lessons only generalization tasks (similarity of attributes) and seriation tasks (similarity of relationships) were discussed. From lesson ®ve onward discrimination[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"tasks (dissimilarity of attributes), disturbed seriation tasks (dissimilarity of relationships), cross-classi®cation (similarity and dissimilarity of attributes), and system formation tasks (similarity and dissimilarity of relationships) were gradually introduced. First similar kinds of tasks were clustered to- gether and then, in the last 2 lessons, each of the six kinds of tasks had to be solved.[¬e]"', 'Page 13:
[¬s]"The Program Inductive Reasoning in Reading Comprehension comprised 16 lessons and consisted of tasks composed of texts. The problem solving procedure was divided into a reading part and a thinking part (De Koning & Hamers, 1999). "
"In the introductory phase, the four task types were operationalized in sepa- rate texts. The group structure tasks (similarity and dissimilarity of attributes) and the row structure tasks (similarity and dissimilarity of relationships) were combined in the practice and re¯ection phase. Finally, in the reciprocal teach- ing phase, the four task types were combined into one long text. After solving the tasks pupils had to compose an appropriate title for the text. The texts changed from everyday content to one that was more abstract and unknown. The texts in the ®rst half of the program involved situation sketches, which linked up to the pupils' knowledge representations. The second half of the program dealt with expository texts. It was assumed that many pupils had insuf®cient knowledge of all the words in the text and of the theme of the text. By analogy with the build-up of the visual program, the relevant attri- butes and relationships that had to be discovered were thus hidden to a higher degree as the lessons progressed.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"This study deals with smoothing the transition from developmentally oriented education in the preparatory phase to curriculum-oriented education from the third grade onward. The emphasis on inductive reasoning that already exists in the prepa- ratory phase was extended to the third and the fourth grades by implementing two classroom-teaching programs. Theories on inductive reasoning provided the founda- tion for the operationalization of the tasks that were used and the reasoning processes that were taught. The tasks and processes were embedded in a three-phase procedure for teaching, which was based on the development of metacognitive knowledge. The materials chosen for teaching inductive reasoning were adapted to the develop- mental level and educational needs of the pupils: in Grade 3, visual material (build- ing blocks and pictures) was used, and in Grade 4 verbal material (texts) was used.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 16:\n[¬s]"The teachers were provided with two kinds of information. First, the objec- tives underlying the three-phase teaching method were described in general, rather than abstract, terms. Second, the teachers received a manual with de- tailed examples of the typical tasks and dialogs to be used preferably in each separate phase. In a few sessions teachers were supported to connect the two kinds of information.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" cooperative learning embedded within multilevel metacog\xad nitive training (MMT)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"MMT group: In this condition, the teacher implemented the IMPROVE method (Mevarech & Kramarski, 1997) in"
"both mathematics and English (as a foreign language) class\xad es. A discussion was held in the mathematics class on the similarities and differences in learning a foreign language (English) and a mathematical language (Pimm, 1987, 1996) . The teacher presented the studying stages of IMPROVE and held a discussion on the importance of using metacognitive questions in both mathematics and English classrooms. In addition, students discussed the common factors of mathematics language and English, including the importance of understanding vocabulary and symbols, using appropriate strategies to read a text or solve a problem, and reflecting on the text or the solution."
"Each session (in mathematics and English classrooms) began with the teacher’s short presentation of the new mate\xad rials to the whole class using metacognitive self-addressed questioning techniques according to comprehension, con\xad nection, and strategy questions (Mevarech & Kramarski. 1997) . For example, students used the following metacog\xad nitive questions in mathematics lessons: What is the prob- lem/task all about? How is this problem/task different from what you have already solved? Which strategy/principle is appropriate for solving/addressing the problem/task? The students used similar questions in English lessons: What am I supposed to do in this task? What do I already know about the story/task? What are the differences/similarities between the texts? Which strategy is appropriate for under\xad standing the text? Following the introduction, students started to work in small groups using the materials that we designed. Students studied in heterogeneous groups comprised of 4 members: 1 high-achieving student. 2 average-achieving students, and 1 low-achieving student. The students studied in groups as follows: each student, by turn, read a problem/text aloud and tried to solve or analyze it. Whenever there was no con\xad sensus, the group discussed the issue until the disagreement was resolved. Students were encouraged to talk about the problem/text, explain it to each other, and approach it from different perspectives. Students used the metacognitive questions during their discourse in small-group activities and in their written explanations when they solved the mathematical problems or addressed the texts in the English class. Periodically, the teachers bridged the metacognitive processes that were activated in the mathematics and Eng\xad lish classrooms.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" we hypothesized that providing metacognitive training in both mathematics and English classrooms (MMT) would exert more positive effects on students’ achievement than would implementing metacognitive training in only mathematics or English classrooms (UMT), not only because the provision of a “double portion" of metacognitive training is assumed to be more effective than “one portion" but also[¬e]"', 'Page 2:\n[¬s]"because of the possibility that students who are exposed to MMT may be able to generalize the use of metacognitive processes beyond a specific domain. Thus, the effects of MMT are expected to be observed on mathematical reasoning, the activation of metacognitive processes, and the solution of a transfer task that focuses on authentic, real-life problems.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"Prior to the beginning of this study, the six teachers par\xad ticipated in a 1-day in-service training session that focused on pedagogical issues related to teaching problem solving. We told the teachers that they would be part of an experi\xad ment in which new materials were being tested. They worked w ith the ne w material s and learned how to use them with their students. The materials included explicit lesson plans, problems, and use of examples.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Within each school, teachers conducted classes accord\xad ing to their assigned teaching methods for the entire school year. In the present study, we focused on the problem-solv\xad ing unit that was taught in all classrooms for about a month in the last semester.[¬e]"']
int_freq_info: Unclear. Implemented in both maths and English language classes, however it is not stated how often these lessons took place.

int_name_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]" cooperative learning embedded within metacognitive instruction (COOP+META) [¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"The COOP+META condition: We used the IMPROVE method (Mevarech and Kramarski, 1997; Mevarech, 1999; Kramarski, Liberman, and Meva- rech, 2001) to train students to activate metacognitive processes in small groups. Students were taught to formulate and answer four kinds of self- addressed metacognitive questions: comprehension, connection, strategic, and reßection questions.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"The studying in the small groups was implemented as follows: each student, in his/her turn, read the task aloud and tried to solve it and explain his or her mathematical reasoning. Whenever there was no consensus, the group discussed the issue until the disagreement was resolved. Stu- dents were encouraged to talk about the task, explain it to each other, and approach it from different perspectives. Students used the metacog- nitive questions during their discourse in small group activities and in their written explanations when they solved the mathematical tasks. When all students agreed upon the solution, they wrote it down in their notebooks.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"The comprehension questions were designed to prompt students to re- \x1fect on the problem/task before solving it. "
"The connection questions were designed to prompt students to focus on similarities and differences between the problem/task they work on and the problem/task or set of problems/tasks that they had already solved."
"The strategic questions were designed to prompt students to consider which strategies are appropriate for solving the given problem/task and for what reasons. [¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The reßection questions were designed to prompt students to reßect on their understanding and feelings during the solution process[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"Prior to the beginning of the study, all three teachers were exposed to a one-day in-service training. They were told that they will participate in a study in which new materials on problem solving are being tried out. They went over the new materials and learned how to use them with their students. The materials included the tasks and the explicit lesson plans. In addition, the teachers were introduced to pedagogical issues related to the New Standards (NCTM, 2000). A discussion was held about the question: \x93What is a worthwhile mathematical problem?\x94. The teachers who were assigned to the IMPROVE method were famil- iar with it. They started to implement the method three years prior to the beginning of the study, and since then they have used the method regularly in their mathematics classrooms. Nevertheless, prior to the beginning of the study, we brie\x1fy reviewed the IMPROVE principles and reminded the teachers to embed the metacognitive questions in the new unit.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]" The present study focused, however, only on the problem solving unit which was taught in all classrooms in the last semester for six weeks.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"COOP +META Condition The COOP+META condition resembled the IMPROVE procedure (Mevarech & Kramarski, 1997a). Students in that condition studied in small heterogeneous groups using the metacognitive questions described earlier: comprehension questions, strategic questions, and connection questions. The metacognitive questions were used by students individually when their turn arrived to solve a problem or complete a task aloud, by the group as a whole in mathematical discourse, and by the teacher when introducing the new concepts to the whole class, reviewing the lesson at the end of the class, and providing help in the small groups."
"COOP Condition Under the COOP condition, students studied in small heterogeneous groups as in the COOP+META condition, but they were not exposed to metacognitive training. Each session started with a short presentation of the new materials to the whole class using the question-answering technique. The students then started work on the problems or tasks. The teachers encouraged students to discuss mathematical ideas in their small groups and to provide explanations to one another, but no explicit metacognitive guidance was provided. Each student, in turn, read a problem or task aloud and tried to solve or complete it. When students failed to solve a problem or did not agree on the solu- tion, the team discussed the components of the problem until consensus was achieved. When all team members agreed on a solution, they recorded it in their notebooks. When no team members knew how to solve a prob- lem, the team asked for teacher assistance. At the end of the lesson, the teacher reviewed the main ideas of the lesson with the entire class. When common difÞculties were observed, the teacher provided additional expla-[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"nations to the whole class. In each period the teacher worked with two to three groups.[¬e]"']

"The connection questions were designed to prompt students to focus on similarities and differences between the immediate problem or task and prob- lems or tasks that they had already completed successfully. [¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"metacognitive instruction within cooperative learning (COOP C META)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"All classes studied the Linear Graph unit. The main purpose of the unit was to develop graph sense of linear graphs. In particular, in all classes students studied: (a) the concepts of slope, intersection point, and rate of change; (b) quantitative and qualitative methods of graph interpretation of the form y Z mx C b. Students were not exposed to graph construction in any class."
" The Linear Graph unit was taught for two weeks (10 lessons). At the beginning of the unit the teacher introduced in each group strategies of graph interpretation such as tables, algebraic formula, steps, and verbal explanations. All students in both methods of instruction practiced these strategies with the same problems/tasks, and all students used the same textbook. The sessions under both methods included three parts: Teachers’ introduction to the whole class (about 10 min), cooperative seatwork (about 30 min) and teacher review with the whole class (about 5 min). Each session started with a teacher’s short presentation of the new materials to the whole class. The teacher modeled aloud strategies for completing the task, and explained why the strategies are likely to solve the task. Following the teachers’ introduction, the students started to work in small groups using materials designed for the study."
"The cooperative learning in both COOP C META and COOP groups encouraged mathematical discourse among students. Students learned in heterogeneous teams of four pupils: One high, two middle, and one low achieving student."
"Each student, in turn, read a problem/task aloud and tried to solve it. Whenever there was not any consensus, the team dis- cussed the issue until the disagreement was resolved. The group discourse was based on explaining the problem/task to each other, approaching it from diﬀerent pers- pectives, balancing the perspectives against each other, and proceeding according to what seemed to be the best option at the time. When all team members agreed on a solution, they wrote it down on their answer sheets. When none of the team members knew how to solve a problem/task, they asked for the teacher’s assistance. At the end of the period, the teacher reviewed the main ideas of the lesson with the entire class. When common diﬃculties were observed, the teacher provided additional explanations to the class.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]" The metacognitive instruction utilized a series of four self-addressed metacognitive questions: Comprehension, strategic, connection and reﬂection."
" To assist students in using the comprehension questions, students used the acronym DATA: Describe the x-axis and the y-axis; Address the units and the ranges of each axis; Tell the Trend(s) of the graph or parts of the graph; and Analyze speciﬁc points."
"The strategic questions were designed to prompt students to consider which strategies are appropriate for solving the given problem/task and for what reasons."
"Regarding graphs, strategic questions referred to strategies that students could use in interpreting the graphs. Strategies could refer to adding steps to the graph in order to calculate the slope, to using data-tables, or to referring to the graph’s algebraic representation."
"Connection questions were designed to prompt students to focus on similarities and diﬀerences between the problem/task they attempted to solve, and the problem/ task or set of problems/tasks that they had already solved. Regarding graphs, the connection questions referred to questions that guided students to ﬁnd similarities and diﬀerences between the graph at hand and graphs they had already interpreted or to compare diﬀerent intervals on the same graph. Reﬂection questions were designed to prompt students to focus on monitoring the solution process (e.g., ‘‘Is the result reasonable?’’)."
"he metacognitive questions were used by each student when it was his/her turn to attempt to solve a problem/task aloud; by the group as a whole in the mathematical discourse; in writing when students used their booklets; and by the teacher when she introduced the new concepts to the whole class, reviewed the lesson, and provided help in small groups.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"The present study investigates the diﬀerential eﬀects of cooperative learning with or without metacognitive instruction on making sense of graphs.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]" The main purpose of the present study is therefore to investigate the eﬀects of the two methods on graph interpretation and graph construction with regard to students’ alternative conceptions.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Given the studies reviewed above, there is reason to suppose that providing metacognitive instruction within cooperative settings would enrich the mathematical discourse and thus would proﬁt students’ graph sense. Metacognitive instruction would exert positive eﬀects both on students’ ability to interpret graphs and on students’ ability to construct graphs as a transfer task. Furthermore, this instruction would also exert positive eﬀects on students’ ability to reduce their alternative conceptions regarding graphing.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" E-leaming supported by the IMPROVE self-me- tacognitive questioning approach (EL+IMP) [¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"(a) Self-metacognitive questioning: the self-metacognitive questioning included four categories of questions based on the IMPROVE method: comprehension, connection, strategic, and reflection. The questions were presented on the screen and printed on a worksheet. The teacher modelled the use of the self-metacognitive questioning. Students were asked to think aloud about the questions and provide written responses. They were informed that self-metacognitive questioning would help them better understand and remember mathematical topics."
"(b) Mathematical explanations: a discussion was held with the students on the subject of mathematical explanations. The teacher[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"practiced various types of explanations (e.g. logic- formal, daily, computational, drawing). Students were stimulated to ask themselves: ‘What is a good math\xad ematical explanation’? In addition, students were asked to provide explanations for their solutions, reflect on their explanations, and suggest ways to modify them. (c) EL-metacognitive feedback: students were exposed to two types of interactive feedback that were provided in E-leaming: metacog- nitive and result feedback. Metacognitive feedback referred to questions that were provided on the com\xad puter screen during and after the solution process (e.g. ‘Why the slope of a line a does not change?; What is the difference between the expression X and the ex\xad pression that you found’?). Students were asked to answer such questions and explain their reasoning on the computer. In addition, students received computer- generated result feedback regarding the correctness of the task solution. An example of a task provided in EL+IMP embedded with metacognitive and result feedback is provided in Appendix A.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"We argue that many more students would be able to attain mathematical problem solving competency in E- leaming if they implement the following procedures: emphasize self-metacognitive questioning based on what, when, and why certain strategies should (or should not) be applied, and reflect on mathematical explanations in E-leaming environments."\n"We suggest that students who are exposed to the IMPROVE self- metacognitive questioning approach (EL+IMP) will reflect on solution processes more easily than students who are not exposed to this approach. We also assume that reflecting on mathematical explanations using the IMPROVE self-metacognitive questioning approach (EL+IMP) will enhance SRL.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]" instructors recorded every session with each student on an audio-cassette tape. Two RAs familiar with the instruction reviewed at least three sessions for each student, except for one student for whom they reviewed two, while completing a treatment \x1edelity form. For reliability, another RA, a doctoral student in special education, listened to at least one tape of each student and completed the same treatment \x1edelity form. Thus, each student received two treatment integrity scores: an initial score completed by the \x1erst RA reporting overall session integrity for all intervention sections and a second completed by an outside observer who observed between one and four sessions for each student. For both approaches, session integrity was computed by dividing the number of lesson components taught divided by the total number of components possible, multiplying the quantity by 100.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"The treatment group received main idea lessons in a sequence suggested by the literature, in order: (1) identifying relationships in units smaller than paragraphs and identifying topics of paragraphs; (2) identifying explicit main ideas in paragraphs; (3) identi\xad fying implicit main ideas in paragraphs; and (4) identi\xad fying main ideas in passages"\n"Information about main idea identification was con\xad veyed largely by direct explanation, along with the aid of teacher-created overhead transparencies and hand\xad outs. A five-step instructional strategy developed by Baumann (1983b) was followed for each lesson. Briefly, the five steps are: (1) introduction of the content and its purpose; (2) provision of a concrete example of the skill to be taught; (3) direct teacher instruction of the skill; (4) teacher-guided application of the skill; and (5) inde\xad pendent student practice of the skill. Added to Baumann’s five steps was a review component intro\xad duced at the beginning of the second, third, and fourth lessons. This review component helped orient students to the lesson at hand by recalling for them what had been learned the week before and linking the skills of the previous lesson with the skills to be mastered in the current lesson.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" improve students’ identification of explicit and implicit main ideas in para\xad graphs. "\n"determine whether systematic instruction in main idea identification would influence summary writing and general reading comprehension.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"On the first day of actual reciprocal teaching, the students in the experi- mental classrooms were divided into groups of four or five. [¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"After a discussion leader was de- cided on in each group, students were told to begin reading their lesson for the day from their social studies text- book (usually three to four pages). They were also given a daily work- sheet that had been formulated in the pilot study to be completed. The intent of this worksheet was to help structure the process of reciprocal teaching until the students could do it on their own. The worksheet asked students to think of three good questions to ask about the material that they read. It also asked them to list the subheadings of the section that they read and to list three main points of each subheading. This worksheet is found in Appen- dix C. Students were told that the daily worksheets were to structure the process and were only going to be used for 4 days. Students then began the process of reciprocal teaching. Gener- ally, it took the groups about 30 min- utes to work their way through each day\x92s reading."
"For the first 5 days, I structured and monitored the process of reciprocal teaching. This involved taking the stu- dents step by step through the strate- gies of questioning, summarizing, pre- dicting, and clarifying."
"Students also practiced how to identify main points in the text and how to put them together to form basic summaries. I also asked students to think about how to ask other group members for additional information that would help foster their own un- derstanding and that of the group. If other questions arose regarding the process of reciprocal teaching, I pro- vided scaffolding on how to approach the material."
"At the start of each intervention day, I provided 5 minutes of procedural feedback to students regarding how the intervention was going. I asked students to keep in mind the structure of reciprocal teaching (questioning, summarizing, clarifying, and predict- ing) and to remember that this was a group activity and not a contest with the other groups. I also emphasized that group members were there to help other group members discuss and un- derstand the text. After this review, students were told they could begin work on their lesson.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"Reciprocal teaching has been demon- strated to improve reading compre- hension ability in students. The premise of reciprocal teaching is that students, by active discussion of text in a small group of their peers, can en- hance their learning and improve their ability to comprehend text and moni- tor understanding of text. "
"The purpose of this study was to ex- amine the effectiveness of reciprocal[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"teaching during social studies with fourth-, fifth-, and sixth-grade stu- dents, some of whom had learning dis- abilities.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"(A) Finding a title for the passage None of the texts used as work material for this programme had a title. The reader’s task consisted of making up the most appropriate title, given the information they had just read. The task involved looking for the general outline of the text, including the comprehension of the most important information."
"(B) Identification of the overall relationship between the contents of the passage and the main elements In this task, the student was trained to use the internal organization of the text through some of the dominant rhetorical relationships described by Meyer (1984, 1985a). These were: problem-solution; causation (antecedent-consequence); and collection and description.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"(C) Summarizing the contents "
" The task consisted of summarizing the written selection of ideas produced in tasks (A) and (B). The reader, therefore, using only the title and the schematic information, had to make a written summary which reflected the most important parts of the text."
"For each task during the implementation of this programme, we followed the “reasoned instruction” steps (Brown & Palincsar, 1982; Palincsar & Brown, 1984). These steps involved three consecutive phases: (1) Explanation. The object of this phase was simply to describe to the subjects each one of the tasks, its usefulness and its purpose. (2) Modelling. In this phase, the idea was to model each activity for the students. First, the researcher explicitly demonstrated the task so that, step by step, the student could internalize what was involved and assume more responsibility for the task. (3) ' Supervised Practice. In this phase, the idea was to monitor the application of each one of the tasks. The role of the researcher consisted of orienting the student to carry out the task, pointing out errors that he/she had made and suggesting possible strategies for considering or justifying their decisions as a way of reinforcing their achievements. This assistance from the researcher was gradually reduced as these adolescent readers began to perform the task by themselves. In each activity, the instructor used questions, graphs and simple examples to facilitate and support learning.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"The Direct Instruction Programme was designed to improve the comprehension of written material by using strategies that would allow subjects to recognize the text structure, identify its logical relationships and apply this structure to text construction in memory. More specifically, the programme involved teaching skills which enabled the students to: — Obtain a clear understanding of the structure of a number of expository texts. — Activate an appropriate general scheme in which the newly read information could be included. — Extract the macrostructure from the text.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]" Identify and retain the essential logical relationships of the text structure together with the main elements of the passage. — Summarize the text by following the original structure.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"he CVD program included 12 modules (one to three les- sons each) based on the district’s social studies textbook, Early United States"
" Each CVD lesson was scripted and followed a similar format. The teacher began by providing a rationale, explaining the importance of the strat- egy or method and how it would help the children’s vocabulary development and reading proficiency. The teacher modeled the method with simple text passages (included in the scripted lesson plans) and often used a think-aloud to help the children understand complex metacognitive skills. She provided opportunities for the children to practice and coached them as they attempted to implement self-monitoring methods and clarifying strategies. Once the children were comfortable with the newly learned methods, the teacher dem- onstrated how they could be used to make sense of words found in the social studies textbook. The children then worked in independent pairs, reading the textbook and implementing the method. int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"The 13 sessions of reciprocal training were divisible into four phases: 1. On the first 4 days, the adult ex\xad plained to subjects how to ask questions, clarify unknown words or phrases, sum\xad marize passages, and predict what would happen next using passage clues."
" Each day a new strategy was introduced, and the pre\xad viously learned strategies were practiced. Students took turns attempting the trained processes, beginning with the first session.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"2. For days 5 and 6, subjects read the story aloud and took turns clarifying, ques\xad tioning, summarizing, and predicting. On a typical day, the adult instructor introduced the training passage for the day with a brief discussion intended to activate students' prior knowledge about the topic. The adult called attention to the title and requested predictions about the passage based on it. Then the adult assigned a student to serve as “teacher" for a segment of the passage. This student leader attempted to predict (before reading) what might be contained in the passage. The prediction was based on prior knowledge of concepts in the title. The leader also generated questions as read\xad ing proceeded and summarized the content of the passage. The leader made clarifica\xad tions both during and after reading. When the student leader experienced difficulties, other students provided assistance. The leader also solicited requests for clarification from other members of the reading group. All participants were aware that they could ask for clarifications whenever needed. The peer leader also requested fellow students to generate questions, to summarize the segment, and to make predictions about subsequent segments of the passage. 3. For days 7-11, the passages were di\xad vided into segments, with students reading each segment silently. Subjects read stories one segment at a time. Then the adult elic\xad ited oral clarifications, questions, summar\xad ies, and predictions from the students. Sup\xad portive prompting was provided as necessary; feedback was given consistently. 4. For the last 2 days, subjects read the entire training story silently without inter\xad ruption, encouraged by the adult instructor to pause occasionally to clarify, question, summarize, and predict.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Reciprocal teaching was hypoth\xad esized to affect comprehension processes, and thus pretest-to-posttest improvements for standardized comprehension were ex\xad pected to be greater in the reciprocally taught condition than in the control group.[¬e]"']

int_leng_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]" We selected readings permitting completion of the train\xad ing passage and daily assessment in a half hour with a relaxed pace.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"The third part of training involved instruction and practice in recognizing text structure, such as what main ideas and supporting details are, and the most common locations of these in paragraphs. In the fourth part of training, subjects were taught how to identify which main ideas were most important for understanding and remembering astory, and received practice in ranking the importance of different main ideas in astory. The fifth part of the training program involved having subjects generate questions about the ideas they had rated most important. They were also encouraged to generate questions before they began reading aselection using the title and any instructions from the author or instructor. They were told that generating questions as they read would help them to understand what they were readi"

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Subjects in the experimental group received instruction in formal logic from the curriculum developed for this study. The curriculum, hereafter referred to as Reality-Based Logic for Adolescents (RBLA), introduces students to concepts of information processing theory, classification, hierarchical organization of information, propositional reasoning, syllogistic reasoning, and analogical reasoning. It is primarily text-based, although Venn diagrams and truth-tables are included. RBLA is comprised of a student textbook and a teacher\'s handbook, and designed to be infused into standard instruction in math, English or social science courses for approximately one hour per week for one semester. It differs from other programs to teach thinking skills in that the focus is primarily on formal logic. It differs from standard logic texts such as those used in college philosophy classes in that it is written for high school students and connects logical principles to life experience."\n"Instruction from RBLA was presented by the classroom teacher for approximately one hour per week.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" The purpose of the study described here is to determine whether teaching formal logic to adolescents in a U.S. public high school enhances their capacity for critical thought as measured by both standardized ability tests and students self-perceptions.[¬e]"']

The third had attended workshops on critical thinking offered at a local community college.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]" This programme (which we called the TRAC\x97Talk, Reasoning and Computers\x97programme) was a specially-designed scheme of work made up of teacher-led and collaborative activities, with some of the latter being computer-based. Embodied in TRAC was our own explicit conception of the 'ground rules' necessary for generating exploratory talk. The findings of our own and other relevant prior research (see Mercer, 1995; Wegerif & Mercer, 1997a) led us to specify the following set of ground rules: 1. all relevant information is shared; 2. the group seeks to reach agreement;[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"3. the group takes responsibility for decisions; 4. reasons are expected; 5. challenges are accepted; 6. alternatives are discussed before a decision is taken; and 7. all in the group are encouraged to speak by other group members. The programme (which is described in more detail in Dawes, 1997, 1998) requires teachers to take their class through a series of nine structured lessons which raise children's awareness of how they talk together, and guide them into the use of exploratory talk."
" Each lesson within the programme was designed to last for about 1 hour and focused on one or more of the ground rules of exploratory talk. The first few also dealt with skills such as listening, sharing information and cooperating, while later lessons encouraged children to make critical arguments for and against different cases. One specified outcome of the early part of the programme is that each teacher and class create their own, user-friendly version of the ground rules for generating exploratory talk established by the researchers.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"the teacher makes explicit the talk-related aims of the lesson, elicits children's understanding of the ground rules and consolidates this understanding as 'common knowledge' (Edwards & Mercer, 1987)."
"The class's ground rules embody the main characteristics of exploratory talk, and once established the children are expected to follow them when engaged in any joint discussion activities in class. It is therefore important that they feel some 'ownership' and responsibility for adherence to them. Once each target class had agreed a set of 'ground rules for talking', these were written up on a poster and displayed prominently in the classroom."
"The TRAC programme included some computer-based group activities designed to elicit[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"and support children's use of talk for joint reasoning. Some of these used commercial software while other software was specially designed by one of the authors (Wegerif) with content based on the science and citizenship curricula for Year 5 children in English schools. (The Tracks software, which figures in Sequence 1, is an example. See Wegerif et al., 1998 for more information.)[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Metucognitive training. The metacognitive training condi- tion is part of the IMPROVE project described earlier. As indicated, metacognitive training uses a series of three kinds of questions: a comprehension question (i.e., What is in the problem?), a compare question (i.e., How is this problem similar/differentfrom the previous problem?), and a strategy question (i.e., What strategies are appropriate for solving the problem?). The questions were constructed and arranged to follow the four-stage model of the problem-solving process: orientation and problem identification, organization, execu- tion, and evaluation (Garofalo & Lester, 1985; Polya, 1973; Schoenfeld, 1985). The questions were deliberately de- signed to help students to be aware of the problem-solving process and to monitor their progress."
"Comprehension questions oriented students to articulate the main ideas in the problem (e.g., \x93Describe the problem in your own words without referring to the numbers\x94), clas- sify the problem into an appropriate category (e.g., this is a . . . problem), and identify the given and the unknown."
"Strategic questions refer to strategies appropriate for solving the problem. Students were prompted to use a mod-[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"ified version of\x91 the number-line strategy suggested by Lewis (1989). The modified strategy is based on a compar- ison of two lines, each representing one variable, and equal- izing their lengths by adding the needed amount to the shorter line. "
"Finally, connection questions refer to the similarities and differences between the problem at hand and the problems solved previously. Students had to discuss the mathematical structure of the problem and to distinguish between the mathematical model and the problem\x92s story. In doing so, students gradually learned to distinguish between the sur- face and the deep mathematical structure of the problem. Students learned to distinguish between consistent and inconsistent problems as well as between problems sharing the same story context but having different mathematical structures (Weaver & Kintsch, 1992). "
"The three metacognitive questions were used by the stu- dents when they worked in small heterogeneous groups and by the teachers when they introduced compare problems to the whole class. worked with the teams, and reviewed the materials. A series of individual hand-held strategy prompt cards was used by the students during the practice and sub- sequent lesson-discussion sessions to instigate their discus- sion. Each student took turns trying to solve a problem and explain his or her reasoning by answering the metacognitive questions printed on the cards. When all team members agreed upon the answer, another student tried to solve the problem in the same way. The metacognitive questions also were printed in the students\x92 workbooks; periodically they had to answer them in writing.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]" In that method, students learn to formulate and answer metacog- nitive questions for each other on mathematical problems. The metacognitive questions focus on comprehending the problem, making connections, and applying strategies. In doing so, the students must process the material and learn how to focus on the essential elements of the problems."\n" structuring group interactions through metacognitive training that combines constructing connec- tions and applying strategies would produce better achieve- ment outcomes than structuring group interactions through strategy instruction, which would, in turn, produce better achievement outcomes than unstructured group interac- tion[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]", each class studied mathematics cooperatively five times a week[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"In all classrooms, students studied in cooperative settings with the same textbook and for the same duration of time. Furthermore, students in all classrooms solved exactly the same problems, and the teachers used the same problems in their introductions and reviews. The learning in the cooperative settings was implemented as follows. At the beginning of each period, the teacher introduced the new concepts to the whole class by using the questioning-answering technique. Then, students worked in small heterogeneous groups comprised of one low, two middle, and one high achieving student. The assignment of students to small groups was based on their performance on the pretest. Finally, at the end of the period, the teacher reviewed the new concepts, solved the problems that were considered difficult by many groups, and addressed students’ questions."
"The two conditions differed in the learning procedure. In the cooperative setting embedded with worked-out examples (WE condition), in each class period students were administered a worked-out example followed by four practising problems of the same kind."
" Students were asked to study cooperatively the worked-out example and then to solve the practising problems accordingly. Each student in turn solved a problem aloud, and explained the solution to the group by using the worked-out example."
"In the cooperative setting embedded with metacognitive instruction (MT condition), students were not provided with worked-out examples, but were guided to activate metacognitive questioning as used by IMPROVE (Mevarech & Kramarski, 1997). The metacognitive questions included comprehension questions, connection questions, strategic questions and reflection questions. Students formulated and answered the metacognitive questions while they worked on the problems. Each new type of problem was followed by a series of four practising problems that required a solution through metacognitive questioning. Each student in turn read a problem aloud and tried to solve the problem by using the metacognitive questioning procedure. When a student failed to solve the problem, or when there was a disagreement between solvers, students discussed the solution until a consensus was achieved. Students asked the teacher for help only when they failed to reach an agreement.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"The study examines two ways to structure group interaction: one is based on worked- out examples (WE) and the other on metacognitive training (MT). Both methods were implemented in cooperative settings, and both guided students to focus on the problem\'s essential parts and on appropriate problem-solving strategies.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:\n[¬s]"Mevarech and Kramarski (1997) designed a multidimensional instructional method for teaching mathematics in heterogeneous classrooms. The method, called IMPROVE, is based on cognitive-metacognitive theories and cooperative-mastery learning approach (Mevarech, 1985, 1991). IMPROVE is the acronym consisting of the following teaching steps: Introducing new concepts, Metacognitive questioning, Practising. Reviewing, Obtaining mastery on lower and higher cognitive processes, Verification, and Enrichment.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]" teachers did not have to be specially trained for the purpose of the present study.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"In all classrooms, students studied the time-distance-spced unit for about 4 weeks.[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" The teacher’s introduction lasted approximately 10 minutes, the students’ work in small groups lasted almost 30 minutes, and the teacher’s review lasted for 10 minutes. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"s. Features available include: personalizing the portfolio; setting outcome and process goals; creating new work; linking to existing work; reﬂecting on work; sharing work; obtaining feedback from teachers, peers & parents; editing work; saving work under multi- ple versions and sending work to a presentation folder."\n" ePEARL guides students through the creation process, allowing enough ﬂexibility for truly creative work and just enough scaffolding to keep students on the right track. It offers a text editor and an audio recorder for the creation of work. Readings, music pieces, or oral presen- tations may be recorded. The software also offers the ability to attach work completed using other software, so it can accommodate any kind of digital work a student creates, including videos, slideshows, podcasts, scanned images or photographs of paper-based work. Before work is created, students are encouraged to set their goals for this work, and may attach learning logs, evaluation rubrics and study plans to keep track of their learning process as it takes place. After the creation of work, sharing with peers or teachers is supported so that students may solicit feedback on drafts of work. Students may also reﬂect on their performance and strategies, and to use these to adjust their goals for the next work. The presentations folder is where students collect their selected artifacts – created either from within ePEARL’s text editor or audio re- corder, or from outside of the tool. The selection process allows students to reﬂect on why they feel a work belongs in their portfolio, its relationship to other work, and on their own advancements. Self-regulation is also supported when students create new goals for future work or modify learning behavior based on their reﬂections on a particular piece they have collected. Sharing with peers and parents is encouraged and teachers have automatic access to view all of their students’ ePEARLs.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" is designed to support the phases of self-regulation. The three cyclical phases of self-regulation include both metacognitive and motivational components, providing the foundation for better sustainability of learning and skill development. The forethought phase includes task analysis (goal setting and strategic planning) and self-motivation beliefs (self-efﬁcacy, outcome expectations, intrinsic interest/value and goal orientation). Tasks involved in the forethought phase are: set outcome goals, set process goals, document goal values, plan strategies, and set up learning logs. The next phase, the performance phase, includes self-control (self-instruction, imagery, attention focusing and task strategies) and self-observation (self-recording and self-experimentation). Tasks involved in the performance phase are: creation of work, and learning log entries. Finally, the self-reﬂection phase includes self-judgment (self-evaluation and casual attribution) and self-reaction (self-satisfaction/affect and adaptive-defensive responses) (Zimmerman, 2000). Tasks involved in the self-reﬂection phase are: reﬂection on work, reﬂection on process, and awareness of new goal opportunities.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" All experimental teachers[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]"(n = 16) received at least a half-day of training on the use of ePEARL from research centre staff and follow-up support including lesson plans and job aids, an online discussion forum (in the form of a moderated wiki), as well as in-class observations and model lessons during the school year. In addition, multimedia scaffolding and support for teachers and students are embedded in the tool. At the conclusion of the school year, experimental teachers were offered additional training to deepen their understanding of ePEARL, portfolio pedagogy, and to introduce them to the new version of ePEARL (3.0) that was launched in August 2008.[¬e]"']

int_freq_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Due to varying levels of implementation [¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"We began by identifying the levels of implementation of each of the participating 16 experimental classrooms. We applied the Imple- mentation Assessment Protocol (IAP) to rate each classroom as ‘‘low,” ‘‘medium,” or ‘‘high” degree of implementation. The IAP was applied at two points during the research cycle: in April prior to post-test and in June at the end of data collection to ensure that the experimental classes included in the data set met our minimum implementation criteria. Classrooms that were categorized as low implementation (n = 9) were dropped from the data set entirely as they did not have sufﬁcient exposure to the tool to expect treatment effects. Their equiv- alent control schools were also dropped from the analysis (n = 9) leaving a total of 14 classrooms in the data set (experimental = 7, control = 7).[¬e]"']
int_freq_info: Varied depending on class - IFQ was used to determine how many hours per month teachers implemented treatment.   Only teachers and classes that implemented treatment for at least 5 hours a month were included in the analysis.   So there was at least 1 session per week.
int_leng_info: 60 minutes - implementation was measured in hours per month.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"All students studied the unit three times per week for 12 weeks (over 4 months), using the same textbook and reading identical scientific texts (IME, 1999). "
" each lesson comprised three parts. The first part focused on the description of a scientific phenomenon. Students were asked to read a scientific text, identify the scientific problem described in the text, analyze relevant data, and formulate scientific hypotheses. In the second part, students read the results of an experiment relating to the scientific phenomenon that was described in the first part. At this stage, students were required to identify the experiment’s components, such as dependent and inde\xad pendent variables, measurement techniques, control, and repetition. In the third part, students were asked to describe the results of the experiment and to reach valid conclu\xad sions based on the data."
" students studied in cooperative, small learning groups comprising four students: one higher achiever, two middle achievers, and one lower achiever. [¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"The metacognitive guidance used"
"in the present study was based on Mevarech and Kramarski’s (1997) IMPROVE method in which students are encouraged to use a series of four self-addressed metacognitive questions. The IMPROVE method’s self\xad questioning refers to (a) comprehending the phenomenon or the problem described in the text"
"(b) constructing connections between previous and new knowledge"
" (c) using appropriate inquiry strategies to solve the problem"
" (d) reflecting on the processes and the solution"
"The metacognitive self-addressed questions were printed on the students’ learning sheets and in the teacher’s guide for all three metacognitive treatments. Students used these metacognitive questions in the small group activities. In addition, the teachers modeled the use of the metacogni\xad tive questioning"
"The beMETA group received the set of self-addressed metacognitive questions prior to beginning each text’s reading. Students were told that these questions would help them to understand and remember the text and that they would have to use the questions when reading the text. Students discussed the questioning in small groups to ensure that they would be able to use these questions when comprehending the text. Then, they started read\xad ing the text, discussing it in small groups, and respond\xad ing to the metacognitive questioning and the tasks that followed the text.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"investigated effects of metacogni\xad tive instruction at different phases of reading scientific texts on elementary school students’ sci entific literacy a nd meta\xad cognitive awareness.[¬e]"']

[¬s]" Students"
"were told that for the next few days they would be learning and practicing some spe\xad cial thinking instructions to use during reading."
" for the remain\xad der of Session 1, and for Sessions 2 and 3, stu\xad dents received two presentations of their assigned training package with a different prac\xad tice passage used for each presentation."
"Specific Self-Instruction. The content of the statements given to the Specific Self-Instruction students reflected five training components sim\xad ilar to those used by Kendall and Wilcox (1980) and Meichenbaum (1975). Five task specific statements were constructed to: define the task, designate an approach to complete the task, evaluate the approach taken, reinforce the learner’s efforts, and complete the task. The children employed the first three statements be\xad fore reading, then stopped to assess their pro\xad gress with the fourth statement after reading two sentences and finally, used the fifth state\xad ment after the entire passage was read. Children were asked to read the passages orally as they employed the self-statements. Feedback was given on the correct answer for each of the prac\xad tice passages."
"The students were taught to internalize these self-statements through a four-phase fad\xad ing procedure (after Meichenbaum, 1975). During the first phrase, the experimenter mod\xad eled the instructions while reading the training passage orally. In the second phase, the child and experimenter verbalized the instructions and read the passage together. In the third phase, the child whispered the instructions alone while reading the passage orally. Finally, the child read the passages orally but used the instructions covertly.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"After a child had progressed to the covert phase, the four-phase procedure was repeated with the second practice story.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Self-instruction (SI). The self-instruction children were taught a series of self-statements which reflected the five training components most typically employed in cognitive behavioral interventions (Kendall & Wilcox, 1980; Meichenbaum & Goodman, 1971). The five self-statements were designed (a) to define the task, (b) to designate an approach to complete the task, (c) to evaluate the approach taken, (d) to reinforce the learner\'s efforts, and (e) to check on the completion of the task. The statements used to correspond to each of these components were What am I supposed to do?; How am I going to do this, what is my plan?; How is my plan working so far?; I am really doing good work; and Think back, did I find any problems in this story? The children employed the first two statements before reading, then evaluated their progress with the third and fourth statements after reading a few sentences and, finally, used the fifth statement after the entire passage was read. In addition to learning how to employ the self-verbalization strategy, children were also instructed on when and why it would be important to use a self-verbalization strategy during reading. Children learned to internalize the self-statements through a four-step fading procedure in which the experimenter first modeled the statements. Next, the student and experimenter used the self-statements together. Then, the student whispered the statements without the experimenter. Finally, the student covertly used the statements and read the passage. These four phases constituted one presentation of the instructional package with the same practice story used throughout the presentation. The same story was employed so that children could focus on learning the self-statements. Once the four phases were completed on the first practice story, the whole procedure was repeated on the second practice story. These exact procedures were followed for all three training sessions. Thus, the students in this condition received eight exposures to the instructions during each training session (i.e., four times with the two practice passages\x97one which had an error and one which did not).[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Children were taught to use these sentences before reading  What am I supposed to do? How am I going to do this, what is my plan?  After reading a few sentences   How is my plan working so far? I am really doing good work    and after reading the entire passage  Think back, did I find any problems in this story?

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"The total duration of the experiment was eight lessons of 1 h. In the \x1erst lesson, the students were given instructions about the assignment and the electronic learning envi- ronment. All students received the same instructions and all triads spent the same time working on the assignment (6 h). In six lessons the triads worked on an assignment called \x91\x91Would you like to live abroad?\x92\x92 The goal of the assignment was to explore a country of choice (New Zealand or Iceland), write a paper on the \x1endings and decide if they would like to live in this country. The triads worked on one computer and had access to an inhabitant of the country. They could consult the expert by asking questions and requesting information about different topics about the country that they were interested in. In the expert section, the requested information about the country was written by the expert and questions were answered in a forum. The assignment to write a paper about the country was preceded by four sub-assign- ments: introducing the group, writing a goal statement, selecting a country and specifying topics of interest in a mind map to further support the collaboration with the expert. All tasks were integrated into the working space of the triads, where they also wrote the paper. The performance of the triads was stored in the learning environment. All lessons were supervised by the same researcher. The 8th h was used for the measurement of individual domain and metacognitive knowledge.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: 7-9-year-old elementary school pupils working in triads worked on an assignment "would you like to live abroad". Through electronic learning environment they could access expert of either New Zealand or Iceland. The avatar (either gave an example - which we are not interested in - or) asked a question structuring how the children should approach the task. The avatar appeared on the screen to the control group but did not ask questions.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Teachers at Rosendale Primary School developed the ReflectED approach over a number of years. The ReflectED approach comprises the following: 1. Pupils receive a weekly ReflectED lesson from their teacher who follows a series of lesson plans. 2. At least once a week, pupils are expected to reflect individually on their learning in other lessons and record these reflections on the Evernote platform (accessible through any tablet, netbook, laptop or PC). The lesson plans include tasks for the week, to support pupils to practice their metacognitive skills throughout their normal lessons. 3. Children code their reflections to record their thoughts on a lesson and their performance. This enables them, and the teacher, to read previous reflections to inform future teaching and learning."
"There are a total of 28 lessons in the materials provided by Rosendale. These lessons teach children specific metacognitive strategies they can use to support their learning, and teach them to reflect on their learning. For example, in the first lesson children are encouraged to think about when they learned something new and are then taught to juggle or do origami, which is not a skill they have learned before. Throughout this lesson pupils are encouraged to talk about how instruction helps them to learn, about learning in stages and the importance of practice."
"Enabling children to reflect well takes time and is scaffolded using a number of tools. A colour-coded system is used for the children to quickly show how well they thought they had done in a particular task. Green, for example, is used by a child to show they have been successful at the task and blue if they believe they have mastered the topic. Yellow denotes they are struggling and red is used to show that they are \x91stuck\x92. A set of pictures showing different feelings, like happy faces or rain clouds, is also provided along with a range of emotion words for the children to express their feelings about the learning process. The colour code, pictures and words are displayed in the classroom for children to quickly refer to. In the early stages of the process children fill in paper-based templates, which are pasted into their workbooks. When children start using the Evernote software on the iPads to record their reflections, they can either take pictures of the paper-based templates, or take pictures of the images or words expressing emotion and add a typed comment. These comments can become very detailed. They can also add audio or video to record reflections. A series of key words (\x91tags\x92) are used to label the posts on Evernote so that they can be easily searched either by the children or the teacher. Children and teachers can use these tags to go back and review their progress and find areas that need more work. Some ReflectED lessons focus on getting the children to develop their skill in using the Evernote software to record their reflections. As the year progresses teachers encourage pupils to use Evernote to record their reflections on a regular basis, ideally several times a week, across different subjects.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"This report describes an evaluation of ReflectED, which aims to support primary-aged pupils to develop their metacognitive or \x91learning-to-learn\x92 skills. Improving children\x92s metacognition focuses on encouraging them to reflect on how they learn, then encouraging them to develop strategies to improve these learning processes and motivate them to use them (Meyer, 2010).[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"In this project, Rosendale Primary School trained teachers from 30 schools in five areas throughout England to deliver ReflectED over the academic year 2014/15. At the beginning of the year, participating teachers received a pack of lesson plans and supporting resources, and an initial day- long training session. This was followed by three additional half-day training sessions throughout the year. A website, digital resources, and weekly reminders and tips were provided by the London Connected Learning Centre. The National Education Trust supported school recruitment and test administration.[¬e]"']
int_cost_ht:
['Page 23:
[¬s]"The following cost information is based on both discussions with teachers in the final focus groups in July 2015 and information provided by the delivery team. It is expected that the majority of schools will have access to the IT required to implement the programme, so this cost is excluded from the cost estimate. The following costs are included in the cost estimate:  The cost of training, travel, project management and technology support. These costs are likely to be limited to the first year of implementation. This cost information was supplied by the developer.[¬e]"', 'Page 24:
[¬s]"Photocopying costs for Reflection sheets (30 sheets per pupil per year). Photocopying is estimated to cost 6p per sheet, so the cost per pupil is £1.80. The total photocopying cost for the project was estimated to be £1,795. This cost would be repeated every year that a school delivers ReflectED. This cost information was collected through the focus groups with teachers.  The cost of the Evernote license. Evernote is free initially, but schools have to pay to acquire sufficient storage capacity for the large number of notes made by the pupils in the programme. This costs £34.99 a year, but one school only needs one licence."
"The total cost of delivering the project in the first year to 30 schools was £50,294, or £1676 per school. Table 10 displays the cumulative cost per pupil over three years, and the average cost per pupil per year. The cost per pupil was calculated by dividing the total project cost by the number of pupils who were allocated to receive the intervention (997)."
"The average cost per pupil per year would be £18.72 over three years.[¬e]"']

int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" Writing poses challenges for many students. In Egypt, many students with learning disabilities (LD) who learn English as a foreign language exhibit deficiencies in the writing process. In order for students to achieve a good level of competence, those students need to apply strategies which have proven to be effective in improving levels of writing in English. The focus of the research is to explore the effectiveness of program based on the self-regulated strategy development of writing skills in writing-disabled secondary school students.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The experimental group was trained to use metacognitive reading strategies for ninety minutes each day for six weeks during the Spanish reading period. Specifically, the metacognitive reading strategy with these participants was the development of self- generated questioning strategies. In this teaching technique, the teachers modeled by asking a variety of questions concerning comprehension of a story or text passage is read. Following the modeling process by the teacher, the students became dialog leaders in their own small groups, taking turns at role playing the teacher and asking self-generated questions of one another"\n"The size of the groups became smaller each week until the children were finally working in pairs. During week six, the children were on their own for the questioning lessons. They read the story, a paragraph at a time, formulated self-generated questions, and wrote their questions on paper. Following , students discussed their answers with the teacher on an individual basis. At this point in the process, the children were strongly encouraged to self- generate questions at an independent leve[¬e]"']

Furthermore, based on CumminsÕ (1983) Interdependence Hypothesis, metacognitive Spanish reading strategy training may increase English reading performance, as well.[¬e]"']

[¬s]" The major goal of Instrumental Enrichment is to enhance the cognitive modifiabil\xad ity of the individual, and this is achieved by the implementation ofsix subgoals: a. The correction of deficient cognitive functions; b. The teaching of specific concepts, operations, and vocabulary required by the Instrument Enrichment exer\xad cises: c. The development of an intrinsic need for adequate cogni\xad tive functioning and the spontaneous use of operational thinking by the production of crystallized schema and habit formation; d. The production of insight and understanding of one's own thought processes, in particular, those processes that pro\xad duce success and if not mastered, are responsible for fail\xad ure; e. The production of task-intrinsic motivation that is rein\xad forced by the meaning of the program in a broader social content; and. f. A change in orientation towards oneself from passive re\xad cipient and reproducer to active generator of information.[¬e]"', 'Page 2:

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"For the SQWP"
"group"
"the examiner provided instruction, modeling, and ap-[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"plication of the metacognitive techniques, along with the rationale for using the techniques."
"Students"
" were first in\xad structed and given feedback on how to identify the main idea and write it down, and how a main idea could be changed into a questioning. The instruction and practice followed these steps: (1) Examiner discussed the concept of a main idea. (2) Examiner and students read a sample passage, after which the examiner identified the main idea. (3) Students were asked to read a passage and identify the main idea. Examiner gave corrective feed\xad"
"back. In addition, examiner asked students for other examples and ideas. (4) Students were asked to read two more passages and identify the main ideas. Examiner gave corrective feedback. (5) Upon mastery of the concept of main idea, stu\xad dents proceeded to the self-questioning training. Those who failed to reach the criterion level for mas\xad tery (80% accuracy on a series of five passages) were given additional training and practice until they reached this criterion level. (6) Examiner discussed how a main idea could be changed into a question and modeled how a question could be formulated. This was followed by examples and corrective feedback. During the second session, in addition to reviewing the previous steps, students were instructed to write down their question and to answer it. To facilitate the gradual transfer of responsibility from the examiner to the student, the students used a prompt card that listed the steps of the SQ procedure. Finally, the stu\xad dents applied the technique to a passage without us\xad ing the prompt card."
"during the third session, they received instruction and modeling regarding the benefits of predicting what the author might discuss in the next section of the text. This instruction followed these steps: (1) Examiner discussed with students the benefits of predicting what the author might present next in the passage (“Predicting forces you to really try to under\xad stand what you are reading so you can anticipate what might happen next” or “When you form a prediction or hypothesis, it motivates you to want to discover whether your idea will be confirmed”). (2) After reading a passage, the examiner modeled a possible prediction (“I predict that in the next para\xad graph...”). (3) Examiner asked the students for other possible predictions and gave corrective feedback. (4) Students were asked to read a passage and for\xad mulate a prediction. Examiner gave corrective feed\xad back. (5) Students were asked to read two passages and formulate their predictions. Examiner gave corrective feedback. (6) If necessary, students were given additional practice with predicting.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"Instruction in active comprehension began on the first day. The teacher re\xad viewed story grammar for the students and discussed the importance of asking appropriate questions. Then she di\xad rected the students’ comprehension of a story by modeling appropriate ques\xad tions. The students silently read a par\xad agraph or two at a time and the teacher intervened with questions at pertinent points that were consistent with story grammar structure. These included questions about the setting, main char\xad acter, his or her goal, and obstacles en\xad countered on the way to achieving or not achieving that goal. These ques\xad tions involved information that was central to the story content. This modeling of questions took place for approximately half of a 40 minute period. For the remainder of the period, the students were directed to try to ask their own questions as they finished the story silently. Then they were given a 15 item multiple choice comprehension test. After this introduction, a four-step procedure of phasing out the teacher and phasing in the students was used to train students to ask their own ques\xad tions during reading. This procedure was followed on 10 successive school days, with a story for each day fol\xad lowed immediately by a comprehen\xad sion test. On the first day, the teacher worked with the whole group. She began to[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"phase herself out and phase in the stu\xad dents by asking the students questions that required a question in response, such as “What would you like to know about what happens next?” (Singer, 1978). Throughout, the appropriate\xad ness of questions to central story con\xad tent was emphasized. The teacher worked with the whole class in this manner for 3 days. Over the next 3 days, the teacher phased herself out further by dividing the class into groups of five or six chil\xad dren. One student was chosen to chair each group and elicit questions from the others while the teacher circulated around the room."
"Next, the students worked in pairs, asking each other questions as they read, and, finally, students worked in\xad dependently, asking their own ques\xad tions before, during, and after reading.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"MPST was adapted from Schoenfeld\'s [16] Managerial Problem Solving Model. The technique emphasizes the ability of the problem solver to articulate a problem solving method and make plans for problem solving procedures. The steps mapped out in the plan should be followed systematically. The problem solver has the responsibility to consciously monitor and regulate each stage of the computational procedure, just as a business manager would monitor any decision taken among many alternatives. Solution procedures are checked periodically to ensure their continued utility. The model has six steps and each step is a prerequisite for the next. The steps are: (1) Identify the problem. (2) Interpret the symbols, signs, concepts, etc. (3) Form a suitable diagram or model. (4) Choose an appropriate solution technique. (5) Solve, using the chosen technique consciously. (6) Does the solution satisfy the problem?[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"This study therefore intended to examine mathematical computational ability of Nigerian students in mathematics after being exposed to two probem solving techniques. Specifically, the study intended to find out whether metacognitive and heuristic problem solving techniques can enhance the computational ability of students working on creative mathematics problems.[¬e]"']
