int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Reciprocal Teaching of Comprehension- Fostering and Comprehension- Monitoring[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 15:\n[¬s]"Briefly, the six students were assigned to three groups of two students who worked together with the adult teacher. Each day the teacher would intro\xad duce the passage with a brief discussion that was intended to activate the stu\xad dent’s prior knowledge (Au, 1979). If at the beginning of instruction the passage were new, the investigator called the student’s attention to the title and asked for predictions based on the title. If the passage were partially completed (portions having been covered on a previous day), the investigator asked the students to state the topic of the text and several important points already covered in the passage. The adult instructor then assigned a teacher for the first segment (usually a paragraph) and the group read the segment silently. Then the teacher for that segment proceeded first to ask a question, then to summarize, and to offer a prediction or ask for a clarification when appropriate. The adult teacher provided the guidance necessary for the student teacher to complete the preceding activities through a variety of techniques: prompting, “What question did you think a teacher might ask?”; instruction, “Remember, a summary is a shortened version, it doesn’t include detail”; and modifying the activity, “If you’re having a hard time thinking of a question, why don’t you summarize first?” The adult teacher also provided praise and feedback specific to the stu\xad dent’s participation"\n"Interactive sessions lasted approximately 30 minutes. All dialogues were tape-recorded so that qualitative changes could be assessed. Throughout the interventions, the students were explicitly told that these activities were general strategies to help them understand better as they read, and that they should try to do something like this when they read silently. It was pointed out that being able to say in your own words what one has just read, and being able to guess what the questions will be on a test, are sure ways of testing oneself to see if one has understood.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"During the initial in - service, the teachers reflected on their current remedial programs in terms of goals and instructional activities"
"e The investigator discu ssed current research regarding the features of successful reading comprehension instruction, focusing particularly on the role of self-regulatory strategies in reading Reciprocal teaching"
"teachers then viewed a videotape of a reciprocal teaching lesson being conducted with a group of eight junior-high students"
"In addition to this day of in-service training, there were two more training sessions conducted in the teachers’ schools"
" At the second session, the teacher(s) and investigator role-played the intervention using the instructional passages The investigator first role - played the teacher and then role -played the students, simulating the situations that had arisen in previous research"
"The final formal training session was again h eld in each of the schools During this session, the investigator and teacher(s) worked with a group of students who would not be involved in the research but who were similar to the experimental students. The process of introducing the instruction, structuring the discussion with the use of the four strategies, and guiding students’ participation in the dialogue was modeled and discussed, with the investigator and teachers taking turns leading the instruction [¬e]"']

['Page 8:
[¬s]"Of the six groups, there were three who appeared, virtually from the outset, to be very comfortable with the procedure I[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]" The teacher of group three indicated, and we agreed, that this discussion was a real struggle for her group"
". For the initial three days, the “discussion” took on the form of teacher inquiry and student response with no indication that this pattern would change "
"We also collaborated more actively with groups one and five"
"After observing for three days, the objective with these groups was just the opposite of the objective described for the previous teacher Our goal was to have these teachers begin i mplementation of reciprocal teaching in a more structured fashion Both of these teachers had attempted to very quickly place the students in control of the discussion, however, the students hadn’t indicated readiness to do so and, consequently, the “discussion” quickly deteriorated into something not unlike a verbal “free -for-all.”[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"To validate our own observations of these sessions, we asked two raters, both of whom had conducted reciprocal teaching instruction, to listen independently to sessions from the first three and the last three days of instruction for each teacher and to rank order the quality of instruction For the first half of instruction, while the aters were not in 100% agreement regarding the exact ordering of the lessons, they did rate the three teachers who worked independently from the beginning among the top three and concurred on the two bottom ranked lessons For the second half of instruction, they concurred on the top two lessons but were not consistent in their ratings of the other four groups. The raters noted that each of the teachers indicated fidelity to the reciprocal teaching procedure.[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"Comparability of the experimental and control groups prior to instruction To determine the comparability between the experimental and control groups prior to intervention, a multivariate analysis of variance for repeated measures was used. MANOVA was selected because tests based upon this approach are free of sphericity assumptions (O’Brian & Kaisar, 1985). The four dependent measures were the mean for the five assessment passages administered in baseline, the scores earned on the pretest summary and question genera ting tasks, and the correct decoding rate of each student. The means and standard deviations for these measures are reported in Table 1. The results indicated that there was no significant difference between the experimental and control group nor was there a significant interaction between group and teacher. There was however, a significant overall teacher effect, F (20,414) – 2 04,p < 005 A series f Bonferroni T tests indicated that this effect was true only for the means on the baseline comprehension assessments and not for the other dependent measures On these assessments, there was a significant difference between those classes taught by teachers two and three, two and five, six and three and six and five[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Strategy training was provided for 4 months and in- cluded three modes of instruction: classroom lessons, bulletin board materials, and suggestions for classroom . teachers on how to use the strategies. 1 The classroom instruction was the most critical component and in- volved 30-min group lessons taught twice each week by M. Lipson. During these lessons children were stimu- lated to think about reading strategies by direct ques- tions and groupdiscussions. Our intention wasto make children reflect upon various goals of reading and the actions, they could take to reach them. Questions, di- alogues, analogies,-and modelingwere all used to stim- ulate awareness. Each lesson also included worksheets that required children to read high-interest material and to apply the instructed strategy. Discussion fol- lowed the worksheets and provided feedback about options for selecting and employing strategies. Throughout the lessons children were persuaded that these were necessary and self-controlled strategies for reading. The second vehicle of instruction was the bulletin board that accompanied each lesson. In order to make each lesson on reading concrete and easy to understand, we chose metaphors to represent each strategy or con- cept. These metaphors were illustrated graphically on large bulletin board displays and were included as themes within each lesson. For example, the lesson on task evaluation used the metaphor "-Be a reading de- tective" to examine clues to the passage topic, length, and difficulty. Strategies for monitoring comprehen- sion were made comprehensible to 7-8-year-olds by using analogies to traffic signs, such as "Stop\x97say the meaning in your own words" arid "Dead end\x97go back and reread the parts you don't understand." Each bulletin board colorfully illustrated the metaphor and included several focal questions that directed children to think about how, why, and when to apply the strat- egy. The metaphors and questions were incorporated into the worksheets and daily lessons. They also served[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"as reminders in the classroom throughout the week to use the instructed strategies."
"The third mode of instruction wasa brief description of each module that was given to classroom teachers. These three-page handouts included descriptions of the strategies, rationales for their importance .to reading, and suggestions for incorporating each one into other classroom activities.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The fundamental purpose of ISL is to inform children about strategies that facilitate reading comprehension. The lessons are designed to illustrate strategies con- cretely and to show children the effort required and benefits derived from their use.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"The entire package of instructional materials included 20 modules ar- ranged in groups of 5 that were sequentially aimed at (a) planning and preparing to read (b) identifying meaning, (c) reasoning about text con- tent, and (d) comprehension monitoring. The first 4 modules in each set introduced a distinct strategy; the 5th module was a review that integrated and repeated the previous four strategies."
"Strategies that involved construction of text meaning (e.g.. elaboration, inference, integration, activation of prior knowledge, and summarization) and compwhension monitoring (e.g., re- reading, self-questioning. checking consistencies, and paraphrasing) were especially emphasized throughout the year. The list of 20 modules is shown in Table 1. Large bulletin board displays illustrating the metaphor for each strategy and posing Òfocal questionsÓ to ask while reading ac- companied each module. Each module included three lessons that were designed to be presented to the entire class in approximately 30 min."
"The first two lessons introduced the metaphor, described the strategy, and ex- plained how to use the strategy while reading. Practice and feedback were provided for the whole class. The third lesson was referred to as a ÒbridgingÓ lesson because the reading material was to be taken from other parts of the teachersÕ curriculum such as social studies or science so that students could learn directly that these strategies should be trans- ferred to content area reading. Worksheets and passagesaccompanied all 60 lessons making more than 300 pages of material in the modules pro- vided to the teachers. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The sequence for the introduction of the three categories of invalid arguments was: (a) the ability to detect faulty generalization, (b) the ability to detect false causality, and (c) the ability to detect invalid testimonial."
"The actual teaching sessions"
" included brisk pacing of lessons (i.e., 8 to 10 learning tasks per minute), immediate correction of errors using procedures specified in the script, a high degree of immediate reinforcement for correct student responses, and teaching to a mastery criterion (i.e., each student was required to complete at least one practice example[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"correctly without help from the teacher before going on to the next skill). In the initial examples in each lesson, teacher prompting was maximized to make the suggested cognitive routine overt. For instance, when attempting the item in Figure 1 on detecting faulty causality, the subject would be required to read the passage aloud and the experimenter would ask, “Tell me one thing that happened in the passage.” After the student responded correctly, the experimenter would ask again, “Tell me another thing that happened.” After identifying the two things that happened, the experimenter asked, “What do we know about these two things?” The student was required to respond with, “They happened together.” After further"
"questioning by the experimenter, the student was required to relate the two things that happened together in the passage to the following rule: Just because two things happened together, it doesn’t always mean that one causes the other. The student would then respond to each item following the passage. This was also done with prompting from the experimenter and, when necessary, correction procedures were introduced. For the remaining examples, the prompting pro\xad cedures were faded until the student success\xad fully completed one item unprompted. If it was felt that a student was having difficulty and seemed to be under stress, the lesson was terminated and reconvened the next day. This happened on three occasions.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"One of the two instructional procedures developed to teach critical reading skills in the present study was based on this model of making cognitive routines overt. Systematic instruction used the principles of subskill analyses, mastery learning, and the cognitive routine model to develop a 3-day teaching sequence.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]". The directed reading activity that was used to teach basal selections was based on the work of Schmitt and Baumann (1986). Comprehension monitoring training during basal reader instruction included prereading activities, guided reading activities, and postreading activities. Specifically, students were taught to (a) activate background knowledge, (b) make predictions about the content, (c) set purposes for reading, (d) generate questions, (e) summarize at various points, (f) evaluate and make new predic- tions, (g) relate new information to prior knowledge, (h) generate questions, (i) summarize total selection, (j) evaluate predictions, (k) return to the purpose set for reading, and (1) generate questions for the total selective. Figure 1 contains a detailed description of a sample lesson plan created for the basal selection Ghost in theOrchard.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The use of these metacognitive skills required the active participation of the student. In order to help students develop metacognitive skills the teacher took a directive role in explaining the reading process, thinking aloud, analyz- ing skills, modeling mental processes, and providing guided practice. Thus, the major focus for instruction was to teach students to use knowledge about the reading task so that they could independently plan, regulate, and monitor their reading/thinking activities. So, initially, the classroom teacher guided the students through each step, but gradually (after six to eight weeks) the students assumed responsibility for them and performed them independently as they read."
"The organization of the lessons in the experimental and control class- rooms was the same, and included prereading activities, a guided reading of the story, and a postreading discussion. However, the experimental treatment encouraged students to take active responsibility for their own comprehension and not to rely as much on the teacher.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"in improving reading comprehension, strategy use, and attitude toward reading was investigated.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"The procedural component was taught by giving information about when to use a strategy; for example, skim before reading a long text, slow down when information seems especially important, make a diagram when there is a lot of interrelated factual information. In addition, information was given about the purpose of a strategy; for example, make a diagram to identify main ideas, make categories to organise information, or skim read to focus attention on the main points. To facilitate regulation of cognition and task planning, we used the instructions in the RC by asking the children about the nature of the task, the goal, the kind of information and strategy and the time and resources they would need. For monitoring, we asked children if they had a clear understanding of what they were doing, if the task made sense, if they needed to make any changes. Evaluation was taught by asking the children if they had reached their goal and what they would do diﬀerently next time.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]" Each training session had a diﬀerent goal: . The ﬁrst concerned mental and concrete representations of the problem: how to create mental images, diagrams, drawings, or graphs. The researcher encouraged the children to compare their representa- tions of the problem. . The aim of the second session was to develop relevant strategies for solving mathematical problems; for example, ‘‘read the question several times’’, ‘‘cross out irrelevant information’’, ‘‘check the calculations’’. . The aim of the third session was to teach children how to identify the key words in order to interpret the problem correctly. Which are the most important words in the question? What are the interrogative pronouns (who, how much, etc.)? What is the unit of the response (Euros, number of years, number of marbles, etc.)? . The aim of the fourth session was to teach children to identify the mathematical expressions: for example, ‘‘what is the remainder?’’ indicates subtraction; the word ‘‘to add’’ indicates addition. . During the ﬁfth and ﬁnal session, the children had to use metacognitive knowledge and skills individually, without help from their peers or the researcher.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"1. Could metacognitive training improve metacognitive knowledge and skills in 8- to 10-year-old children?[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"2. Could metacognitive training improve mathematical word problem- solving performance?[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]"The study was carried out over a 7-week period[¬e]"']

"The second analysis showed no eﬀect of Group on the pre-test macroprediction scores, F(1, 46) ¼ 2.53, p 4 .05, MSE ¼ 1.33, Z 2 p ¼ 0.15, and the third analysis showed no eﬀect of Group on problem-solving scores, F(1, 46) ¼ 2.97, p 4 .05, MSE ¼ 10.08, Z 2 p ¼ 0.15. Further analysis revealed no eﬀect of Group on prediction problem-solving scores (without taking into account the diﬀerence with actual problem-solving performance) F(1, 46) ¼ 0.23, p 4 .05, MSE ¼ 1.33, Z 2 p ¼ 0.15."
"Thus experimental and control groups did not diﬀer on the three metacognition scores.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]" They differentiate between three phases during the process of learning: the preaction phase/forethought, the action phase/performance and volitional control, as well as the postaction phase/reflection."
"The preaction phase (forethought) mainly focuses on goal setting."
" the learner sets individual goals. Studentschoose their goal s considering the kind of exercise at hand and their situational background (e.g., the learner’s attitude to learning which influences the approaching to the task).[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"During the action phase (performance and volitional control), when the task is actually dealt with, the amount of learning time, the use of internal resources (e.g., concentration) and the application of learning strategies (e.g., MSLQ; Pintrich, Smith, Garcia, & McKeachie, 1991) are important to achieve desired outcomes"
" we differentiate between three kinds of strategies: cognitive, metacognitive and resource-oriented strategies."
"After having completed the task, the so-called postaction phase (self-reflection) begins. The learner evaluates the result of his or her effort and draws conclusions for further learning processes (e.g., dealing with mistakes)."
" The theoretical background is depicted in Figure 1. The components of the three phases of self-regulation, as postulated in the model, were integrated in terms of strategies into an intervention implemented in regular mathematics classrooms.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]" metacognitive prompts intervention-science (MPI-S) was composed of examples to demonstrate a target behaviour for the particular task in developing or verifying scientific knowledge, a checklist to self-monitor quality of the task and a graphing activity to self-monitor the breadth of consideration of the scien- tific endeavour during the task. int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Embedded Metacognitive Prompts based on Nature of Science (EMPNOS)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"For the quantitative portion of the study, students from four eighth-grade classes were given measures of metacognitive orientation of the classroom, metacog- nition in science, self-regulatory efÞcacy, nature of science, and content before the intervention began. "
" The inquiry units without the embedded metacognitive prompts were given to the comparison group and the inquiry units with the EMPNOS were given to the experimen- tal group. Students studied the phenomena using the four modules of the intervention with the guidance of the teacher/researcher. Student groups of three or four used the module packets to investigate the learning goals in electricity and magnetism."
"After the second module was complete, all students took the self-regulatory measure in order to measure a midpoint"
"After all four modules were complete, students took the measures as a post-test. A qualitative portion of the study used student focus group interviews, think aloud protocols, and work products to describe processes the different groups used to learn the nature of science."
"EMPNOS consists of checklists and questions orga- nized into four developmental phases strategically placed into lesson plans. Each set of metacognitive prompts represent ideas from one of the seven aspects of the nature of science. Module one focused on empirical data, module two focused on laws and theo- ries, module three focused on peer review and data collection, and module four focused on creativity. In order to address the issue of added time on-task for the experimental group, since they spent time on the checklists and the questions in the prompts, the com- parison group was given additional physical science content questions in their inquiry units.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" examine the effectiveness of a develop- mental intervention, Embedded Metacognitive Prompts based on Nature of Science (EMPNOS) to teach the nature of science using metacognitive prompts embedded in an inquiry unit.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The curriculum of this experimental program was composed of five separate but integrated parts. Part A consisted of discussions, debate over intellectual issues with both high per\xad tinence"
"and low pertinence"
" Part B was practice in critical thinking skills through exerc ises gathered from a variety of sources. In Part C, students were encouraged to use these categories during discussion\xad debate to identify instances when critical thinking skills were not being used in sug\xad gested rationales for positions taken, state\xad ments made for or against solutions and comments ventured."
"Part D consisted of value issues with both high pertinence"
" and low pertinence"
"When an incidence of high per\xad tinence involving value conflicts was dis\xad cussed, staff not directly involved in the class were often used as resource people. "
" In the follow-up pro\xad cess, students not only shared views, but also entered reactions in an ongoing journal."
"The final part of the program, Part E, con\xad sisted of a student-directed independent learning project. At the heart of this effort was the assignment of a mentor for each student."
"As students encountered problems and dilemmas in the process of completing their projects, the teachers, as mentors, were able to engage in a series of one-on-one interchanges in an effort to assist the students in organizational stra\xad tegies, task analysis, and reflective thought."
"Students received a five-step learning packet designed to take them through their project. In step one, a series of introspective surveys were used to identify areas of sincere interest. In step two, students narrowed their broad interest area to a specific project. At the cul\xad mination of step two, students and mentors signed a “Project Agreement” outlining pre\xad liminary ideas, including such things as community resource people to be used, rationales for the project, mentor comments, and projected completion dates. At steps three and four, students outlined their entire work plan, specifying subtasks and checkout dates. At step five, students responded to an ongoing evaluation of the success of each task, including their perceptions of how the completion of the tasks met their expec\xad tations, and were given an opportunity to[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"modify their planned activities in light of their current status. Projects were t hen com\xad pleted over the course of the year, and stu\xad dents kept a “log” of the experience. The students’ projects culminated in a PTA Par\xad ents’ Night in the spring, during which stu\xad dents displayed projects and discussed what they had accomplished with interested adults.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"It can be concluded from these elements that a curriculum model that would maximize the potential for critical thinking and moral de\xad velopment would include: (1) an issues orientation, (2) some issues that would focus on intellectual conflicts, (3) some issues that would focus on value conflicts, (4) issues examined in group and one-on-one situ\xad ations, and (5) the development of skills in identifying flaws in the defense of positions taken on issues.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"The teacher, who had attended in-service ses\xad sions on Kohlbergian The ory, organized ses\xad sions so that students’ justifications for the value positions taken reflected all levels of moral development and were available to all students."\n"In in-service workshops, teachers were given instruction in Kohlbergian Theory, critical thinking skills, the independent study pro\xad cess, and anticipated hurdles.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 18:\n[¬s]"In the text structure instruction (TSI) condition, participants received explicit instruction in composing from sources utilizing text structure strategies. In this condition, participants learned to record main ideas and details, take notes, organize notes in order to plan for writing, and practice writing summaries from single and multiple sources.[¬e]"', 'Page 20:\n[¬s]" PLAN & WRITE for Summarization (PWS) based on De La Paz\x92s (1999) PLAN & WRITE approach, in order to take and organize notes and plan and write summaries from social studies sources. The in- struction had two dimensions: explicit instruction in composing from sources using the mnemonics PLAN and WRITE, and goal- setting, in which the students set personal goals based on their performance on composing-from-sources tasks.[¬e]"']

['Page 5:
[¬s]"The Changing Mindsets project "
"pupil workshop intervention"
"teacher training intervention[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"an intervention that taught pupils directly about the malleability of intelligence through six workshops, which were delivered by undergraduates from the University of Portsmouth, and four further sessions delivered by two local organisations: the Education Business Partnership, and Pompey Study Centre (now called Portsmouth in the Community)."
"a professional development course that trained teachers on approaches to developing and reinforcing growth mindsets through their teaching. This course consisted of two half days of instruction.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"The first intervention consisted of a series of six workshops for pupils. The workshops were delivered in schools by university students employed as project support assistants (PSAs). Half of the pupils on the course were randomly allocated to receive the mindset intervention, while the other half received general study support. The workshops taught pupils about the malleable nature of intelligence, and sought to help pupils develop a growth mindset. The workshops also used hands-on work in maths and literacy\x97demonstrating how not giving up and exploring different strategies can help to find solutions. This part of the intervention was designed and managed by the University of Portsmouth. As far as possible, the format of the course was standardised across schools. The second intervention consisted of staff from the University of Portsmouth training teachers to teach pupils that intelligence is not a fixed characteristic, and to reinforce this in their lessons through the way they communicate with pupils. This was delivered through two half-days of teacher training.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"The evaluation was designed to assess the impact of: \uf0b7 a pupil workshop intervention"\n"\uf0b7 an INSET intervention[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"Pupils in the intervention group received a six-week course of mentoring and workshops with a focus on growth mindset, from trained university students (PSAs). The PSAs were trained in mindset, behaviour management and how to administer the intervention or control workshops, by the academic team at the University of Portsmouth. Pupils who were allocated to the control group received time-matched general study skills support, also delivered by PSAs. Both intervention and control group pupils received a further four-week course of workshops delivered by project partners from the Education Business Partnership and Portsmouth Football Club."\n"Teachers in the intervention group schools received training which was not available to teachers in control group schools. [¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]" six consecutive weeks[¬e]"', 'Page 12:\n[¬s]" two teacher training sessions[¬e]"']
int_cost_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The estimated cost of implementing the pupil workshops intervention over three years is £397 per pupil per year. The estimated cost of implementing the teacher training intervention over three years is £16 per pupil per year (£678 per school per year). Over the single year of this evaluation the teacher training intervention cost £49 per pupil (£2,035 per school). Teachers required two half days of supply cover to participate in the teacher training, which schools might choose to deal with in ways that may or may not incur a financial cost.[¬e]"']

int_dur_info: 12-15 months   The completion of baseline assessments for pupils followed by The first half-day training in January/February 2013,  the second half-day training in April 2013. The initial post-test in June and July 2013 and  the final post assessment between February and April 2014.
int_fidel_ht: ['Page 18:\n[¬s]" Of the 15 intervention schools, 2 schools dropped out after the programme started. One of these was having a difficult time following poor inspection reports and despite receiving the teacher training dropped out before the final assessments. In the other school, University of Portsmouth staff turned up for training on two occasions to discover something else had been arranged so were sent away. Of the 15 control schools 4 dropped out, also after the intervention had started. One of these was due to school restructuring so they were too busy to continue with the study; a second could not find time to conduct either of the post-intervention assessments; and a third did not like the assessments and decided that the trial was of no value to the school. No reason was given by the fourth drop-out school.[¬e]"']
int_fidel_info: Of the 15 intervention schools, 2 schools dropped out after the programme started.  Of the 15 control schools 4 dropped out, also after the intervention had started.

int_name_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"Retention and Transfer of Children\'s Self-Directed Critical Thinking Skills[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"le. Conduct of the discussions. The teacher began the first discussion with a general overview of the purpose of the project?to improve the pupils\' thinking skills?and an explanation of the four roles that the children would play. Each teacher made four tag board signs that bore the label of the four roles. Copies of the definitions of the roles were distributed to the children. Each child played a different role in each discussion. A standard pattern for using the roles was established at the first discussion. The children first read aloud the definition of the role that they were playing that day. Then the children tried to paraphrase the role. The chil dren had considerable difficulty paraphrasing some of the roles (task definer and strategist), especially in the early stages. As the discussions continued, the children became better able to do so. We"\n"ldren to play their roles at appropriate times. Thus, the teacher asked ques tions such as, "Task definer, do you think you\'ve played your role here?" or "Whose job is it to help the group work out a plan to solve the problem?" (strategist). Over the course of the 12 discussions, the teachers prompted children less often. This role for[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"s study was designed to examine the degree to which fourth- and fifth-grade pupils who were trained in self-directed critical thinking skills could retain and transfer those skills. The work reported in this article "\n" [¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"control subjects for the investigation. Inservice education for the teachers. There were two 1-hour inservice seminars for the experimental teachers before the small groups began their work. Unfortunately, the seminars had to be held at the end of the teaching day. The sessions were used to inform the teachers in more detail about the nature of the research project and what their role would be in it. The teachers met 12 times with their small group of four children, and each meeting was attended by an assigned Washington University staff member, who served as a consultant to them and the chil dren and who remained after each discussion to debrief the teacher (what was good about the session, what might be attempted in the next one), and also audiotaped the discussions. The teachers were placed into two small groups, each with one or two of the research team members, and given an opportunity to solve a problem similar to those that their children would work on, but designed for adults. Discussion that followed completion of this problem fo cused on the thinking roles that the children were to learn. Each teacher was later given a manual that con tained a copy of all 12 of the lessons they were to under take and any special suggestions about them. Each teacher was given a starting point on the lessons. Teacher A began the discussions with Lesson 1, Teacher B with Lesson 2, and so forth. Sample. Forty children were originally identified to[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"This study, then, evaluates the effects of a general think- ing skills program, de Bono\x92s CoRT (Cognitive Research Trust) Program, which features divergent and creative thinking.[¬e]"']
int_name_info: general thinking skills program, CoRT (Cognitive Research Trust) Program (Edward de Bono 1973, 1986), featuring divergent and creative thinking
int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]" the CoRT lessons provide a framework where the emphasis is placed directly on thinking, 0 pupils are encouraged to think, and are given credit for their thinking, l pupils get opportunities to think in groups, to put their ideas across and to interact with the ideas of others, l CoRT offers a selection of specific and deliberate thinking skills, l pupils are encouraged to view thinking as a skill that can be learned and practised, pupils can practise and see their improvement,[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"62 S. M. RITCHIE and J. EDWARDS l the improvement is in confidence, focus, fluency, and application, l pupils feel in control of their thinking, rather than drifting in a sea of emotion and confu- sion, and l another intention of CoRT is the learning of specific thinking tools which can be transferred to other situations.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"The thinking program consisted of a selection of 20 lessons from the CoRT program. More specifically, the entire CoRT1 program (10 lessons) and five lessons each from the CoRT-4 and CoRT-6 programs were taught. De Bono (1991) recommends that the programs can be taught in any sequence provided one begins with CoRT-1 (Breadth). Lessons from the CoRT-4 (Creativity) and CoRT-6 (Action) were chosen because of their potential to enhance creative thinking (CoRT-4) and application (CoRT-6) of the thinking skills in practice. The sequence of the lessons as well as a brief description of each lesson is displayed in Figure 1.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"e primary object of this tool approach is to build a metacognitive pattern which can be used to direct attention (de Bono, 1986a).[¬e]"']
int_objec_info: The title and results suggests that the intervention aimed to improve creative thinking  flexibility, fluency and originality of thinking was measured.
int_prov_info: One school was 400 km apart from Townsville. Only a university could solve that distance. Also a researcher was monitoring the lessons in town
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Training of the three treatment teachers consisted of two one-hour meetings conducted with each of the teachers separately. During the first meeting, the salient features of each skill from the CoRT-1 program were identified. As well, the steps involved in a typical CoRT-1 lesson were illustrated with examples from the CoRT-1 Teacher\x92s Notes (de Bono, 1986b, pp. 44-63). After this introduction the teachers were asked to read the relevant advice from the CoRT Teacher\x92s Notes prior to the commencement of the program. The second training meeting was scheduled to follow the CoRT-1 program. During this meeting, the major features of each set of five lessons from CoRT-4 and CoRT-6 were outlined. Because each teacher had some experience with CoRT lessons by the time of the second meet- ing, emphasis was placed on how the structure of CoRT-4 and CoRT-6 lessons differed from[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"As with the CoRT-1 training meeting, each of the scheduled lessons was outlined and the CoRT Teacher\x92s Notes were provided.[¬e]"']
int_training_info: Training of the three treatment teachers consisted of two one-hour meetings conducted with each of the teachers separately.
int_who_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The treatment teachers were asked to teach one CoRT lesson per week, usually lasting about 45 minutes. These lessons were monitored by a researcher in the two city classes.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The thinking program consisted of a selection of 20 lessons from the CoRT program. More specifically, the entire CoRT1 program (10 lessons) and five lessons each from the CoRT-4 and CoRT-6 programs were taught. "\n" The first CoRT lesson was taught in early March and the treatment concluded in early September. The implementation schedule was interrupted during school vacations (ap- proximately 4 weeks-there were two vacation periods in April and June) and in the weeks on either side of a school vacation (another 4 weeks).[¬e]"']
int_fidel_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"These lessons were monitored by a researcher in the two city classes. The regional treatment teacher audio-taped each CoRT lesson so that the treatment in that school could be monitored. "\n"There were no significant departures, in any class, from the lesson outlines in the CoRT Teacher\x92s Notes (de Bono, 1986b, c, d).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" The Denktraining program is based on Klauer\'s theory of inductive reasoning and transfer (e.g., Klauer, 1988, 1989a, 1989b, 1991). In Klauer\'s view, the domain of inductive reasoning is constituted by a lim- ited number of basic problem structures or ``paradigms.\'\' The Klauer pro- gram teaches these paradigms by way of prototypical examples and offers practice in applying speci®ed solution procedures to various instances of the paradigms.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 42:
[¬s]"The comprehension strategy for the COMP condition required students to read each page of their text booklet and, for each page of text, write answers to the following questions in the margin of their booklets: 1. What is this section of the story about? 2. Why is this information important to the story or how does this relate to other sections of the story? 3. How can I remember what this section is about?"
"In addition to these three questions, students in the COMP/MET condition were
instructed to ask themselves the following metacognitive question and act accordingly:
Does this section make sense to me? If I don't understand, I need to go back
and read the section again.
Students in both instructional conditions were told that this would be the strategy they
needed to use as they read through their booklets."
"After reading through the entire booklet and responding to the strategy questions
in the margin on each page of their booklet, students were presented with an additional
strategy: they were instructed to write a brief summary of the story they read. In
addition to the instruction to write a summary, students in the COMP/MET condition
were instructed to ask themselves the following metacognitive question and act
accordingly:
Have I done a good job in learning the information in the story, or do I need to
go back and look over the information again?"
"Students were then administered the comprehension measure."
"On the second, third, and fourth day of[¬e]"', 'Page 43:
[¬s]"instruction, teachers assumed the role of facilitator, and students were given the
opportunity to actively practice applying the strategies. On these subsequent days of
instruction, students were reminded of the strategy and also of how the strategy would
help them improve their comprehension.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 14:

reading by comparing the effectiveness of two forms of instruction on fourth-grade
students' strategy use, metacognition, and comprehension.[¬e]"', 'Page 34:

comprehension questions for the five days of instruction, as well as the metacognitive
questionnaire and the general plan for administering these materials. Teachers were then
presented with the administration instructions and scripts for each day of instruction (see
Appendix B for example). The purpose of these prepared instructions and scripts was
to standardize instruction across school sites, since it was not possible to schedule

Teachers were asked to complete the same form at the end of each day of instruction.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"The procedure during the five sessions devoted to each type of paragraph was identical. At the start of the first session, a tester administered a self-efficacy for improvement test, which was identical to that of the pretest except children judged capabilities for improving their skills at the five tasks for the paragraph type to be covered during the next five sessions rather than how well they already could perform the tasks."
"Following this assessment, the teacher gave the goal instructions appropriate for chil\xad dren's experimental assignment (discussed below), after which he or she referred to the writing strategy displayed on a poster board: What do 1 have to do? (I) Choose a topic to write about. (2) Write down ideas about the topic. (3) Pick the main idea. (4) Plan the paragraph. (5) Write down the main idea and the other sentences. The first 10 min were devoted to modeled demonstration in which the teacher verbalized the strategy’s steps and applied them to sample topics and paragraphs. Students then re\xad ceived guided practice (15 min); they applied the steps under the guidance of the teacher. The last 20 minutes of each session were devoted to independent practice; students worked alone while the teacher monitored their work. The daily content coverage was the same for each of the four types of paragraphs; session 1—strategy steps 1, 2, 3; session 2—strategy step 4; session 3—strategy step 5; session 4—review of entire strategy; session 5—review of[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"entire strategy without the modeled demonstration. Children worked on two or three para\xad graph topics per session."
"To children assigned to the process goal and the process goal plus progress feedback conditions the teacher said at the beginning of the first five sessions, "While you're working it helps to keep in mind what you're trying to do. You'll be trying to learn how to use these steps to write a descriptive paragraph." These goal instructions were identical for the other sessions except the teacher substituted the name of the appro\xad priate type of paragraph."
"Each child assigned to the process goal plus progress feedback condition received feed\xad back 3-4 times during each session. This feedback conveyed that children were making progress toward their goal of learning to use the strategy to write paragraphs. Teachers delivered feedback to each child privately during independent practice with such statements as, "You’re learning to use the steps," and, "You're doing well because you followed the steps in order." To ensure that feedback was credible, teachers provided feedback contin\xad gent on the child using the strategy properly.[¬e]"']

[¬s]" Although the process and product goals were comparable in spec\xad ificity, proximity, and difficulty, the process goal was expected to high\xad light strategy use as a means to improve writing. Students who believe they are learning a useful strategy experience greater control over learn\xad ing and self-efficacy for skill improvement"
". Perceived strategy usefulness can motivate students to apply the strategy, which promotes skill acquisition"
" we felt that our subjects, who had average writing skills, could focus on their progress in learning the strategy and on how the strategy was improving their writing. In contrast, a goal of writing paragraphs or a general goal may not convey that the strategy is important. Learners who believe a strategy does not contribute much do not employ it sys\xad tematically or feel confident about learning[¬e]"']

['Page 4:
[¬s]" In each lesson, with each paper-and-pencil Instrument page, the pupils with their teacher first discuss how best to find out what information they need to gather to work on the problems, and formulate one or more plans for solving the problems. After a period of individual work on the problems, during which the teacher intervenes merely to guide pupils out of unproductive strategies, the pupils again discuss, in terms of cognitive functions, their successes and difficulties, summarise what they have learnt about productive strategies, and finally attempt to invent other applications both in school learning and out of school activities for the successful strategies. This last element of the IE lesson is called bridging. The intended frequency of IE lessons is five 50 minute to one hour lessons a week, for a period of two years at least[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"The experimental group were withdrawn from the class for three lessons a week of IE each week for the twenty months duration of the experiment. These lessons were conducted by the trained IE teacher[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]" The only departure from optimum conditions other than the pupils receiving less than five lessons a week is that the class teacher, not sharing the IE methodology, was therefore not able to continue the process of 'Bridging' into the other lessons which the pupils received.[¬e]"']

['Page 4:
[¬s]"The Reading Edge Ð program description The Reading Edge is a comprehensive literacy program for all middle-grade students, from struggling to advanced, with the goal of preparing them to be strategic, indepen- dent and motivated readers and learners. The Reading Edge combines effective instructional practices, a coherent curriculum, and frequent informal assessment and feedback to students, with extensive professional development for teachers and instructional leaders. This enables middle school teachers to provide intensive reading instruction that emphasizes four key areas: metacognitive strategy use, cooperative learning, goal-setting and feedback, and classroom management. Since reading levels vary widely for this age group, students are assessed and grouped for instruction in classes at their instructional level. All reading classes meet during the same 60-minute period each day. Students are re-assessed quarterly to determine their current levels of performance. These assessment results allow teachers and students to monitor and discuss progress, and to move students immediately to a more challenging group. This structure allows for differentiated, targeted instruction, as well as rapid acceleration. It allows students who are struggling with decoding and phonics to work through well-structured texts with a high proportion of phonetically decodable words, while in other classes, students use novels or expository texts appro- priate to their reading level to improve fluency and comprehension. Students receive regular feedback on their work, and set and review personal goals. As soon as students are ready, they move to the next level. Extensive training and ongoing coaching support within collaborative learning communities enable teachers to implement this aspect of the program efficiently and with integrity. Every Reading Edge lesson follows a regular pattern, but the instruction itself varies according to the nature of the text and the challenges it presents. Program developers carefully choose readings that lead the students to relevant discoveries and practice opportunities. Combining explicit instruction in metacognitive reading strat- egies with peer collaboration and regular assessment and feedback builds studentsÕ confidence as they try out their new tactics. Although lessons vary significantly in level of difficulty and purpose, all follow this structure: setting the stage; active instruction; teamwork; and time for reflection. The four key areas of metacognitive strategy use, cooperative learning, goal setting and feedback, and classroom management are embedded in the everyday class- room routines that teachers use for instruction and that students use to become better readers (Slavin et al., 2005). The following sections describe how each of the key program areas is manifested in The Reading Edge.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"16 R. Slavin et al. Cooperative learning in The Reading Edge Cooperative learning refers to a wide variety of methods in which students work in small groups (usually four members) to help one another learn. Extensive experimental research on cooperative learning methods has found that these strategies generally increase student achievement if they incorporate group goals and individual account- ability (Slavin, 1995; Slavin, Hurley, & Chamberlain, 2003; Webb & Palincsar, 1996). Cooperative learning has been particularly effective and extensively researched in middle schools (Roseth, Johnson, & Johnson, 2008; Slavin et al., 2003). Cooperative learning methods in which students have regular opportunities to discuss ideas with partners, to help each other study, and to provide formative feedback to each other have been successfully evaluated in several randomized evaluations in elementary and middle schools (Slavin, 1978, 1995; Slavin & Karweit, 1984). Cooperative learning has also been successfully evaluated many times as a means of introducing and practicing metacognitive skills. For example, Meloth and Deering (1992, 1994) found that peers could help each other acquire metacognitive strategies. Dansereau (1988) and OÕDonnell (1996) studied Ôcooperative scriptsÕ, in which students took turns summarizing and evaluating each otherÕs summaries. Fantuzzo, Polite, and Grayson (1990) developed and evaluated reciprocal peer tutoring strategies to help students study complex material. In The Reading Edge, students work in teacher-assigned cooperative teams of four or five students. Each student is individually accountable for his or her own learning and there are no group grades. However, teams are rewarded when all members improve their performance compared to their past performance. Students set goals together, and with the support of practiced routines, they help each other learn new content, use, evaluate, and personalize strategies, and remain attentive to the task at hand. Teams also provide a safe environment for individuals to try out new ideas or admit when they are confused. Each team works to help each member achieve his or her Ôpersonal bestÕ so there is always an equal opportunity for success Ð teams are not in competition with each other. Metacognition in The Reading Edge Numerous studies show that metacognition plays an important role in both learning to read and in learning new content through reading (Armbruster, Anderson, & Ostertag, 1987; Gertz, 1994; Langer & Neal, 1987). Research suggests that students who can assess their own knowledge and interest in a topic and choose and apply effective strategies to understand unfamiliar text on that topic can control their learning envi- ronment and successfully make meaning from what they read (Tei & Stewart, 1985). Metacognitive strategies are directly taught in specific Reading Edge lessons, and regular use of strategies is supported by the routines built into every lesson. Early in every Reading Edge lesson, students are presented with ÔThe big questionÕ, a provoc- ative question that students ponder and discuss over the course of the dayÕs activities. With stems such as ÔHave you everÉÕ or ÔHow would you handle this characterÕs challengeÉÕ or ÔBased on what you know aboutÉÕ, students must draw upon their own experiences and beliefs as well as details from the text they are reading in order to formulate their answer. This question often leads to student-generated questions of the same kind, and enriches team and partner discussions about the text. It also requires students to paraphrase or summarize what they have read, and encourages students to monitor their comprehension as they read.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Effective Education 17 Also in the beginning of every lesson, teachers complete a ÔBuilding backgroundÕ segment in which they activate prior knowledge with ÔKWLÕ charts that ask students to summarize what they know about the topic (K), what they want to know (W), and then, at the end of the lesson, what they learned (L). Teachers make connections to student interests, and hold conversations in which they discuss vocabulary important to the understanding of the text. They preview the text and discuss text features that prompt students to make predictions about the main idea, topic, or theme, depending on the nature of the text. During the ÔActive instructionÕ portion of the lesson, the teacher engages students in targeted instruction on how to use a particular strategy or skill. For example, the teacher will read aloud a passage from the text and stop and Ôthink aloudÕ about some- thing significant, perhaps an example of foreshadowing, and how it influences her thinking as she reads. As she does this, she is breaking down a larger strategy into smaller steps so students can understand the otherwise invisible tools that good read- ers use. Now that this strategy has been modeled and discussed, students practice using it as they read, and later reflect upon whether or not it helped them. Teachers use techniques for keeping the lesson moving at a brisk pace by posing important questions to the entire class, allowing for team discussion, and randomly call- ing on students to answer as representatives of their teams. Students learn that any team member could be called upon to answer for their team, so they must help each other prepare to answer every question (Kagan, 2001). For quick checks for understanding, teachers use whole-class responses such as Ôthumbs-up/thumbs-downÕ to keep the pace of instruction brisk, and every child involved (Emmer, Evertson, & Worsham, 2003). During teamwork, students read some text silently and some aloud with a partner. They stop regularly to paraphrase what they just read, to share insights, and to clarify understanding. After reading, each team of four or five students uses another routine to discuss what they have read, and ÔDiscuss and defendÕ their answers to prepared ÔTeam talk questionsÕ. Students have the opportunity to clarify their thinking, try out new ideas, use new vocabulary, and help someone else understand the text, all in the safety of a small collaborative group. During teamwork time, the teacher circulates around the room to check for understanding, prompts and reinforces positive behavior, and conducts quick, informal conferences with partners or teams called ÔOne-to-onesÕ. During these interactions, the teacher can informally assess the studentsÕ grasp of the targeted strategy or skill. Goal-setting and feedback At the beginning of every cycle (six days of instruction ending with a curriculum-based assessment), students receive a Learning Guide. On it, students record reading goals for each lesson and points they earn for classwork, homework, and tests that make up their grade for the cycle. The Learning Guide is a self-assessment tool that helps the students identify strengths and weaknesses and set personal goals. It also helps students stay organized. Students keep track of their work as they complete it, and identify the work they still need to master. As the teacher visits each team during one-to-one confer- ences, she initials work that students have done well, and helps them identify next steps. Teams can earn bonus points for demonstrating extra effort by participating in activities such as ÔBook clubÕ, in which students share their critiques of books they have read outside of school. In ÔWord wiseÕ, students share how they have used their vocabulary words in new contexts. Students also learn to use a team mastery process[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"18 R. Slavin et al. to prepare for the end of cycle test. This gives students time to try out new study skills in a personally meaningful context. At the end of each cycle, students compare their current total score to their previ- ous work. Teams receive Ôimprovement pointsÕ for each member who increases his or her score, and the team is recognized in a whole-class celebration. This is also a time for the whole class to review their reading goals for the cycle and discuss which strat- egies worked well for them, which ones did not, and why. Every quarter, students take a standardized reading assessment. This information is added to the growing set of data about how students are performing. Students know that as soon as they show sufficient improvement in reading, they will move up to the next level, or even skip a level.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]" In line with models of self-regulation, the complete instructional program contains three parts. Firstly, principles of motivational aspects of self-regulation (MSR) are introduced to the students. Secondly, reading strategies (Strat) as mentioned in the ÔOECMÕ-schema are taught and Þnally, a working-routine for cognitive self-regulation (CSR) is presented to the students. The instructional script and materials cover about 20 les- sons comprising of 45 min each. The program is based on a training developed by Schreblowski and Hasselhorn (2001) for small-group coaching in addition to classroom instruction."
" during the Þrst four lessons, students were introduced to principles of goal-setting, self-assessment and causal attribution. By means of a game whereby students had to throw a ring, they were shown that e in contrast to the usual competition e one can Þnd out a realistic goal (with average difÞculty) for oneself, depending upon oneÕs own ability."
" These motivational aspects of self- regulation are repeated when students are dealing with texts later in the program. Using a metaphor Þrst described by Paris et al. (1984; ÔÔbe a reading detectiveÕÕ), the next lesson deals with the analogy between a ÔÔreal detectiveÕÕ and a ÔÔtext-detectiveÕÕ. As a detectiveÕs professional characteristics include searching for information, systematically fol- lowing a clue, and carefully monitoring the investigations e procedures that are quite familiar to the students e similarities concerning the reading process are discussed explicitly."
"At the beginning of the core strategy program two cognitive strategies are introduced to the students. Thinking about the headline of a story leads to an activation of prior knowledge. Forming mental images while reading a text supports looking for details and reading slowly, which helps to elaborate the information of a text and to inte- grate it with prior knowledge and beliefs. Students are told that these elaborative strategies support deeper understand- ing of a text. In general, instructional methods such as modelling and informed teaching were suggested as well as high intensity of interaction amongst students.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Organizational strategies that reduce the text and help keep information in the readerÕs mind are contents of the next lessons. With the help of a text containing enumerations and redundancies students learn to condense information and to differentiate between more or less important passages of the text. The Þrst strategy is to underline important infor- mation and the second strategy is to summarize important information in oneÕs own words. Additionally, there is also a metacognitive strategy to check if the main ideas can be recalled after summarizing a text. Again, there is a close connection between cognitive and metacognitive strategies. The metacognitive strategy proves if the use of the cog- nitive strategy, like summarizing, led to a satisfactory result."
"The aim of the last lessons is to join the seven strategies together in an integrated routine that students can rely on. To illustrate that strategies should be used in a ßexible way and with regard to a speciÞc task there are some exercises called ÔÔmeans and goalsÕÕ. Students are asked to decide which strategies are appropriate in order to achieve a certain goal. The last step in the text-detective program is a ÔÔreading planÕÕ that offers a structured schema for planning, mon- itoring and regulating the reading process. Questions about the task/goal (before reading), choice of strategies (during reading), and success/consequences (after reading) promote cognitive self-regulation. The program ends with a second ÔÔreading gameÕÕ where students have to apply the reading plan to a text without assistance.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The main purpose of promoting motivational aspects was to support self-regulated learning e goal-setting, strategy use, and investment of effort. Beyond this function of supporting strategy instruction we predicted that students in experimental classes with the program including motivational aspects of self-regulation would show signiÞcantly higher gains on self-efÞcacy and learning-goal orientation than students in control classes. Introducing strategy instruction into the classroom should bring about long-term effects. If the implementation of a strategy program leads to instructional change and to main ideas being transferred to further lessons, students will be given many opportunities to practice and internalize self-regulated reading. This should result in increased strategy knowledge and reading comprehension even months after Þnishing the program. We predicted that students in all ex- perimental classes would show signiÞcantly higher gains on knowledge about reading strategies and a standardized reading comprehension test than the control children in a retention test. According to the motivational variables higher scores were expected for the classes in which the complete program was implemented.[¬e]"']

[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 17:
[¬s]"Strategy training. This treatment provided students with explicit instruction in comprehension fostering strategies and metacomprehension strategies, and an explanation of their usefulness in understanding and remembering the information presented in the passage. Students in this group were taught specific strategies for identifying the topic and main idea of paragraphs. The strategy[¬e]"', 'Page 18:
[¬s]"instruction stressed that the main idea of the passage should be a short summary of what all of the sentences in the passage tell about the topic. Students also were taught a self-checking strategy to judge the appropriateness of their main idea statement by testing its completeness and accuracy in summarizing the information in the passage."
" Initially, the students learned a text-based procedure in which they were directed to the information in the text to determine which subject(s) the sentence was about. The students received instruction via computer tutorial which modeled the text-based procedure for each sentence of the paragraph, noting the subject of each of the sentences."
"Following the tutorial, the students practiced this strategy in a multiple choice format. Initial stages of practice used heavily prompted items that were very similar to the tutorial. Later practice activities were less prompted, simply asking the student to read the paragraph and identify the topic from a list of alterna\xad tives. Any errors made by the student were corrected by directing[¬e]"', 'Page 19:
[¬s]"t-he student's attention to relevant portions of the text and indicating that the word or phrase was another name or way of referring to the topic. Items that were answered incorrectly were then coded as "not mastered" by the computer and returned to the practice queue. Then the student was given another similar para\xad graph and a repeat of the activity."
"After instruction and practice on identifying the topic of paragraphs, students were taught strategies for identifying the main idea of the passage and metacomprehension strategies for self\xad checking. "
"Initially these strategies were modeled via computer tutorial, which presented a portion of the paragraph and then described what potential main idea(s) fit the paragraph to that point. This was followed by practice with corrective feedback in which portions of paragraphs were presented to the student in an activity like the tutorial.[¬e]"', 'Page 20:
[¬s]"The computer tutorial also modeled metacognitive strategies for checking main idea statements by comparing them to the textual information provided, students were presented with a portion of a passage (two to three sentences) and asked if they could select the appropriate main idea from a list of four alternatives. If not, they could get another portion of the paragraphs."
"Following the tutorial, the students practiced determining if portions of a paragraph provided sufficient information to select an appropriate main idea.[¬e]"', 'Page 21:
[¬s]"Students also learned to check their earlier choice(s) against the additional information. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]" five weeks of training were conducted with nine fourth grade classes, both during regular classroom instruction and through homework activities.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"During the first week the focus was on self-evaluation and monitoring, that is, the pupils were to identify their own personal strengths and weaknesses in homework behavior for the subject of mathematics (see \x93Introduction\x94).[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Nine classes of fourth grade pupils in German were getting instructions on time management, self-regulation and motivation during a 5 week intervention in Maths class / Maths home work
int_objec_ht: NA
int_objec_info: To get faster and beter in solving maths problems (home work)
int_training_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]" after participating in a 3-day seminar (see below for detailed description)."
"The teachers who administered the training attended a 3-day seminar which was conducted by the authors of this report. On the first day, the theoretical groundwork of self-regulated learning was presented. The second day was dedicated to the topics of time management and behavior patterns relevant to home study. Discussions related to self-regulated learning were also conducted. In addition, all learning materials relating to the training were distributed and discussed. On the third day, the teachers worked together to conceptualize 25 sets of math exercises, five math quizzes (see below), and a comprehensive final exam which was to be completed by all students in all classes. The intention of this exam was to provide an indicator of the training\x92s success. The training\x92s content addressed the abilities associated with time management, self- regulated learning and the preparation of classroom materials at home (for more details and the materials see Zimmerman et al. 1996). In order to mediate these skills a particular domain and subject matter had to be specified. In our case mathematics was the chosen domain and the subject matter was the math content described below. However, as long as[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"the construction principles concerning the exercise sheets and quizzes are upheld, the training can be implemented in alternative domains and with other types of subject matters.[¬e]"']
int_when_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]" activities at home, and the materials are supplemented by several handouts on homework behavior.[¬e]"']

int_leng_info: not mentioned  classroom time at school + individual time on home work at home
int_fidel_info: Three children in the training condition were excluded from the analyses because they were absent at least ten of the 25 training days.

int_desc_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"The majority of lessons followed the same pattern; an introductory discussion followed by experimental work and then further class discussion. During the class discussion the teacher questioned the students in order to facilitate discussion but did not provide answers. Every student was encouraged to participate in the discussions and each was given continual positive support in keeping with the general philosophy of Feuerstein. The questions asked during the discussions were directed at compensating for cognitive deficiencies displayed in the interviews. In addition, a variety of modalities were used including verbal, symbolic and pictorial. The level of complexity was kept to a minimum to make it as easy as possible for the students to process the information. The intention was to avoid confusion with difficult chemical names or complex pieces of glassware. Thus only very simple reactions and apparatus were used.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The experiment was designed to test the hypothesis that teaching the chemical reactions module, using methods which compensate for the cognitive deficiencies found previously to be associated with learning about chemical reactions, will result in a better general understanding of chemical change.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Two kinds of worked-out examples were used in the experiment. The worked-out examples contained two kinds of ratio word problems: an easy word problem and a difﬁcult word problem. The easy worked-out example prob- lem, which students in the self-explanation group and the self-learning group received, consisted of ﬁve solution steps. The difﬁcult worked-out example problem, which students in the self- explanation group and the self-learning group also received, consisted of seven solution steps."
"Students in the self-explanation group were asked to self-explain each solution step.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Before students wrote down their explanations in the blank spaces on the example sheet dur- ing self-explaining for each solution step, they were asked about whether they understood a problem solution at each step. When students understood it, they answered “yes” and then wrote down their explanations. When students did not understand the problem solution at each step, they circled the “no” answer in pencil. Then, they were encouraged to write down their explanations about why they did not understand it. [¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"students in the self-explanation group and the self-learning group studied two worked-out examples."
" Students in the self-explanation group were instructed to"
"self-explain a problem solution at each step and did not receive feedback on their explana- tions. "
"Each group was given 20 min to work on each of the above activities.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"The procedure whereby students ﬁrst make “yes” or “no” judgments to each solution step is more likely to promote monitoring of their understanding of the solution step. When stu- dents give “yes” responses to solution steps, they understand what sentential expressions at the solution steps mean. As a result, students who make “yes” judgments will draw more inferences pertaining to correct solutions. Students integrate information about the sentential expressions with their existing know- ledge. This integration process can be facili- tated by requiring students to make “yes” or “no” judgments and self-explain the content of a sentential expression at each solution step. We hypothesized that students in the self-explanation group would outperform students in the other two groups on ratio word problem and transfer tests.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: The effects of training inductive reasoning (Mauer 1989) on inductive reasoning and maths
int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The rationale of the pro\xad gram is that regularities among objects are induced by strategies of comparison, i.e., by a search for similarities and/or differences, either with attributes of objects, or with relations. Comparing objects in order to find out (a,) similarity or (a 2 ) difference or (a 3 ) both with respect to (bj) attributes or (b 2 ) relations leads to 3x2=6 different types of strategies. Accordingly, it is possible to distinguish six kinds of inductive reasoning tasks or problems: generalization (similarity between attributes), discrimination (difference between attributes), cross-classification (similarity and difference between attributes), recognizing relations (simi\xad larity between relations), discriminating relations (difference between relations) and system construction (similarity and difference between relations)."
"The training program consists of 120 problems, i.e., each kind of inductive problem and problem-solving strategy is represented by 20 items. Only 15 percent of the items use abstract, meaningless material. Most of the remaining 85 percent consist either of concrete material, blocks the children can manipulate, or pictorial-figural problems taken from the every-day lives of the children. In this way, the children learn to apply the strategy to a great variety of problem situations but the transfer distance between training and test material remains considerable. Training procedure. Following the pretest, the children assigned to the training group received the treatment each school day for a period of one week. Each of the five training ses\xad sions took about 30 minutes. The children assigned to the training group were trained in three groups of six, six, and five by three researchers, who were not involved in administering the[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"pretests and posttests. At the beginning of the first training session, the children were given the opportunity to become familiar with the problems. When a child gave an incorrect response in a training session, the researcher asked: “How do you know that?” or “Can you demonstrate that?” The child was then asked to perform the item again until he or she gave a correct response. Within the same time frame, the control group counterpart of a trained child had to complete tasks from the school program. The training program is designed for ten training sessions. Since only five sessions could be given, the trainers tried to administer more than the usual twelve items per session. In fact, they succeeded in working on 80 to 90 instead of 60 problems. [¬e]"']
int_desc_info: 7-year-old pupils were guided to tackle problem solving by inductive reasoning in five half-an-hour sessions in small groups (5-6 students)
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The aim of Klauer’s program is to help children acquire a strategy of inductive reasoning which can be modified in different ways according to the inductive reasoning tasks distin\xad guished by the author. Transfer is not expected to occur automatically, for instance by a process of stimulus generalization; instead, it is necessary to teach transfer by offering a great number and variety of problem situations.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"The purpose of the experiment was to replicate Klauer’s training program and measure the effects on the performance of children on tests measuring inductive reasoning.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]" Mauer (1989) designed a program for the development of inductive reasoning strategies (see also the American version by Mauer & Phye, 1994). The rationale of the pro\xad gram is that regularities among objects are induced by strategies of comparison, i.e., by a search for similarities and/or differences, either with attributes of objects, or with relations.[¬e]"']
int_objec_info: to improve problem solving and inductive reasoning
